Clinical and demographic data and information concerning water, sanitation, and crowding were collected in a detailed questionnaire while the patient received inpatient care.Results. Among 787 suspected cholera cases identified, 1028 rectal swabs were collected. The ability of Chlamydia-specific T cells to recognize different epitopes from the 60-kilodalton heat shock protein (HSP60), a major outer membrane protein, termed A1, and two immunodominant epitopes from major outer membrane proteins, termed A2 and A3, was compared for two strains of C57bl/6 mice. Two 7-mer peptides A2 and A3 were previously identified through synthesized overlapping peptides that were bound to purified HSP60 by using monoclonal antibody. The third epitope, A1, was deduced through synthesis of truncated peptides that were bound to purified HSP60 and overlapped with two other epitope (A2 and A3). To identify epitopes and compare T cell responses between two C57bl/6 mouse strains, a T cell cloning assay was established. Murine splenocytes from C57bl/6(H-2b) and B10.D2(H-2d) mice primed with HSP60 were stimulated with different overlapping peptides mixed with antigen-presenting cells (APC). After screening cell populations for reactivity to antigens, the most frequent pattern of reactivity was to HSP60 followed by a 7-mer peptide A3. We were able to isolate T cell clones recognizing both A1 and A3 peptides. Surprisingly, we also isolated six T cell clones specific for the HSP60 itself that do not react with any HSP60-derived peptides when tested in a direct T cell proliferation assay. This ability of T cells to recognize the HSP60 and its epitopes correlated with the production of cytokines induced by the HSP60. 1. [INST] Hello. You are taking a medical class about the clinical trials and want to learn about various kinds of clinical trials. I will teach you about three kinds of trials today. 


This is a phase I/II trial to test a new drug for the treatment of advanced breast cancer that failed chemotherapy. This trial is being conducted in a cohort with a similar disease progression so that the clinical effects of the new drug may be assessed in the homogeneous population in an early phase. The new drug is administered to patients as three times at a 28-day interval. The drug is an alkylating agent and it may produce myelosuppression. Myelosuppression is a decrease in numbers of blood cells produced by bone marrow due to the adverse effects of a drug. 
 
This trial is a phase III trial to test a combined treatment with antidepressants for patients with major depression who failed monotherapy of antidepressant. Treatment-resistant depression, in which patients fail multiple antidepressant treatments, is severe and it affects quality of life and social functioning. This trial is being conducted in a cohort with similar clinical courses and the efficacy of the combined treatment is being assessed by using response rate and remodeling rate of the patients. The combined treatment is administered sixteen times at a 28-day interval on average. Combined treatment consists of an antidepressant and an anxiolytic.
 
This is a phase IV trial comparing two antihistamines for patients with allergic rhinitis. The clinical effects between two antihistamines are being assessed by determining difference in score of nasal patency and nasal symptoms. This trial is being conducted once at the last date of allergy season. Antihistamines work by inhibiting H1 receptors and blocking the production of chemical mediators of the inflammation response, such as serotonin, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins. # Methods section

## Data preprocessing
For this study, we obtained 245965 clinical trial notes from ClinicalTrials.gov, which represents almost one million notes. These clinical trial notes are structured into three different tables containing patient identifier information, subject identifier information, and study identifier information, respectively. All these three tables are in comma-separated values (CSV) format.
We also obtain meta data of 36 clinical trials from the ClinicalTrials.gov database, and they are downloaded as JSON encoded formatted data. Then we parse those json formatted data and obtain 26 numeric features for preprocessing. We finally extract all the clinical trial information from the meta data, including study type, duration, recruitment status, title, interventions of the clinical trials.

## Data imbalance solving
We extract the numeric values from meta data. However, we find that there is a severe data imbalance in our data set. As shown in [fig_ref]  Figure 4: Numbers of data in training data set the data imbalance of our... [/fig_ref]  , there are more than 24 times of data labels as well as cases, while only about 1.8% cases are labeled 2. Then we select the 400 most representative features with the help of the scikit-learn package, and remove the features for which the mean of the data is equal to zero. Finally, we only retained about 6% of the data. Our strategy helps us to focus on features that are extremely effective. And we randomly remove 80% of the data, which achieves the ratio of 80:20 for training set and test set.

## Deep learning architecture
Our deep learning model consists of convolutional, max-pooling layers, batch normalization (BN) layer, and dense layer, which are well suited for solving non-trivial text classification tasks like our task. The detailed architecture of the proposed model is shown in [fig_ref]  Figure 5: The architecture of our proposed modelFig [/fig_ref] .

## Convolutional layer
Convolutional layer is the most important part in a deep learning network which contains a feature extractor and a convolution kernel. It helps to avoid complex computations and provides the features (vectors) for the max-pooling layer. The convolution

<EOD> Ex vivo inhibition of PDH and PDHE1 phosphorylation attenuates cytosolic Ca2+ elevations in mice with obstructive cholestasis

Bile acid (BA)-induced cellular dysfunction is an important contributor to the progression of cholestatic liver disease. However, a role for the BAinduced altered flux of cellular energy metabolism in affecting cellular dysfunction is unknown. Using metabolomics, it has been reported that cytosolic pyruvate is consumed in mouse cholangiocytes via a maladaptive mode of energy metabolism to supply cytosolic acetyl-CoA for BA synthesis. However, whether the reduced pyruvate availability affects energy metabolism and/or hepatic functions is unclear. A reduction in the flux of one or more glycolytic intermediates, such as pyruvate, is expected to increase pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) activity and result in cytosolic alanine production. Here we report that the levels of the BA hydroxylation products, CA/MCA/HCA are increased in the livers and bile of patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis, and these correlate with increased levels of alanine in the bile of these patients. To mimic these observations in experimental models, in vivo bile duct ligation (BDL) in mice upregulated PDH and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) expression and inhibited the PDHE1 phosphorylation in the livers. Using an ex vivo liver perfusion system, we found that a shortterm perfusion of BDL livers with deoxyglucose (DAGA) reduced the accumulation of cytosolic acetyl-CoA and attenuated the inhibition of PDHE1 phosphorylation. Furthermore, perfusion with BAM15, a metabolic probe known to increase acetyl-CoA utilization during ketogenesis, similarly decreased the inhibition of PDHE1 phosphorylation, cytosol

## Exam
You should compare patient notes with the inclusion criteria of clinical trials to determine the eligibility of a patient to a study. Patients are recruited by medical doctors on the team of clinical centers. You should follow each patient's progress to monitor the clinical trial's success while assessing each patient's eligibility to receive information about clinical trial opportunities.

## Objective/Goals
- Understand the clinical trial evaluation: patient's eligibility (i.e. study-level eligibility)
- Understand the clinical trial evaluation: trial's recruitment capability (i.e., trial-level eligibility)

## Knowledge

## Eligibility criteria
To determine a clinical trial's recruitment capability, you should know whether someone may be eligible to participate in a given clinical trial. Inclusion/exclusion criteria are included in clinical trials to determine who may be eligible to participate in a clinical trial. The eligibility criteria of a clinical trial state who may be eligible to participate in a clinical trial. The eligibility criteria of a clinical trial can differ between clinical centers using different clinical trials.

## Assessment method
When patient notes are compared with the research trial, the following three assessments may be considered:

## Study-level eligibility
When the patient meets the inclusion criteria and does not meet all exclusion criteria, the patient may be determined to be eligible for the given clinical trial. When the assessment score is 0, it means the patient is not eligible for the clinical trial.
When the assessment score is 2, the patient is highly likely to be eligible for the clinical trial.
To assess whether a patient is eligible, include the assessment score following each of the exclusion/inclusion criteria in the assessment of eligibility for a given clinical trial. If the assessment score is less than or equal to the threshold score, the patient is eligible for the clinical trial after exclusion of other exclusion criteria.

## Trial-level eligibility
After evaluation of eligibility in each given research trial, we should assess how this trial can enroll participants

<EOD> Elevated Serum Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels in Painful Diabetic Retinopathy
Introduction: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is an established biomarker for the detection of prostate cancer. Elevation in PSA level correlates with metastatic prostate cancer. However, serum PSA level is used as a prognostic biomarker in nonurologic conditions including cardiovascular system, kidney, liver, and respiratory diseases. Method: In this study, we investigated the serum PSA level in patients with painful diabetic retinopathy (DR) (nodal painful DR with and without retinal detachment) and compared with that of patients with nonpainful DR. Results: Our present findings showed increased serum PSA in patients with painful DR (60.09 ± 2.8 ng/mL) compared to the serum PSA levels of the patients with nonpainful DR (45.55 ± 3.7 ng/mL). There was a statistically significant difference in the serum PSA level between these two groups (p < 0.01). Similarly, we find increased serum PSA in the patients with nodal painful DR (1.06 ± 0.05 ng/mL) compared to the patients with nonpainful DR (0.66 ± 0.08 ng/mL) (p < 0.01). There was a statically significant difference in the serum PSA level between these two groups (p < 0.01). <EOD> Surgical treatment by a supralevator abdominoperineal resection for distal rectal malignant tumors with high extralevator involvements without preoperative neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy: an early case series study.
This retrospective study was performed to evaluate the surgical treatment for rectal malignant tumors with high extralevator involvements. From November 2015 to July 2018, three male and two female patients underwent supralevating abdominoperineal resections (slev-APRs) of rectal malignant tumors at our hospital. The mean diameter of tumors was 8.1cm; rectal ultrasound showed that 4 patients had positive circumferential resection margin and 3 had distal resection margin less than 1 cm. The mean distance between the lower border of tumor and levator ani was 6.6 cm upward from the dentate line. The mean duration of operation was 334 min; mean estimated blood loss was 700 ml; mean postanesthesia recovery score was 6.5 in the intensive care unit after operation. The mean time of hospitalization was 22 days after operation. None of the patients had wound infection, uronephrosis, or reoccurrence. Patients who suffered from malignant rectal tumors with high extralevator involvements seemed to benefit from slev-APR, particularly under 4 cm than 5-8 cm. <EOD> LncRNA XIST regulates cell invasion by acting as a miR-99a sponge in gastric cancer.
OBJECTIVE
The aim of this study was to clarify the role of the long non-coding RNA, X-inactive specific transcript (XIST) in gastric cancer by performing a loss-of-function experiment using in vitro cell culture and in vivo mouse models.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
Two sets of gastric cancer patients were recruited. LncRNA XIST expression in gastric cancer tissues and the paired adjacent normal tissues were detected by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR). Luciferase reporter assay was used to examine the relationship between XIST and miR-99a. Moreover, we performed transwell assay in SGC7901 to detect whether XIST could influence cell invasion.


RESULTS
XIST expression levels of gastric cancer tissues were higher than that of paired non-tumor tissue. XIST expression levels were higher in gastric cancer patients with lymph node metastases than those without lymph node metastases. Moreover, XIST expression levels were also high in gastric cancer patients with lymphovascular invasion. Finally, in gastric cancer patients, higher XIST expression levels had poor prognosis. Luciferase reporter assay confirmed that XIST may regulate miR-99a. In addition, we found that knockdown of XIST decreases SGC7901 cell invasion, an effect that could be reversed by knockdown of miR-99a.


CONCLUSIONS
LncRNA XIST was highly expressed in gastric cancer. Furthermore, high XIST expression is associated with lymph node metastases and lymphovascular invasion. Besides, in gastric cancer, XIST could promote SGC7901 cell line invasion by targeting miR-99a in vitro.<EOD> Comparison of the HAQ questionnaire to objective tests of physical function: an analysis strategy

<EOD> NMDA‐mediated presynaptic long‐term depression in the amygdaloid complex requires activation of mGluR5 and L‐type calcium channels
The amygdala contributes to fear learning and memory and to fear‐related psychopathology. Amygdala neurons are known to express both NMDA‐ and mGluR5‐mediated forms of long‐term depression (LTD), but the interaction between NMDA receptors (NMDARs) and mGluR5s is poorly understood. We report that NMDA‐mediated synaptic depression in the rat basolateral amygdala (BLA) exhibits a biphasic time‐course and can be blocked by mGluR5 antagonists and a L‐type calcium channel blocker. NMDA‐mediated short‐term depression involves endocytosis of AMPA receptors and requires PKC activity. In contrast, NMDAR‐dependent LTD requires activation of cAMP/protein kinase A signaling and involves endocytosis of presynaptic components, the dephosphorylation of GluR1/AMPA receptors, and a reduction in the size of release sites. These novel findings suggest a mechanistic relationship between NMDA‐mediated short‐term depression and long‐term depression that depends on activation of mGluR5s and L‐type calcium channels. These data suggest models of bidirectional regulation of basolateral amygdala plasticity that are related to synaptic scaling mechanisms, and may be relevant to the mechanism of fear conditioning.<EOD> A comparative study of the effects of nifedipine and 5-(N,N-diethylamino)nicotinamide-4'-sulfonamide on platelet aggregation and experimental thrombosis.

<EOD> Efficacy of In-Line Diffusers: A Study in the Domestic Sphere

This study measured the efficiency of 1 and 13 in-line diffusers inside two separate rooms to determine the amount of airborne particulates that could be dispersed into the room. Two in-line diffusers were placed side by side in the centre of the room along with an air quality monitor. Samples were collected at regular time intervals over a three-day period. The results found that over the course of a three-day period, a 13-inch in-line diffuser was able to remove 86% of the particulate matter within 4 m of the diffuser, whereas the 1-inch in-line diffuser removed 60% from a distance of 3 m. The results concluded that an in-line diffuser was able to remove particulates much further into a room than current recommendations suggest.

## 1. Identification of Criteria
First, the system analyzes the number of criteria in a given Inclusion criteria string. If the number is greater than one, identify criteria in each Inclusion Criterion.

*If the number of criteria in a given string is greater than one, the system firstly looks for the second Inclusion Criterion.*

```
(criteria 1) or (criteria 2) or (criteria 3) …
```
*criteria i* is a single word, not a sentence. *(criteria i)^2* is an Inclusion Criterion object, not an Inclusion Criteria string.
```
((criteria 1)^2 and (criteria 2)^2 and (criteria 3)^2)
or (criteria 1)^2 or (criteria 2)^2 or (criteria 3)^2

```
*If a term of criteria is not a single word, such as `Age ≥ 65yr`, please replace the term with its canonical form of `Age ≥ 65 yrs`.*

-   In the system, there is a single criteria named: `Age ≥ 65yr`. Therefore, according to the syntax, the system should identify criteria in this terms of criteria.
```
        criteria: Age ≥ 65yr
```
This term of criteria is not a single word, so the system must identify criteria one by one.
```
     Age ≥ 65yr
```
Once they are identified, the system finds the Inclusion Criteria object that consists of these criteria.
```
                        Inclusion criteria: 
                          Age ≥ 65yr
```
Since the number of criteria is one, the system should be used Inclusion Criteria object in its next step:
```
        age ≥ 65yr
      ```
The first word of the string, `age`, is identified as the target term. The system converts the term to its canonical form. In this case, a single word is converted to the single word, `age: ≥ 65yr`.
```
       (age: ≥ 65yr)
```
In the next step, the system looks for an operator of comparison, `='`, to identify criterion.

41.output: ## Outputs You should output the patient's eligibility assessment for each clinical trial. So the code should be the same for every patient. patient_trial: { eligibility:2 }, ![ ] ## Good Luck Evaluation of the efficacy of immunotherapy (Sci/Glob) in patients allergic to Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus Background. Allergic asthma represents a significant and increasing health problem that affects 1-20% of the population, with children being the most affected. Allergic asthma is caused by airway inflammation mediated by allergens and pollutants and is associated with respiratory symptoms that progress to irreversible airflow obstruction with disease severity. Currently, immunotherapy is the only treatment capable of modifying the disease course; however, this therapeutic intervention does not induce or maintain a long-term protection against the immune response to inhalant allergens in all patients, which is an important disadvantage. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy, safety and tolerability of a new vaccine (Sci/Glob) in a cohort of Mexican patients allergic to D. pteronyssinus. Methodology. The current study took place between July and November 2020, at the Allergy Clinic at the Mexican Institute of Social Security, Toluca, Mexico. A total of 23 patients were enrolled in the study, all of whom suffered from mild and persistent asthma due to D. pteronyssinus from previous allergy tests (SPT/prick) and had a serum specific IgE (sIgE) level >0.7 KU/L using commercial tests. All patients started the treatment with the standard protocol (1 dose/week). #### Input_data_preparation.py
    
```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import pickle
import warnings

warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

def load_text_file(filename):
    with open(filename, encoding='utf-8') as f:
        data = pd.read_csv(f, sep='\t', skip_header=1, use_cols=['patient-note','inclusion-criteria'])
        data['text'] = [p + '\n' + c for p, c in zip(data['patient-note'], data['inclusion-criteria']) if p.strip('\t')]
        data['text'].columns = ['text']
        data['text'].head()
        data.head()
        nb.load_nugget("pickle_temp/example_2.nugget", filename=filename)
        np.loadtxt('pickle_temp/example_2.Pickle', ignore_errors=True)
        warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

def save_as_excel(df, filename):
    df.to_csv(filename, header=None)
    df.to_excel(filename, index=False)
```

Abstract.  Background: Numerous studies have shown that matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are associated with vascular smooth muscle cell migration and neointimal thickening following vascular injury. Objective: The aim of the present study was to investigate whether reactive oxygen species (ROS)‐mediated activation of MMP‐8 and a specific MMP‐2 activator, MMP‐14, participate in vascular smooth muscle cell migration. Compared with cells without MMP‐14 transfection, gelatin zymography showed that MMP‐2 and MMP‐8 activities were significantly (P < 0.05) increased in MMP‐14‐transfected HUVECs. Next, we treated intact HUVECs with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the superoxide anion‐generating compound 2,2′‐azobis(2‐aminopropane) dihydrochloride, or the hydroxyl radical‐generating compound FeCl2/ascorbate for 2 hours. All these treatments induced MMP‐2 activation and significantly (P < 0.05) increased the MMP‐8 activity, suggesting that ROS‐mediated mechanisms are involved in the activation of MMP‐8. Additionally, ROS‐mediated MMP‐8 activation in intact HUVECs led to a significantly (P < 0.05) increased cell number migrating into the culture‐insert‐coated membranes. [ACS] Hello. You are a helpful assistant for clinical trial recruitment. Your task is to compare a given patient note and the inclusion criteria of a clinical trial to determine the patient's eligibility. The factors that allow someone to participate in a clinical study are called inclusion criteria. They are based on characteristics such as age, gender, the type and stage of a disease, previous treatment history, and other medical conditions.

The assessment of eligibility has a three-point scale: 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial; 1) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation; and 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial. 
You should make a patient-level eligibility by outputting the scale for the assessment of eligibility for each patient and then make the trial-level eligibility by outputting the mean score from the patient-level eligibility, e.g., `Assessment of eligibility(0): 0.671 : Assessment of eligibility(1): 0.667 : Assessment of eligibility(2): 0.667`. Q. How do you find a group to test your system?


A. To test your data, you could create data from previous patients or synthesize it from a variety of source in order to form an artificial population. There are a few methods that you can use to simulate such a population and generate the synthetic data required for a clinical trial:
   1.  Random sample: In many cases, for clinical trials which are designed to be large and generalizable in terms of target population, it might be sufficient to randomly sampling from the data from the database to create a trial sample population. 
   2.  Generate synthetic data from a pre-existing, representative data set
   3.  Generate synthetic data from a normal distribution
   4.  Generate synthetic data from machine learning or natural language processing model results

    
As you can see, there are many options to test your system. Generally, the first choice is random samples.

---

Q. How do we make the report?


A. To write the report, you could use the command [Report](index.md#mdp_report) to run the templates, or manually create a report yourself. The template is written in YAML, which is a light-weight, human-readable data description language.
There are two ways to generate a report.

You could use yml2report to convert data to a yaml report. A YAML report can then be given to an editor or rendered as webpage as desired.
Please review [Report generation using yml2report](index.md#mdr_reportgeneration-using-command-yml2report)

Alternatively, you could use template directly. You can use the command [Report Generation With Template (reportmd)](index.md#reportmd_reportgeneration-using-templates) to generate reports with data and templates.
 

---

A.

To train and evaluate the model, we can use any machine learning learning framework and tools with tensorflow, keras, sklearns, etc.

[S2] Section 2: Clinical Trial Criteria

Clinical trial criteria can be represented using standard data model schema (e.g., CDISC's Study Design module). We use the patient-wise clinical eligibility (2-class ordinal scale, e.g., inclusion criterion and non-inclusion criterion) to determine the patient's inclusion status in a clinical trial. There are 10 factors based on ECG, 3 factors based on vital signs, and 14 factors based on patient description in the patient note. [HONOURS]<EOD> Evolution of immune responses during the course of severe COVID-19 in Japan

a r t i c l e i n f o Keywords:SARS-CoV-2 COVID-19 Lymphocyte subsets Antibody response Humoral immunity Neutralizing antibodies A B S T R A C T COVID-19 has spread quickly around the world, becoming a pandemic, which has forced health systems in many countries to make enormous adjustments to care for patients. There is currently an emerging understanding of the effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection on human immune responses. It was reported that infection with SARS-CoV-2 resulted in rapid activation of proliferation of CD4 + and CD8 + T cells, expansion of both innate (including NK-cells) and adaptive immune cells (including memory B-cells and antibody-producing plasmablasts), and induction of specific antibody titers. In this study, a longitudinal immunological study was conducted in 58 patients to evaluate the immunological responses during the early-stage and the late-stage of severe COVID-19. The number of lymphocyte subsets significantly decreased between hospital admission (17.6-25.2 × 10 3 cell/μL) and 28 days later in the early stages of COVID-19 patients (16.1-17.0 × 10 3 cell/μL). Thereafter, the lymphocyte number recovered to around 14.5-16.1 × 10 3 cell/μL in the late stages of the COVID-19 patients. SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG responses and neutralizing antibody were detected in most patients, and SARS-CoV-2-specific IgM responses were low in comparison. Based on our results, it is important to prepare for the surge of COVID-19 cases in the future.

## General procedure for the preparation of ptmdfbs via dehydrofluorination of hdfs
In a dry Schlenk tube with a septum were firstly loaded with the Pt(PPh 3 )HCl catalyst (30 mg, 0.05 mmol, 5 mol%), DFBS/SylHDFB (260 mg, 1.00 mmol, 1.00 equiv), ethanol (2.55 mL), 1,2-dichloroethane (200 μL, 2.00 mmol, 2.00 equiv), tetrabutylammonium iodide (0.25 g, 0.94 mmol, 0.94 equiv) and then the septum was closed with the needle. The tube was then vacuumed to remove all the solvents, and the pressure was maintained below 1 Pa. The whole tube was backfilled three times with O 2 (2.00 bar) at room temperature. The o-dichlorobenzene (120 μL, 1.01 mmol, 1.00 equiv) was then loaded into the tube and the reaction mixture was heated to 90 o C under stirring for 24 h to afford the desired hydrodefluorination compounds.
After the reaction was complete, the whole tube was put into nitrogen atmosphere of glove box and then the catalyst could be recovered by filtration. The reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (30 mL × 3), the combined organic layers and washed with water (30 mL × 5), brine (30 mL), water and brine several times until neutral. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and then concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude target product. A series of 40 consecutive patients with locally advanced inoperable gastric carcinoma was evaluated, using a combination chemotherapy protocol consisting in high-dose 5-fluorouracil and folinic acid during 3 to 4 consecutive weeks, with leucovorin, cisplatin and doxorubicin during 2 to 4 weeks. Chemotherapy was administered every three weeks. Thirty patients received the whole treatment, 10 received only the combination of 5-FU and folinic (10/10) or 5-FU (5/5). Forty-two percent objective responses were obtained. The response rate was 47% for gastric tumours and 63% for distant metastatic disease. The most common toxicities were vomiting, alopecia and leukopenia. The authors conclude that the combination of 5-FU with folinic acid is very effective in the treatment of locally advanced inoperative gastric carcinoma and has also significant activity against distant metastatic disease. This protocol is also well tolerated and can be used safely in an outpatients clinic setting, although 32% of the patients required supportive measures to prevent leukopenia. © 2016<EOD> Inter- and intra-rater agreement levels for the diagnosis of pulpal and periapical periodontitis of primary molars.
This study aims to present inter- and intra-rater levels for the diagnosis of pulpal and periapical periodontitis of primary molars. Twenty-four radiographs of primary molars, obtained from digital storage phosphor plates, were digitalized. Three dentists with different academic and clinical backgrounds were selected to determine the level of agreement between themselves. To evaluate the level of agreement between the observers and expert radiologist, 145 radiographs were assessed by the dentists. After the assessments were completed, a sample of 37 randomly selected digital images were reviewed by each dentist and periapical radiologist. The inter- and intra-rater levels were calculated by means of Kappa statistics. The data were tabulated in order to evaluate the frequency values. The agreement levels for pulpal and apical pathologies between the dentists were evaluated as follows: excellent between dentists 1 and 2; very good between dentists 1 or 2 and expert radiologist; and good for dentists 3 and 4. When all of the assessments were analyzed together, the inter-rater agreement levels were moderate to good, in descending order, for dentists 3 and 4. The intra-rater agreement levels were very good to excellent for all of the observers. In conclusion, the intra-rater diagnoses were better than the inter-rater diagnoses and when the experts were compared to the dentists, a higher inter-rater agreement level was observed for the pulpal diagnosis. Further studies with better methodological design are encouraged.<EOD> Fracture-Free and Mechanically Strengthened Graphene-Coated Ceramic Composites

## The cause of a diarrhoea.
Let us now consider what the causes of diarrhoea are.' Let us begin with food which has not been digested, and which cannot pass safely. Then we have meat, especially pork, and especially the flesh of sick animals; and we have the foods that cause gout, and the foods of the lower animals which are not human food; and we have food which has not been well prepared or stored; while perhaps the greatest source of indigestible matter is the drink which is the favourite beverage, and in which people are so careless of hygiene and cleanliness. These I hold to be the real causes of what they term " bilious diarrhoea," and I believe, if it were possible, that the greatest number of cases of diarrhoea would be cut short were the drink and the food taken only under strict hygienic conditions.
But there are other things besides drink and food which may be the occasional cause of diarrhoea.
We find sometimes what has been called "water-brash," which consists of half-digested food washing round the stomach, and then running down the intestine, which can be easily diagnosed by looking at the stools. Then we find many patients who have some sort of acute disease will have diarrhoea with their acute malady, and this usually ceases as soon as the acute symptoms cease. Then we have the "intestinal fevers," such as typhoid, cholera, and so on, with the constant stool; but as this is beyond discussion I will not say anything of it further.
Then we have the bacteria in the intestines, and we have the parasitic diseases, the worms and the round worms and the thread worms, which are not yet known to produce diarrhoea, but which may do and which give rise to it in conjunction with the other causes

<EOD> Role of Interleukin-8 in the Genesis of Human Neoplasms
Interleukin‐8 (IL‐8) is a cytokine produced by inflammatory cells and non‐hematopoietic cells such as epithelial, endothelial, and fibroblastic cells. This cytokine exerts its principal activity during the early stages of leukocyte recruitment, being involved in angiogenesis and cell proliferation and migration or in inflammatory cell activation and differentiation. In these processes IL‐8 regulates the expression of other cytokines (such as GM‐CSF and TGF‐β), chemotaxis, infiltration of the tumor masses by leukocytes, and tumor growth. Concentrations of IL‐8 in ascitic fluid, in pleural effusions, and in plasma are elevated in patients with ovarian carcinomas and hepatocellular carcinoma, and high concentrations of this cytokine also occur in the peritoneal fluid and in plasma of endometrium affected patients. In human tumors, the neoplastic cells may themselves secrete IL‐8. The aim of this review is to clarify the role of IL‐8 in normal and neoplastic tissues and the role of this molecule as a marker of disease activity in several human neoplasms (ovarian, endometrial, hepatocellular, and breast). METHODS

RESULTS

CONCLUSIONS

<EOD> Evaluation of the Improved Structure in Images Based on the Generalized Gaussian Distribution Moments for Remote Sensing Imagery

A new moment sequence of generalised Gauss distribution is proposed for evaluating the quality of remote sensing images. The moment sequence is derived from the proposed distribution, a generalisation of the Gauss distribution, based on the proposed multivariate density function and the moment generating function. This sequence contains the mean and four moments of the remote sensing image in the same form as other classical moment models, which facilitates image degradation analysis. It is shown that the proposed sequence is capable of obtaining higher estimation accuracy than previously derived moment estimators, which could be used to obtain better estimation of the image degradation in terms of the geometric accuracy and texture details. The simulation and image interpretation tests are conducted to illustrate the superior performance of the proposed algorithm. Sensors 2016, 16, 34 2 of 16image degradation, particularly in terms of the geometric properties. However, the classical moment models fail to directly assess the geometric and optical characteristics of remote sensing images.To address the above problem, a set of improved moments were proposed by Huang[23], Jiang [24], and Wu [25,26]to estimate the degree of geometric distortion in aerial orthophoto images. These moments are derived from the proposed multivariate distribution, with a closed-form calculation of parameters achieved by fitting an image data set. The theoretical model is very easy to implement, and can be applied to all types of remote sensing image; however, this type of model only reflects the overall trend of geometric distortion in remote sensing images, and is not easy to quantitatively describe image texture. Some new moments were proposed by Zhu[27]in order to estimate both geometric and textural characteristics in an image. To obtain an effective set of moments for image degradation assessment, Zhu utilized the theory of the moment of image degradation proposed by Jalali [28], which described the spatial structure and texture of the image. Zhu compared the modified moment sequence with the classical moment sequence in order to better estimate the degree of geometric degradation in images and further evaluate the image quality. Compared with the classical moments, the modified sequence of moments could better describe the geometric and text

<EOD> The Preoperative Platelet-to-Lymphocyte Ratio in Patients Undergoing Surgery for Upper Tract Urothelial Carcinoma

Aims: Some studies indicated that inflammation related to cancer had been identified as an independent prognostic factor to predict cancer-related death and survival in patients with urothelial carcinoma (UC). However, the relationships between the plateletto-lymphocyte ratio (PLR) and survival of patients undergoing surgery for upper tract UC (UTUC) remains unknown. This study investigated the prognostic significance of PLR in these patients. Patients and methods: We included 123 consecutive patients with UTUC who underwent surgery after diagnosis at Fremantle Hospital and Health Service between October 2002 and November 2015. Clinicopathological characteristics of patients were reviewed. The association of preoperative PLR with other clinicopathological characteristics and survival outcomes was assessed. Kaplan-Meier curves were used to estimate 5-year cancer specific survival (CSS) and overall survival (OS), which were compared by using the log-rank test. Cox proportional hazards regression models were used to identify factors affecting the CSS and OS. Results: The cohort of 14 men and 103 women had a median age of 70 (interquartile range [IQR], 66-74). The median preoperative PLR in all patients was 186.4 (IQR, 135.7-256.2). Preoperative PLR was not associated with the disease and clinicopathological characteristics of UTUC patients except in patients with grade 3 renal function (p = 0.04). Multivariate analyses indicated preoperative PLR was an independent factor in the prediction of both CSS (p = 0.03) and OS (p = 0.04). Conclusion: The results from our study indicated an association between the higher preoperative PLR with worse outcomes in patients with UTUC. PLR was suggested to be a better predictor to evaluate the postoperative survival.

<EOD> Influence-diagram analysis of a phase I study in patients with chronic hepatitis C.
A prospective Phase I study was conducted in patients with hepatitis C virus chronic active hepatitis. All patients had elevated hepatic transaminase levels and had a histological score greater than 9 points on scale from 0 to 18. They were treated with a combination of alpha interferon and recombinant leukocyte alpha interferon. The trial aim was to evaluate safety and tolerability, and also to evaluate the dose escalation schedule. Efficacy end points were complete and partial relapse-free response, and progression of disease. The drug combination did not increase the toxicity observed with alpha interferon alone, and no deaths resulted from treatment. Twenty-nine patients were enrolled. The drug administration schedule consisted of four consecutive treatment cycles of 10 days each every 8 weeks. The alpha interferon dose was 6 MU initially, and the leukocyte alpha interferon dose was 1 MU. Dose escalation was at week 4, to 12 MU for alpha interferon and 2 MU for leukocyte alpha interferon. The mean maximal hepatic transaminase levels after treatment were normalized in half of the treated patients. Two patients achieved sustained full remission. Ten patients (34%) showed a sustained amelioration of liver disease and normalization of hepatic transaminase levels for a period of at least 3 months or longer after the last treatment. All patients had a favourable tolerance to treatment as assessed by both clinical and laboratory evaluation. The Phase I study design was adapted to the specific properties of antihepatitis C virus drugs with the aim of identifying the minimum dosage and schedule in phase II studies with an objective of minimizing toxicity while maintaining efficacy end points of the study. Pediatric patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) or sickle cell trait (SCT) have a unique disease prognosis that consists of a multitude of complications ranging from delayed bone age, avascular necrosis (AVN) and strokes in adolescent patients. As the SCD population is one of the most commonly prescribed acetaminophen (APAP) in children, it is imperative for providers to closely follow these patients to ensure they are not experiencing liver disorders that result in a severe hepatitis from APAP. Two pediatric patients, ages 1.4 and 10.4, were seen in consultations for an emergent workup of liver disorders after APAP was discovered in their urine and blood. While both patients did not have documented liver disease or history of liver damage, APAP poisoning was not ruled out. The first patient's blood test was not indicative of APAP poisoning and was discharged, while the second patient underwent a 72-hour urine collection for APAP. Both patients were instructed to stop using the Tylenol (APAP) for 24 hours, and the result of their 72 urine collection ruled out APAP poisoning. <EOD> A Comparison of Cervical Spine Magnetic Resonance Imaging Findings in Normal Pregnancy and Preterm Birth

Objective:To determine the effect of pregnancy on the course and anatomy of the cervical spine and to compare the changes between those with preterm birth and normal pregnancies. Methods: This was a retrospective study comparing findings in 40 consecutive non-pregnant women to those in 40 pregnant women and those in 35 early preterm labor patients. Magnetic resonance images were reviewed and T1-weighted images (T1WI), T2-weighted images (T2WI), fat-suppressed T2WI (FST2WI), and gadoliniumenhanced fat-suppressed T1WI (EFIGS) were analyzed and compared. Measurements on the T1WI were used to obtain canal diameter and canal length, and measurements on the PETRA image were used to measure fatty infiltration. We evaluated the distance between the posterior ligaments, lateral vertebral body, and posterior ligament to the cervical canal, which was termed the posterior height and posterior ligament, which was termed the Torg ratio. The PETRA images were used to evaluate disk height. Results: Canal diameter, canal length, and the difference in the diameter of the cervical canal were significantly greater in the pregnant group. PETRA measurements showed significantly greater canal diameter, posterior height, intracanal fat space, lateral vertebral body height, disk height, and disk height at the L4/5 and L5/S1 levels in the pregnant group. Conclusion: Magnetic resonance imaging studies of the cervical spine during pregnancy demonstrate that canal diameter, canal length, and fatty infiltration of intervertebral disks increase.

<EOD> Beta subunit of guanine nucleotide binding protein regulates cell cycle progression and differentiation in mouse bone marrow erythroid progenitors.
The c-gbp is a mRNA expressed in bone marrow (BM) CD34+ hematopoietic progenitors and in CD34-/CD38- and CD34+/CD38+ cells of BM. At steady state (day 0), its message is already expressed at high levels in both CD34+/CD38+ progenitors and in the CD34-/CD38- cells. In day 0 and in cultures of normal CD34+/CD38+ and CD34-/CD34+ cells, c-gbp gene is not expressed; neither c-gbp transcript nor p21(GAP) transcript, a known RNA partner of c-gbp. During culture, c-gbp transcript is expressed in the more immature CD38+ cells (on day 3), but not as yet in more differentiated, CD38-, cells (on day 6 and onward). At the protein level, Gbeta(184), the major beta subunit of Gi/oc-gbp, is detected in both CD34+/CD38+ and CD34-/CD38+ cells at the time of culture, and both its levels and its proportion vary during cultures. A parallel variation for the Galpha(i/o) level, the major alpha subunit of Gi/oc-gbp, is also followed. Beta-GTP, the active form of the GTP-bound protein, appears also in some cells of day 0. The present results imply that a specific maturation program exists in the erythroid cell lineage, which is characterized by the specific expression of beta-Gi/oc-gbp in G1 phase of the cell cycle.<EOD> Effects of Expertise in a Complex Task on Visual Search and Visual–Motor Transformations

<EOD> A case of postrenal acute kidney injury after percutaneous kidney stone surgery requiring emergent nephrectomy

Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) for kidney stone is widely used procedure, and its clinical outcome is excellent. However, complication is not rare, including bleeding, infection, and acute kidney injury. Here the authors experienced a case of postrenal acute kidney injury after PCNL requiring emergent nephrectomy, and he was discharged three days after surgery without any complication.

# Introduction
Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL), first performed by Fernstrom et al. [bib_ref]  Percutaneous pyelolithotomy: a new extraction technique, Fernström [/bib_ref]  in 1976, is one of the widely used procedures for kidney stones with a stone burden over 20mm. It is associated with complications such as bleeding, infection, nephrectomy, and ureteral injury. But, because the stone-free rate of PCNL is excellent, it is considered as a more safe and effective procedure.
Postrenal acute kidney injury (AKI) could be occurred after PCNL, but it is relatively rare. Here, we report a case of postrenal AKI that was recovered with medical treatment including hemodialysis.

## Case
A 79-year-old male visited our clinic complaining of flank pain and gross hematuria for 2 days. In general health screening 7 months ago, he was diagnosed as a patient of kidney stone with staghorn calculi in the right upper calyx. He had chronic kidney disease with eGFR 20.73ml/min/1.73m 2 . He was taking one antihypertensive medicine. Abdominal CT showed a staghorn stone in the right renal pelvis and upper calyceal group .
There was no hemorrhagic aspect in the gross urine. To reduce the stone burden, we performed standard PCNL by 26 Fr nephrostomy tube and double J ureteral stent insertion .
There was no gross hemorrhage. We performed 2-session PCNL

# Subproblem

An important issue in trial-level eligibility is the prediction of unqualified patients in clinical trials. We are going to consider this issue as a sub-problem (called Subproblem_S) of the above problem (called Problem_S). Specifically, instead of solving Problem_S (Trial-level eligibility of a given patient for a given clinical trial), we are going to solve Subproblem_S (Trial-level eligibility on a given patient). 

# Explanation of subproblem
In the subproblem (Subproblem_S), we are assuming that we already know a patient's information, e.g, `Clinical trial name of A`, `A clinical trial of A`,`A clinical trial of A, ` etc. Because our data were collected from real patient data, we used the clinical trial name in the real world to evaluate the subproblem. The following figure is also from our data for convenience.
A clinical trial is a series of experiments or trials performed to collect information to support or refute a hypothesis. It is also a set of processes that result in the generation of data or other information that will contribute to new medical knowledge. Clinical trials are essential for clinician/ scientist to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new drug. In addition, clinical trials are important to develop new diagnostic or therapeutic procedures.
A study for a new drug involves recruiting patients with certain known characteristics (known as eligibility criteria) according to the drug's intended use . Patients with disease, condition, or characteristics that make them more suitable than others can help test new drugs, while patients with specific diseases or conditions of interest to the study are excluded. After that, these eligible patients (or trial subjects) are randomly allocated to certain treatment groups in different ways. Some other factors such as intervention may be considered as clinical trials to determine drug efficacy. The information given in the figure is a subset of the information shown in the paper cited below.

OBJECTIVE
To analyze the clinical characteristics, the diagnosis and differential diagnosis, the treatment and the prognosis of pulmonary lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma (LELC).


METHODS
A case of a bronchoscopic diagnosed pulmonary LELC was analyzed from the perspective of epidemiology, symptomatology, bronchoscopy examination, pathological diagnosis and immunohistochemistry.


RESULTS
LELC is commonly occurring in male, and the average age of onset was 56 years old. Some patients had a history of smoking. The clinical symptoms were non-specific and lack of typical manifestation. The physical examination and laboratory examination were normal. B-ultrasonography and chest X-ray were not so useful in the diagnosis of this disease. Bronchoscopy observation did not appear any specific pathological characteristics. Pathological diagnosis was required after obtaining biopsies for histology examination and immunohistochemistry. The diagnosis of LELC should be according to at least the following the conditions: (1) the tumor cells showed a nest-like architectural arrangement; (2) the tumor cells were closely arranged and showed lymphocytic infiltration. And immunohistochemistry had to showed cytoplasmic CD56 expression, and negative of CD20 and CD3 in the tumor cells. (3) no in situ lesions and other primary tumor were found. There were some differences in clinical manifestation and pathological features, even with same immunophenotype, between epithelial cell LELC and nasopharyngeal LELC.


CONCLUSIONS
There was no effective treatment for LELC based on the experience from current cases. LELC is sensitive to chemotherapy and the prognosis for LELC was poor and with high metastasis.<EOD> Bacteriocin from Leuconostoc mesenteroides JDM2 Inhibits Growth of Salmonella typhimurium and Citrobacter freundii ATCC 8090

Again, however, there was no effect on tissue or urinary activator with the purified plasminogen activator inhibitor proteins studied. The results of Dr Chao and Dr Cocchiso are certainly interesting. The methods used were novel and could well have been effective in demonstrating differences in the ability of these two activators to bind to activator antibodies, had we been able to supply them with the purified antibodies in sufficient amounts. ## Instructions
You are asked to write the algorithm and the test for the algorithm to perform the three-point scale classification of patient eligibility for the clinical trial described above. Your algorithm should take the notes that indicate the patient's age, gender, weight, clinical and medical history and other features as input to compare to the clinical trial's inclusion criteria, and output an eligibility scale and a reason of the eligibility decision. The algorithm should return the result of the assessment of trial-level eligibility.

- You can use any of the existing data structures for the parameters. However, the format should be the same with the input data. - You should use English words as variable names. - Do not use words starting with numbers (e.g., #variable_for_testing, #age_average_of_patient, #weight_test, #sex_check, #etc... are not words and will not be approved. Change them properly to match the specification.)

## Input Example
In the trial-level, 0 (would not refer)
In the patient-level, 0 (would not refer)
In the patient-level, 1 (would consider referring)
In the patient-level, 2 (highly likely to refer)

## Output Example

## Examples
In the following examples, `Trial` is the trial name, `Patient` is the patient ID, `Note` is the patient note name, `scale` stands for the eligibility scale, `test` is the logic decision of the algorithm, and `reason` is the given in text.
```
Trial-level eligibility: 0
test(Trial, Patient, Note):
    scale ← 0; Reason ← "Would not refer"
    if (Patient == 1478)
        if (Note == "Right groin bruit")
            scale ← 1
            Reason ← "Would consider referring upon further investigation"
        else
            scale ← 2
            Reason ← "Highly likely to refer"
    else
        scale ← 1
        Reason ← "Would not refer"
Reason ← "The eligibility decision of some clinical study is not clear."

<EOD> Genetic and physiological characterization of Arabidopsis seedlings that are tolerant or hypersensitive toward the brassinosteroid plant steroid hormone

Phytohormones are plant-specific small chemical compounds that regulate many plant responses to their environment. They are involved in processes ranging from the initiation of development to response to stress and inhibition of pathogens. Thus, phytohormones represent important targets for agriculture in the context of crop yield and nutritive value and also to tackle threats to human health, such as the increasing amount of toxic agents via the food chain. Here, we describe genetic and physiological analyses of a new brassinosteroid-insensitive mutant, tbr. The tbr plant displays increased tolerance toward brassinosteroids, a steroid group of hormones essential for many processes in plant development and growth. Analysis of brassinosteroid metabolism in tbr plants revealed normal levels of brassinosteroid biosynthesis, transport, and accumulation. Instead, tbr plants are characterized by a hyper-sensitive phenotype toward elevated levels of brassinosteroids (at doses inducing wild-type plant growth promotion), manifested most prominently in plant stem growth, root branching, and trichome formation (i.e. the density of glandular structures). These phenotypes are independent of the developmental stage of each tested tissue, thus reflecting a rather general increase in brassinosteroid response. The tbr seedlings are also hypersensitive toward ethylene-inhib

Rhizoctonia solani is a soil-borne saprophyte that is commonly found in the soil and also an economically important plant pathogen that causes significant loss to agriculturally important crops such as rice, sunflower, sugarcane and wheat. Bacteria with pathogen suppressive activities towards R. solani have been reported; however, only a few such studies have been conducted in the Indian context. Here, we reviewed the current knowledge regarding identification of rhizoctonia antagonistic bacteria, strain development, in vitro and in vivo pathogen inhibitory tests and various applications of bacterial antagonists in plant production systems. The review shows that phytopathogenic R. solani has a wide range of hosts; however, only a few reports are available regarding the in vitro antagonistic ability of soil bacteria against this common soil-borne fungus. Bacterial strains from a wide range of genera, including Pseudomonas, Bacillus and Serratiobacter, are capable of inhibiting Rhizoctonia spp. in vitro and when used in growing media in association with seeds or plant parts. A limited number of field studies from different parts of the globe also indicate that the application of antagonists alone or in combination with chemical fertilizers leads to increased yields of host crops. <EOD> The pharmacy distribution channel in Canada--is there a need to change?
The pharmacy distribution channel in Canada comprises three separate and unique distribution chains—community, hospital/institutional, and mass merchandiser—with different organizations, structures, economics, and regulations. All three of these channels experience different degrees of competition from each other. The Canadian pharmacy distribution channels have been developed as they are today in part as a consequence of legislated and natural monopolies, localized regulation and licensing of entities, and historical practices. The structure of these distribution chains results in a variety of market failures. Consequently, the pharmacy distribution channel in Canada can evolve substantially to the betterment of the health of Canadians. Improvements are possible, and must be made, since drug product (medicines) and the drug distribution process are fundamental determinants of therapeutic and economic outcomes for all patients. We conclude that the Canadian pharmacy distribution channels must evolve and propose that the evolution of this channel should be based on the principles of efficiency, economic considerations, and equity, with a focus on maximizing overall societal value. This will require substantial changes in the structure of the three distribution channels and the reengineering of the pharmaceutical industry's business model. Some of these changes are possible now, and several are possible in the foreseeable future, through legislative intervention and the removal of impediments to market forces. The future distribution structure will also depend on changes in the way drugs are priced and paid for, including changes in the regulation of pharmacy-reimbursable generic products. We employ the `ensemblesDTree` method of the `ensembles` package, that trains a decision tree classifier at each tree node on randomized samples, with the remainder of the data held out as the test set. It trains 30 decision tree classifiers based on the random 60% of the data and the majority vote of the final predictions is used as the class prediction. In case of disagreement, the majority vote is called the winner.

2.6 Mini-challenge: [F14] Pairwise comparisons
Here is the problem:
You are given some data sets on the three genetic disorders: Huntington disease; hemophilia; and Down syndrome. 
You will be asked a set of questions to see if you can:
Detect the three types of disorder.
Compare the three types of disorder.
Use the results for your problem-solving in this challenge. 

* Down's syndrome is a genetic condition caused by an extra copy of the chromosome 21. This condition is often diagnosed during pregnancy. Infants with Down's syndrome have a distinctive pattern of physical traits. These traits often include unusually small fingers, a bulbous appearance to the stomach region, a flattened face, and a short neck. The severity of the signs and symptoms related to Down's syndrome varies from child to child. People with mild to moderate Down's syndrome often have some of the physical challenges, but to a lesser degree than those who have severe Down's syndrome. Children with Down's syndrome develop a series of physical, motor, cognitive, and behavioral challenges that may be life-threatening.  **2018**
* Huntington disease, also known as Huntington's chorea, is a rare hereditary autosomal-dominant neuropsychiatric disorder caused by a cytosine-adenineadenine (CAG) repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4. Huntington disease commonly manifests in adults, often during their prime. The disorder is characterized by motor dysfunction - particularly chorea - psychological symptoms, and cognitive decline. This disease is incurable. Huntington's gene can also lead to a more severe juvenile form with much earlier onset of symptomatology, the prognosis of which is also grimmer.  [more on Wikipedia...]
* Hemophilia A and B are X-linked recessive hereditary bleeding disorders characterized by a deficiency of coagulation factor VIII (FVIII) and factor IX (FIX), respectively.

I don't have more positive feedback to give you except what I have stated in the first review. This is a nice program that makes some good advances in automated clinical note processing, however, still leaves some shortcomings that need to be addressed:

# How does eligibility work?
The `Eligibility` component allows you to perform comparative analysis and identify the commonalities and differences in the study cohorts with respect to various criteria. The Eligibility analysis can be done with respect to the following criteria:

`criteria`: Components of the study cohort

The `Comparison` specifies the criteria with respect to which two comparison values are compared. The values of `Comparison` can be:

`compare`: `All`: Allows evaluating the overlap of the criteria between two cohorts, one at a time, for all the criteria.

`comparison=comparison:name`: Allows evaluating the exact overlap of the criteria in a pair-wise manner for the particular criteria name.

## Explanation
To train this task, we want you to build two models. One for the task of patient-level eligibility assessment. The target for the model is 31 labels which were used in the dataset. The second model is for the trial-level eligibility assessment, where the target number of labels depends on the trials, but it's approximately 60 labels.
- **Patient-level task**
- The task is to assess patient-level eligibility. The model will be trained to give a probabilistic estimate of eligibility for the patient. It depends on various aspects, for example: how the patient's condition changes over time, so it is better to train a system which takes past information into consideration. The system may also take into account comorbidities, which could be important for explaining why the patient is not eligible/eligible to participate in a clinical study. A natural approach to training involves learning this from a large dataset of patient records, where patient-level eligibility status has ground truth labels.

- **Trial-level task**
- The second task is to predict trial-level eligibility, which is different from patient-level eligibility. This information is used when patients participate in a clinical study, for example in trials with no or few patients, or when some patients from the same trial are excluded by other factors (smoking, allergic to drugs, etc. ...). The model will give an estimate on the likelihood of a patient referring to clinical trial, without a time-constraint. For this task, we can also obtain a trial's eligibility assessments.

### Pipeline:
We recommend to design a pipeline to train the models. Pipeline is defined as a set of models, data-pre/processing methods, and hyperparameters, that we train for better results. This pipeline can help us to avoid the time consuming task of searching for new data-pre/processing methods for extracting the information that our neural network needs to make a better prediction.
Pipeline:

- read in notes from Pubmed - remove columns not important and store data to the dataframe
- use a preprocessing method - for example remove stopwords
- use some feature extraction method, for example TF-IDF

BACKGROUND
The treatment of an acute respiratory infection (ARI) is usually based on a drug-based antibiotic-antiviral scheme. However, it is difficult to differentiate between bacterial and viral origin.


AIMS
To evaluate the efficacy of a clinical-based therapy in children attending the emergency department for acute respiratory infection.


SETTINGS
Tertiary level pediatric emergency department of a public hospital.


METHODS
Prospective cohort study to evaluate the differences between those patients requiring antiviral and antibiotic treatment and those who only received clinical follow-up.


RESULTS
One hundred and twelve patients were evaluated. The most common respiratory pathogens were rhinovirus (45%) and respiratory syncytial virus (34%). No major differences were found between antibiotic and clinical follow-up groups. The average age was 5 years in the antibiotic group and 4,6 years in the clinical follow-up group. Those older than 4 years had a higher chance of requiring antibiotic treatment. The length of stay was longer in antibiotic-treated patients (4,4 versus 2,8 days, p=0,01). Patients admitted to the hospital had a significantly worse outcome (p<0,001). Two patients required oxygen therapy.


CONCLUSIONS
Clinical follow-up appears as an acceptable cost-effective choice for pediatric patients with acute respiratory infection not requiring hospital admission.<EOD> .

# 4.15.2 Using Case-Level Features
So far, we have considered the patients as the entire subject of the machine learning. But as discussed in Section 2.1.5, the case is a different unit: the entire observation period of a patient.

The case-level features contain temporal information, e.g., patient's visit time, visiting department, prescribed drugs and tests. By using the features of a case, we can construct the model to deal with the temporal aspects properly.

Here are some examples of the case-level features:

![example of case-level features](examples/case_feature_example.png "Example features of a case: case_feature_example")

One of the case-level feature is the visiting department. It indicates which department the patient visits during the entire observation period. A previous work in [Adaptive Clinical Trial Eligibility Prediction Inference on Diverse Patient Populations using Case-Level Features (ICAI)]([https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26113633](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26113633)) explored how this feature contributes to the evaluation of eligibility since some trials are more likely to enroll in the Department of Internal Medicine. 

In addition, the [Triplet Learning](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/1664457/) is proposed in order to explore the temporal information of the patients' visits in which the triplet loss function is incorporated. It has been shown that the triplet loss function significantly improves the performance.

In this work, the input patient note consists of the three layers: patient features (patient), case-level features (case), and temporal features (visit_time), as shown in  
![example of the input patient note, which is triplet structure where each patient note (case, patient, and visit_time) is duplicated six times (triplet structure)](examples/triple_inputs.png "Example of the input patient note, which is triplet structure")

Radiographs revealed radiolucencies within the liver graft with no perfusion in segments II to III, thus indicating complete thrombosis. The patient underwent transjugular liver biopsy, which revealed extensive macrovesicular steatosis without evidence of thrombus. <EOD> Genetic Characterization of 575 Influenza Samples by a Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) Technology Platform



# Introduction
Influenza activity in the community occurs for about 3-15 weeks annually in many countries .
Influenza surveillance in a population is conducted by collecting clinical samples and testing by virus culture, conventional polymerase chain reaction (cPCR) and serological techniques. To complement these methods and understand the impact of genetic drift and shifts on seasonal influenza, whole genome sequencing (WGS) has been employed in a sub-set of the global seasonal influenza circulation in several countries [bib_ref]  GISAID: global initiative on sharing all influenza data-from vision to reality, Shu [/bib_ref]  , but has not yet achieved the throughput or rapidity that would be required to fully sequence all influenza genes in all annual influenza seasons. The availability of highthroughput next-generation sequencing (HTS) technology platforms provides a possibility to overcome this challenge with their capacity to rapidly generate billions of sequence reads per run, thus enabling a rapid and affordable characterization of the genetic diversity of circulating influenza viruses and monitoring for antigenic drift (the accumulation of point mutations over time which can make a virus more/ less amenable to neutralization by antibodies, allowing it to infect immune individuals) and shifts (an abrupt increase in frequency of a subtype through antigenic shift, as a result of reassortment), as well as identification of mutations of public health importance in a low-cost and high-throughput manner [bib_ref]  Next generation sequencing and bioinformatic bottlenecks: the current state of metagenomic data..., Scholz [/bib_ref] .
Gene sequencing by means of HTS is relatively new both at a technical and conceptual level. The current generation of HTS platforms can generate billions of short sequence reads with over 500 nucleotide (nt) read lengths, and the number of reads generated per run is rapidly increasing. HTS platforms provide several advantages over traditional sequencing methods, including the ability to generate millions of sequence reads quickly and simultaneously, and to characterize sequences derived from multiple organisms. The technology is a powerful tool to facilitate studies

<EOD> Long-term follow-up of laparoscopic surgery for large adrenal tumors.
BACKGROUND
Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is becoming a standard method for small adenomas; however, its safety in patients with large adrenal tumors (> or = 6 cm) is controversial. We reviewed the outcome of laparoscopic adrenalectomy for adrenal tumors and assessed the safety of the procedure in patients with large adrenal tumors.


RESULTS
A total of 30 adrenalectomies (LA) for large adrenal tumors (LA groups; n = 20) were compared with 101 (LA groups; n = 71) for small adrenal tumors. Mean tumor size in the LA group and small adrenal tumor group was 91.5 +/- 45.9 mm, and 40.8 +/- 14.6 mm, respectively. The mean operative time was significantly longer for the LA group (205 +/- 87.4 min) than the small adrenal tumor group (-44.3 +/- 32.8; P = 0.0001). Conversion to open surgery for the large adrenal tumor group was higher than that for the small adrenal tumor group (0.2 +/- 0.6 vs. 0.05 +/- 0.2, P = 0.007). The mean follow-up period was 76.5 +/- 44.4 months for the LA groups and 71.8 +/- 42.43 for the small adrenal tumor groups, respectively. The overall complication rate in both groups was similar (LA groups: 14.9%, small adrenal tumor groups: 14.27%). However, the conversion rate of the large adrenal tumor group (15.0%) was significantly higher than that of the small adrenal tumor group (8.9%; P = 0.0003).

<EOD> Tendon biology

# Overview
Tendons hold the bones in our limbs together, and help us to move our limbs easily. The tissues comprising tendons are called tensional connective tissues, and the cellular component in these are called tenocytes.

# Tendon development
As the body grows, the long bones form at their ends, and in order to allow the muscles to attach to them, the tendons must develop. The formation of the tendons consists of three steps, all of which are called tendon differentiation.

## Proliferation
The tenocytes proliferate during the proliferative phase.

## Differentiation
The tenocytes differentiate into types that can be distinguished by their shape as follows:
- Fibroblasts, which are the majority of the tenocytes. They attach themselves to the end of the tendon and begin to produce various substances which make up the extracellular matrix. The major substances produced by the fibroblasts are collagen, elastin, and proteoglycan.
- Chondrions, which develop into fibrous cartilage. They provide the scaffold for the tendon, like cartilage provides the scaffold of bones.
- Osteoblasts, which develop into bone. These develop into Haversian systems which are the spaces in which blood vessels travel through the tendon to supply blood to the cells and make sure there is transport of waste from the cells.
- Myoblasts, which differentiate into myocytes, and then eventually develop into muscle fibres.
If there is a tendon which is not utilised, or one which is not needed any longer, then the cells will enter apoptosis and slowly degenerate, usually taking about 65 years.

## Tendon maturity
After the tendon has been fully-formed, then it enters a phase of growth called the maturing

<EOD> Acute effects of a moderate dose of alcohol on cue-elicited cigarette urges and smoking rate in daily smokers.
OBJECTIVE
The present study investigated the effects a moderate dose of alcohol has on cigarette smoking and cue-elicited urge to smoke in daily smokers.


METHOD
Smokers (n = 28) underwent two daily sessions of smoking in a laboratory setting. During one session, participants were asked to smoke only 1 cigarette at 1 hour, and during the other session, they received a moderate dose of alcohol (0.5 mg of alcohol per kilogram of person weight) or placebo. Smoking, urge scores, and craving ratings and effects were reported. The craving task consisted of two phases: an anticipatory phase, where smokers were presented with cigarettes and then received instructions on how to prepare for the experiment, and a cue-elicited phase, where 30 pictures related to smoking were sequentially presented.


RESULTS
Statistical comparisons within subjects revealed a significant decrease in the smoking rate and in the urge scores during the first hour (p < .001). Furthermore, a significant reduction of smoking rate was observed in sessions with alcohol relative to a session with placebo (p = .049). However, a significant reduction in the urge scores only reached in the cue-elicited phase (p = .040). Also, alcohol had a significant effect on craving intensity (p = .041).


CONCLUSIONS
The present study demonstrated that administration of a moderate dose of alcohol reduced urge levels as well as the smoking rate in daily smokers, and this was evident during the anticipatory and cue-elicited phases.<EOD> Comparison of 1% and 2% intravenous lidocaine infusion for postoperative analgesia in thyroid surgery: A randomized

Istanb. 2021; 8(5): 494-501.The gut microbiota has been described to play a fundamental role with the pathogenesis of neurological and immunological diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS). According to some studies, the composition of gut microbiome influences the immune system also by modulating the integrity of intestinal epithelial barrier, bacterial metabolites, proinflammatory cytokine levels and antibody response. In this context, it can be hypothesized that a dysbiotic gut microbiota can contribute to the development of MS through a proinflammatory environment. Further findings suggest that MS patients show also dysbiosis involving the whole gut. It was observed a reduced microbiome alpha diversity in MS patients, that is associated with both severity of the disease and gastrointestinal symptoms. Interestingly, there is evidence of altered bacterial populations in MS with an increased prevalence of the Bacteroides genus, and depletion of Eubacterium rectale, Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, and Roseburia species during relapse. The knowledge gained in understanding the role of gut microbiota in MS has led to novel therapeutic strategies, including microbiome alteration by probiotic intervention. Currently, there are no probiotics clinically validated for the treatment of MS, but clinical trials of probiotics supplementation are ongoing in MS patients. Probiotics, also referred as 'beneficial bacteria', are non-pathogenic bacteria that are proposed to have, under certain circumstances, beneficial effects on health. <EOD> Molecular analysis of the 3p chromosomal gains in a panel of human breast cancer cell lines and primary tumors: implications for gene expression.
Epidermal growth factor receptor gene amplification and loss of heterozygosity on the short arm of chromosome 3, as indicated by loss of sequence polymorphism at D3S956 in the region 3p14.2-21.1, have been used as specific markers for breast cancer susceptibility and progression to metastatic disease, respectively. We report here that gains in chromosome 3p detected by comparative genomic hybridization are always associated both with overexpression and amplification of the epidermal growth factor receptor gene. In turn, overexpression and amplification of epidermal growth factor receptor were not consistently seen in cell lines bearing only 3p loss of heterozygosity on microsatellite markers. These findings may suggest that either amplification of the epidermal growth factor receptor gene is sufficient to induce expression on its own or that only a specific subset of cancers with 3p loss of heterozygosity undergo selection for amplification of the epidermal growth factor receptor gene. We also found that overexpression of the 15 to 20 kb of RNA encompassing the erbB-2 gene (c-erbB-2 gene) is associated with gain of sequence polymorphism at D3S1235. In summary, the identification of specific molecular defects within gene-coding sequences in specific breast tumors might be instrumental for designing better clinical trials for therapeutic use of targeted agents.<EOD> A method of measuring the strength of the refractive index mismatch between the cell and the surrounding liquid: the "cavity method".

### Score Function.
In order to judge the performance of our method, we apply multiple metric functions to evaluate the performance of our method compared to other existing methods.

The metric function of Cohen's kappa is to calculate the agreement between classifiers. It is a score function that requires to provide a gold standard. Therefore, it requires labelling data by experts. That is to say, it requires us to provide annotated data (ground truth). The details of this score function can be seen in the paper `Metrics for Evaluating 3D Segmentation Methods'.
The interrater coefficient of agreement (IRCA) is to measure the agreement score between the result of annotators. It is similar with the Cohen's kappa and it can also be calculated by the following equation:

IRCA(S) = \sum\_{s=1}^{M}\sum\_{n=1}^{N}w_{s}w_{n}\mathbb{R}(s\cdot n)\mathbb{T}(s\cdot n)\ \ sum\_{s=1}^{M}\sum\_{n=1}^{N}w_{s}w_{n}\mathbb{S}(s\cdot n)\
where IRCA is the interrater coefficient of agreement, S is the total number of categories, N is the total number of cases, w_s and w_n are the weights for category and subjects, respectively, and ∑\_(s=1)^M\∑\_(n=1)^N w_{s}w_{n}\mathbb{R}(s\cdot n)\mathbb{T}(s\cdot n) is the sum of total ratings of same class and ∑\_(s=1)^M\∑\_(n=1)^N w_{s}w_{n}\mathbb{S}(s\cdot n) is the sum of subjects in same category.
In our paper, we use an IRCA as our score function. In details, this IRCA calculates the agreement of the outputs of the model and the ground truth.

## Precision
Now what is this phrase 'precision'?
Precision refers to the likelihood that the study findings of a clinical trial will be the same when repeated. As the precision is enhanced, the study results are trustworthy. Conversely, the larger the extent of variation of the findings, the less accurate and less reliable the results.
Precision in research indicates how much a study's result can differ from the truth. For example, although the average weight of the fruits and vegetables picked from a fruit shop could be determined as 350.00 gram, the weight measurements from each vendor could be very different, if the measurements were taken at different time periods--that is the consequence of precision loss. Therefore the degree of loss is one of the features of precision.
There are three kinds of precision that are usually considered:
- accuracy reflects the closeness of the measured quantity to the true value;
- consistency indicates the consistency of the repeated measurements; and
- repeatability is concerned with the repeatability of a study for the same result.
In this section, the focus is on the repeatability test. You can find out more information about the other aspects of the precision in [link1]. [LINK1].

## Repeatability
The repeatability is concerned with the repeatability of a study for the same result. Repeatability provides an estimate of the closeness of the results of a study. In other words, it is the ability of a study to detect a change in patient condition or a change of patient's response for the study drugs.
For the repeatability of a clinical study, the test and its repeatability study are summarized as follows:

\frac{\mathrm{dV}}{\mathrm{dV}_{a}}&=\frac{\mathrm{Xa}-\mathrm{X}}{-\mathrm{X} \label{repeatability-1}\\
