A: In a trial, the inclusion criteria consists of different aspects of patient's profile. The variables will differ from trial to trial. The sample answer you provided have 10 different variables, and the range in variables is 20, so the question is: 'how do we compare these two variable, is 20 > 100?' .
That brings a question to my mind: Are the two variables in this case are numerical? Or there are something else?
Then, there is another question: 'how are we going to measure the similarity between two values with the same range?' . Here is the answer: we use the cosine similarity to solve this problem.
Therefore, these questions may lead us to this problem where we have to calculate cosine similarity.
The cosine similarity is a statistic that represents the degree to which two non-zero vectors are oriented in the same direction. Given two random positive values x and y, and their direction vectors x and y, the similarity is defined as:

(cosine similarity) =
  x * y  ||x|| * ||y||

This link may be helpful: http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.cosine_similarity.html
Finally, as the cosine similarity is normalized between 0 and 1, you may assume that by normalizing 0.25, the similarity of two patients will become 0.5 (if the similarities are 1 and 0.5, then the similarity will be 0.5).

<EOD> Aortic wall characteristics in patients with myocardial infarction.
BACKGROUND
The pathogenesis and clinical significance of disruption in the aortic wall of patients with myocardial infarction (MI) have remained enigmatic in recent years. The present study was designed to address this issue.


METHODS AND RESULTS
Thirty-seven patients with MI (24 anterior MI, 13 inferior MI) and 26 healthy subjects (HS) with normal coronary arteries were examined. The internal and external diameters of the ascending aorta and the mean circumferential thickness of the ascending aorta wall were measured in transverse ascending axial images. The wall thickness (WTh) was calculated by dividing the wall circumference diameter by the calculated cross-sectional area. The ascending cross-sectional area was approximated by multiplying the aortic internal diameter by a constant (0.72). We found significant differences in the ascending aortic dimensions between the MI and HS groups. The differences in the aortic internal and external diameters between the groups were due to higher values in the MI group. There was no difference in the WTh between the MI and HS groups.


CONCLUSION
Our results indicate that different alterations in aortic and cardiac dimensions are evident in MI patients in association with their different heart failure conditions. Increased ascending aortic diameters in MI patients do not appear to result from increased aortic wall thickness, but from an increase in aortic diameter caused by increased aortic perimeter length.<EOD> The

Background: Plant extracts have been studied due to their biological properties and as potential functional and medicinal food ingredients. Arthrospira platensis is a cyanobacterial species widely used as an ingredient in the aqua feed for fish and prawns and in food supplements due to antineoplastic, antidiabetic and immunomodulatory properties. Here, we analysed the effect of the aqueous extract of A. platensis (A-A. platensis) on the bacterial composition of pig ileum using real-time PCR (quantitative PCR) analysis to quantify the intestinal bacterial growth. Fecal characteristics of pigs (weight gain, body weight, gastrointestinal transit time and rectal temperature) were also monitored by using a weighing balance, a stainless steel cylinder, a rectal thermometer and video-tracking system, respectively.Results:Our results revealed that A-A. platensis is well digested, as it is not observed in the lumen of porcine ileum. In addition, A-A. platensis supplementation had no visible effect on the intestinal characteristics of pigs such as body weight, total body weight gain, gastrointestinal transit time and rectal temperature.Conclusions: This study reveals, for the first time, the influence of A-A. platensis on intestinal microbiota without any side-effects on livestock and piglet growth. Congestive heart failure (CHF) is the final stage of heart disease in the development of cardiac pump failure. In recent years, the morbidity and mortality rates of CHF have been steadily increasing, which is also a public health problem.

Platelets (PLTs) play a role in both the progression and prognosis of CHF. Numerous studies have indicated that an imbalance in the platelet-to-lymphocyte ratio is a well-defined prognostic marker in patients with CHF.
Atherosclerosis is an immune response disorder, and platelets appear to be active participants in atherosclerosis. The PLT count, a routine haemogram test, may reflect the activity of atherosclerosis. Many crosssectional and longitudinal studies have linked an elevated PLT count with an increased risk of atherosclerotic plaque formation and clinical vascular events. Some studies have also reported a strong positive correlation between PLT counts and atherosclerosis-related markers such as C-reactive protein and N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide .
In addition to the classic role of PLTs in thrombosis, growing attention is being paid to the contribution of PLTs through the release of PLT microparticles (PMPs) to atherosclerosis. PLT microparticles (PMPs) are small (1-2 µm) membranous vesicles derived from the plasma membrane of activated PLTs, which contain a cell-type transcriptionally active nucleus.
As a bioactive mediator, PLT microparticles have been shown to promote inflammatory cell activation.

#### Challenge

You should compare a given patient note and the inclusion criteria of a clinical trial to determine the patient's eligibility. # Introduction
Mitochondria are essential double-membrane organelles that play indispensable roles in cellular respiration, energy production, metabolism, signaling, and gene expression and regulation. They are a complex evolutionary system that arose at the junction of the host cell and invading alpha-proteobacterial endosymbiontsand contains their genetic endowment in the form of circular double-stranded DNA. All vertebrates possess two mitochondrial genomes per cell: the circular mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) that encodes crucial proteins for oxidative phosphorylation (mtOXPHOS) and tRNAs and the linear mitochondrial ribosomal DNA (mtrDNA) that encodes 2 ribosomal RNAs. Metazoan mtDNA ranges in size from~20 kb in nematodes to~16 kb in humans. In addition to core mitochondrial gene products, mtDNA also encodes 37 tRNAs, 22 transfer-mRNAs, and 12 short open-reading frames (ORFs) that have no annotated function but do encode transcripts and proteins in nematodes, teleost fishes (12 ORFs), and mammals (15 ORFs). <EOD> Development and validation of a quantitative, multiplexed serological assay for SARS-CoV-2

The COVID-19 pandemic has caused immense human suffering and economic devastation that will require years of recovery. Efforts to understand and prevent the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) are hampered by a lack of high throughput assays for detecting SARS-CoV-2 specific antibodies. The only available tests to date use either low-resolution immunofluorescence or radioimmunoassay (RIA) methods that use recombinant protein fragments as antigens. These assays do not have the necessary throughput and the fragment antigen approach precludes detection of antibodies that target conformational epitopes. To overcome these limitations, we developed a high throughput 4-plex quantitative Luminex assay using full-length antigens and a unique peptide-based blocking strategy. The assay demonstrates robust seropositivity over a broad dynamic range and is a useful tool for estimating the fraction of the population with active antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. More broadly, this assay is an efficient platform for evaluating the kinetics, persistence, and antigenic coverage of humoral immune responses to human pathogens.
T he novel coronavirus, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has precipitated pandemic disease that has affected tens of millions of people worldwide and over 140,000 in the US . <EOD> A comparative study of the impact of SARS-CoV-2 on human and non-human hosts: a review from a palaeocological perspective

Human-to-wildlife spillovers have contributed to numerous transitions in host and pathogen biology. Many of these events were initiated by pathogens in urban settings via interaction with human pathogens. These spillover events are of particular interest due to potential impacts on host populations and ecosystem structure. Here we examine the role of the novel coronavirus, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), as a human-to-wildlife spillover pathogen from a palaeocological perspective. We compare the natural history of SARS-CoV-1, the putative zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2, and its natural hosts to the natural history of SARS-CoV-2 and its natural host. Results indicate both SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 fit the criteria for having a natural wildlife reservoir as these viruses have been sporadically detected for over a decade with no clear indicators of cross-species extinction. We note that the novelty of SARS-CoV-2 is due to the extent of the pandemic across wild and domestic environments, its global impact on the human population, and the fact the natural reservoir of SARS-CoV-2 has yet to be identified (and thus our ability to determine pre-existing evolutionary differences between natural hosts). Overall, the novel virus may have evolved to take advantage of anthropogenic-related changes in humans, bats and livestock as these taxa are important in human diets, trade and consumption; further, as such, SARS-CoV-2 may be well adapted to the global trade of humans and livestock. The importance of such a zoonotic spillover in bats and possibly pangolins is likely to be underappreciated in comparison to other wildlife taxa that may have suffered similar exposures. Ultimately, SARS-CoV-2, like many other viruses, may become a resident of the human population as it continues to evolve.Publisher'

# Problem
Given that $A, B \in \{0, 1, \ldots, 5\} $ is a random variable, determine the event $A + B \leq 4$ . [$A, B$ is used for patient and a clinical trial respectively]

# Solution
Let $A_i$ and $B_i$ denote the $i$-th sample of A and B respectively. 
Then, suppose $0 \leq A_1\leq A_2\leq \cdots\leq A_N$ and $0\leq B_1\leq B_2\leq \cdots\leq B_N$, and let $p$ be the p.d.o. of $A$ and $q$ be the p.d.o. of $B$. 
Then, $A_i$ and $B_i$ are i.i.d. random variables, with $p_A(x)$ the p.d.f for $A$ on $(0,1)$. Similar, for $x\in (0,1)$,
$$q_A(x) = 
\int_{x}^{\frac12}-2x\ln(1-x) \mathrm{d} p_A(\cdot)$$

To compute the expectation of this sum is the same as the integral $\dfrac{x}{1-\frac12x}$ multiplied by the integral of $-2x\ln(1-x)$. For a random variable $X$ with cumulative distribution function $F_X$ and p.d.f $f_x$ the expected value is given by
$$E[X] = \int_{F_X(x_0)}^F(\mathrm{x_0}^+) f_X(\mathrm{x}^\prime) \mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}^\prime $$

So,
$$\mathbb{E}[A + B] = \int_0^1 (x+y) \cdot \frac{x\cdot\phi(x,y)}{1-3\cdot x-y} \, dx$$

We know,
$$\phi\phi = \phi \cdot \phi = -2\cdot x\cdot f_x (1-2\cdot x) -\ln 1-2x$$

Receptor-tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are among the most important regulators of many cellular processes, including proliferation, survival, migration and differentiation. In response to growth factors and cytokines, RTKs generate multiple intracellular signaling pathways involving protein phosphorylation and dephosphorylation. Rho family of small GTPases (Rho, Rac, Cdc42) are well-known regulators of the actin cytoskeleton, the activity of which is crucial for the formation and dynamics of various cellular compartments. These proteins are involved in the modulation of cell proliferation, differentiation, membrane protein sorting, adhesion and migration. Rho proteins play an important role in the regulation of RTKs: they link the signals from receptors and their direct downstream targets, such as nonreceptor tyrosine kinases, ERK1/2, Src kinases and PI3K, to the actin cytoskeleton. Rho proteins also regulate the RTK activity through a direct binding with the components of the receptor signaling system, which leads to a change in the phosphorylation status of receptors by nonreceptor tyrosine kinases. A critical step for establishment of central tolerance involves the negative selection of thymocytes by selecting self-reactive T cells. Although the negative selection process has been studied for over 30 yr, how this selection is accomplished has been a continuing enigma. The role of HLA-DM in this negative selection process is a contentious issue. Expression of HLA-DM in thymus was initially reported to be undetectable, and several studies argued that HLA-DM is not required for central tolerance. However, we have shown that HLA-DM and MHC class II accumulate in cortex and medulla, respectively, during thymic maturation, suggesting that thymocytes are subject to both the positive and negative selection processes. Surprisingly, transcriptionally regulated expression of HLA-DM in thymus was shown to be low, but detectable. # Introduction
Falls in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) are frequent. Fall frequency ranges from 19% to 66%. The incidence of falls in patients with MS has been reported to occur in up to 66% of MS patients, although this varies widely from person to person. Fear of falling is a significant psychosocial condition that decreased level of physical performance and quality of life in middle-aged and elderly adults, and might be related to falls. A recent study showed that the odds ratio in elderly people was 8.3 (CI 95%), and that falls, in turn, doubled the risk of being overweight and of having hypertension.
The most common causes of falls in individuals with MS are loss of balance and muscle weakness. The causes of falls in MS are related to motor disorders, cognitive disability, fatigue, and visual and sensory-motor deficit. Balance in an upright posture is maintained through the integration of visual, muscular, and neuronal proprioceptive information. Muscles involved in balance are the biceps, quadriceps, calf muscles, abdominal muscles, and gluteus medius during weight-bearing exercises; these muscles are very important for balance and gait.

# 24.5 Assay_Level Eligibility_Assessment
This chapter focuses on a second task of the eligibility for clinical trials: the assessment of eligibility based on assay-level data. As with the clinical trial eligibility, we define this task as a function of patient as `get_assay_level_eligibility_note(): ` so that you can output the eligibility assessments of a patient for all the clinical trials and finally get the patient_level_eligibility for each patient.

First, the assay-level data are needed; therefore, the patients' assay-level data are loaded. We load the data that are contained in the columns `Id`,`assay_ID`,`patient-ID`, and `value` in the `assay_data` data frame. ## Test Set
All code and data of this article (except datasets) will be released after acceptance. This is a public service. In addition, datasets are provided to support reproducibility.

## Benchmarking data set
To benchmark [2,16] a range of techniques, an original synthetic data set is designed. Each sample is generated by a generative process that depends on the chosen model. The design of the dataset is inspired by the real problems of this article and the use case data set of [2,16], but contains no private or sensitive human data. The data set is provided as `Example_dataset.txt` in the [data folder](https://github.com/zhangjianqiang/clinical-trial-eligibility-assessment/tree/main/data). The data generator and the definition of all synthetic variables are provided as [R Script](https://github.com/zhangjianqiang/clinical-trial-eligibility-assessment/tree/main/R%20scripts/generators/Example_data_generator.R).
The following steps define the dataset generation. First, a data set of 500 samples is initialized with synthetic random seeds. Sequences containing 3 variables are generated for two datasets (patients and study). The generator of the first dataset (patient data) assigns variables between 0 and 1 (12 variables) and the generator of the second dataset (study data) assigns variables between 0 and 130 (6 variables) with 87 as the mean. A uniform distribution is generated uniformly for all variables in the first dataset and the normal distribution is generated for variables from 50 to 500 in the second dataset. After that, the generator generates categorical variables by randomly selecting values from set variables. For example, variables 32 and 266 are generated to variables 1 and 0, respectively, and thus the categorical variables have a frequency of 1. Similarly, the generative data set is extended to 200 samples by the same process, and a second random seed is provided.

## ➂ [A/N]
There are multiple levels in the CERT algorithm, including the Patient-level Eligibility, Trial-level Eligibility, Clinicaltrial-level Eligibility, and Study-level Eligibility, as well as the overall CERT score. The first is used to check if a patient is eligible for a clinical trial; the Trial-level can be used to check if the patient is eligible for a given clinical trial; and the overall CERT score can be calculated to determine if the patient is eligible for all clinical trials on a given disease. As we already mentioned in `01.01.050_cert_algorithm.md`, the calculation formula of this overall CERT score is:
[CERT overall score] = Patient CERT score + Trial CERT Score .
So we should calculate the overall CERT score for our patient, in the following section.

## CERT overall score for a patient
Before calculating the CERT overall score, we need to determine whether a patient is eligible for each of the included clinical trials on a given disease according to the `CERT Algorithm`. Then, the overall score is calculated by adding the scores of the included clinical trials.   

The following script includes a method to calculate the CERT overall score:

```python
def get_cert_summary(note_id, study_id):
    list_of_trial_study = list(note_id.studies.all())
    list_of_trial_summary = list(study_id.studies.all())
    if len(list_of_trial_study) > 0:
        note_summary = PatientSummary.objects.get(id=note_id.note_id)
        summary = get_trial_summary(note_summary, list_of_trial_study)
        overall_cer_score = get_CERT_summary_overall_cer(summary)
        return summary, overall_cer_score
```

Where:


* `get_CERT_summary_overall_cer` returns the summary of study-level CERT overall score, CERT patient score and CERT trial score.

The tests gave fair to good reliability coefficients except in the case of the refraction tests which may have given better reliability but were considered unsuitable. For the nonmedical group the average reliability coefficient was 0.7 for medical graduates, 0.4 for science graduates and 0.6 for science graduates with prior experience of ophthalmology. The average reliability coefficient for ophthalmologists after 5 tests had been done was 0.8. There was no consistent correlation between tests in groups of cases. There was good agreement between the scores given by medical graduates of different types of course in 2 out of 8 tests. In the other 6 the differences were not considered significant. There was no evidence that the average ophthalmologist had a better score than the various groups of test takers. It was concluded that: 1. Scores on the tests used showed the same tendency to disagreement as those found in other studies, and, that there was no good evidence of an improvement in the results with experience. Therefore, there was no reliable evidence of a correlation between scores and ability or lack of ability on the test. 2. Although the test results could be improved by giving preliminary training, it was not found possible to devise a valid and reliable score. Therefore, the tests did not appear to be satisfactory instruments for pre-registration evaluation or selection of students for pre-registration work. 3

[R2ML](www.r2ml.org) is a free-to-use machine-readable representation of a research article available on the web. It allows people to generate a high-fidelity representation of a biomedical article as an R Markdown file.

A paper published in a journal is a document that describes a study in the form of words and figures. However, the textual content cannot be analyzed further since it is in natural language. Therefore, it is important to export the information from the natural language to structured data representation such as R or Excel that will allow a researcher to apply data mining techniques on the information in order to derive new knowledge.


----

# Introduction 
The `R2ML` package extends the `R2ML` functionality to allow a wider range of input formats such as `HTML` and `PDF` and converts a selected subset of information from biomedical articles into the structured data format. `R2ML` was originally built to convert R Markdown files to `RDKit` data representation.  `R2ML` is a Python package to read various source formats such as `HTML`, `PDF`, and `RnLatex`. The `R2ML` package allows a person to generate a high-fidelity representation of a biomedical article in the form of a `R Markdown` format that can be easily consumed by the `R` programming language, and used to generate a list of objects in the `RDKit` data representation. `R2ML` can be used to convert the `R Markdown` representation to structured data in several formats including RDKit, Excel, csv, json, sdf, mol2, mol, and SMILES.

A traditional document published by the researcher to a journal is available in the form of textual documents such as `PDF` or `HTML` only. A person cannot analyze the information from textual content in a non-structured manner, but can only view the information in the natural language. The natural language, however, is unstructured and cannot be read by computers or machines. Therefore, it is necessary to export the information of the article to the struct

<EOD> Clinical and serological responses in patients with human toxoplasmosis of various clinical types
Blood serum and urine were collected from 40 patients with central nervous system and eye toxoplasmosis, retinopathy due to toxoplasmosis, acute toxoplasmosis with negative or ambiguous history of infection, and preclinical toxoplasmosis, as compared with control patients and volunteers. A clinical analysis and ELISA and DIF serological tests were conducted during a follow‐up to these patients for 24 months.<EOD> Atypical pulmonary manifestations of chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is characterized by a clonal proliferation of CD5 B lymphocytes, which accumulate primarily in the peripheral blood, lymphoid tissue, and bone marrow. Although pulmonary disease may develop in patients with CLL, it is a rare complication of the disease and is often overlooked. In addition, pulmonary complications may occur in the absence of classical B cell lymphocytosis. We present here a rare case of a 64year-old female patient with a 1-year history of non-productive cough, fatigue and decreased exercise capacity. A chest radiograph was compatible with a multifocal pneumonia. A lung biopsy was performed to investigate the cause of these symptoms; no classical histological features of CLL could be identified on the biopsy. CLL was finally diagnosed after positive B-lymphocyte immunostaining of paraffin-embedded tissue. To our knowledge, this is the first case of atypical pulmonary involvement of CLL diagnosed by histopathological demonstration of lymphocyte infiltration in the lung parenchyma and its successful treatment by rituximab.

<EOD> A Case of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis



## Case report
A 45-year-old African American man was referred for evaluation of hyperpigmented patches that had been present for two years. He had a history of hypothyroidism diagnosed four years prior, for which he was treated with levothyroxine. Four months prior to presentation, he presented to his primary care physician with complaints of hyperpigmented areas over his cheeks. The rash was pruritic, and he was initially treated with clindamycin. However, the lesions persisted and new lesions subsequently developed over his back. In addition to the pigmented lesions, the patient complained of hair loss, which the dermatologist suspected was telogen effluvium. He was treated with steroids at his dermatologist's request, but the rash persisted.
Physical examination revealed well-demarcated areas of discrete hyperpigmentation, ranging from 2 to 3 cm in diameter, on the patient's cheeks, forehead, and back . Dermoscopy showed a network of white lines. Histopathology from the back showed an increased number of Langerhans cells, consistent with Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). The results of biopsies from his cheek and forehead also revealed LCH and a decreased number of epidermal melanocytes. The number of melanophages was also decreased in the patient's skin biopsy specimen. The patient did not have a familial history of similar pigmentary abnormalities. He denied experiencing any additional symptoms, including fever, weight loss, diarrhea, cough, or fatigue.

# Discussion

<EOD> The role of immunoglobulins in allergic reactions.
The IgE isotypes of antibody (allergen-IgE-cell-mast cell complexes) are responsible for the immediate allergic response (asthma, angioedema, itching, etc.,), while IgG antibodies (pre-formed specific antibodies and synthesized upon re-exposure to allergen) are thought to mediate the chronic allergic response (asthma, in particular). While IgE molecules are essential for these reactions, the function of IgG in allergic reactions remains unknown. The IgG immune response is essential for the allergic reaction, even when IgE is not present. Allergic reactions would not likely occur if IgG synthesis were completely suppressed. <EOD> The E6 oncogene of HPV‐18 up‐regulates HSF1‐induced expression of HSPs and increases the growth, survival, and invasion of cervical cancer cells under heat shock and hypoxic stress
Heat shock proteins (HSPs) have been implicated in many human diseases. HPV infections have been shown to increase HSPs expression and stabilize several oncogenic proteins; however, the direct effects of HPV E6 oncoproteins on HSF1‐regulated HSPs are not well understood yet. Here we investigated the effects of HPV‐18 E6 on HSF1 activation and cell stress survival by modulating the transcription of HSPs. We stably transduced Hela and SiHa cells with a lentiviral vector expressing the E6 protein. The E6 oncogene significantly affected the expression of HSF1 proteins and their upstream‐activated factors, including HSF‐1, HEAT SHOCK FACTOR TRANSCRIPTION FACTOR 2A (HSF2A) and 2B (HSF2B). In addition, overexpression of E6 oncoprotein was shown to promote the survival and invasion of malignant cervical cancer cells under heat shock and hypoxic stress. The E6 oncoprotein also upregulated Hsp70, Hsp90α and Hsp90β at mRNA and protein levels in HeLa and SiHa cells, providing evidence of E6‐mediated induction of cellular heat shock response. E6 inhibition decreases HSF1 expression, resulting in decreased cell invasion in vitro, as well as inhibition of tumor formation and invasion in a cervical cancer mouse model. Finally, our study showed that HSF1 expression correlated with that of its downstream target HSP70 in cervical tumors. Our work reveals a new mechanism between HPV oncoproteins and HSF1, providing clues to potential therapeutic targets to combat HPV‐related diseases.<EOD> Fatigue during spaceflight, part II: microgravitational effects on human performance.

T he prevalence of overweight children in the Netherlands is higher than that reported elsewhere in Western Europe. It is unclear what factors may influence or explain this seemingly paradoxical observation. However, this trend in recent years appears to correspond with the increased immigration to the Netherlands, as demonstrated by Statistics Netherlands .
An article in this journal and in The Lancet points to the potential influence of the increased consumption of high-caloric and energy-dense types of foods in addition to the decreased level of physical activity being undertaken by children. 1,2 To test this hypothesis, we determined the prevalence of overweight and obesity among two subpopulations of the Dutch population -Dutch-speaking children and children from immigrants, defined by the parents' country of birth.
This analysis was based on data collected as part of the study "Preventing overweight in preschool children: a randomized controlled trial," ongoing at the Academic Medical Center in Amsterdam. In the study, 690 4-year-old children living in the region of Amsterdam, who visited the outpatient division of the academic department of pediatrics from September 2004 to October 2006, were randomly assigned to intervention groups focused on prevention of overweight. Parents were interviewed after the routine visit about whether the child was of Dutch origin or a child of immigrants.
The children came for the initial visit at age 4 with no recent symptoms or conditions, and only a minority (127 [or 18%]) had been seen by a physician in a preceding year. Weight and height measurements were then taken, following which parents completed a questionnaire. Children were classified into three groups depending on the body mass index (i.e., weight in kilograms divided by the square of body height in metres). The three groups were normal (between the 10th and 85th centiles), overweight/obese (≥ 85th centile) and underweight (< 10th centile).

<EOD> Enhanced biosynthetic activities in transgenic soybean roots overexpressing the type-B response regulator GmRegulator of G-protein Signaling4.
The family of G-protein signaling pathways has been implicated in stress responses and developmental processes; however, most of the signaling components and their function in crops remain unidentified. The family of type-B response regulators (RRs) is encoded by one gene class of the family of G-protein signaling pathways in Arabidopsis. Despite a high degree of similarity among RR proteins, they play distinct regulatory roles and have different subcellular localizations. Here, we describe the expression and function of RR4 (GmRR4), a type-B RR gene from soybean. RR4 is constitutively expressed in various plant organs, including roots and stems upon abiotic stress conditions; its mRNA steadily accumulates in a wide range of plant tissues and also in leaves after dehydration. Transgenic Soybean overexpressing gmRR4 has enhanced root biomass and aphid resistance, and was sensitive to the salt stress. RR4 was targeted to the nucleus under nonstress conditions, which was altered to enrich in the cytoplasm under abiotic stress conditions. This change is consistent with the finding that RR4 functions in the cytoplasm, not in the nucleus. These observations indicate that RR4 participates in various abiotic stress responses including biotic stress and provides new insights about RR4 and G-protein-mediated signaling pathways in plants.<EOD> A comparative study of the anti-inflammatory effects of chloroquine and thiamazole using different rat models.

<EOD> Ankle distraction arthroplasty for talar osteochondral lesions. Surgical technique.
BACKGROUND
Restoration of the tibiotalar articulation surface for osteochondral lesions on the talar dome has been difficult.


METHODS
In this retrospective study of twenty-three ankles that were treated by ankle distraction arthroplasty, we present our surgical technique, the clinical outcomes, and the preliminary findings at a minimum follow-up of two years and with computed tomographic evaluation. Distraction and osteotomy were performed over either the medial or the lateral tibia. The patients were assessed by the modified Maryland Foot Score.


RESULTS
The ankles were assessed by the Orthopaedic Research Institute Ankle Score. The average patient age at the time of the procedure was thirty-seven years, and the average follow-up period was four years. The average increase in the medial clear space was 5.3 mm, from 3.5 mm to 8.8 mm; the average increase in the lateral clear space was 6.3 mm, from 4.9 mm to 11.2 mm. No patients developed avascular necrosis or had loss of bone from the distraction zone, which was not covered by articular cartilage. All except one patient had a good result. The average preoperative score of forty-three points increased to seventy-nine points; in some patients the final score improved above the average points received by a normal foot in a healthy individual (ninety-two points).


CONCLUSIONS
Ankle distraction arthroplasty is a useful technique for restoring the articular surface on the talar dome in osteochondral defects, and allows an effective reduction of congruency in the sagittal and mortise views of the ankle.<EOD> High-resolution 3D surface topography reconstruction using confocal laser scanning microscopy and computational geometry.

<EOD> In situ formation of hierarchical mesoporous titania coating on cotton fabrics for dye and antibiotic sensing.
A hierarchical mesostructured titania film was synthesized directly onto cotton fabric by an improved sol-gel method which involves the formation of polyoxocaprylsiloxane (POCS) monolayer and in situ formation of titania layer. POCS monolayer can be used as the template to synthesize mesoporous titania because of its hierarchical nano- and microstructure. The synthesis is very simple, reliable, and cost-effective, and titania can be uniformly grown on fabrics without any treatment, which is very beneficial to the applications of fabrics. The effects of pH value, the dosage of POCS, and titania on the morphologies, pore structure, properties, and photocatalytic activities of the film were investigated. The characterization results show that the hierarchical mesostructured titania film uniformly coats the fabrics, with an extremely large surface area of 121.06 m2 g(-1) and pore volume of 0.3600 cm3 g(-1). The titania film exhibits excellent dye adsorption for colorants (MB and RhB), and the adsorption capacity of 20 min is 1.67 mg g(-1) for RhB and 1.11 mg g(-1) for MB dye. # Conventional Approach
Instead of doing `Triallevel eligibility` with a simple text annotation, you might prefer to first extract all the patient information like age, gender, and prior medication history and then compute the risk of the trial. Finally, you would generate a risk-level label for the patient based on certain risk criteria. Note that, here you also compute the text score using the sentence embedding model. However, you can not simply concatenate the embeddings of the document and sentence embedding, as shown in [inst01]. Instead, you should compute the cosine of the angle between sentence and vector representations, as shown in [inst02]. This step works as a text normalization layer, thus eliminating the need for the risk level model, which otherwise would have to be trained separately. 

Instead of [inst05], you might also try writing code as:

	patient_tensor = doc_tensor.T[1]
	cosine = - torch.cosine(sentence_tensor, patient_tensor.squeeze()),

	# Trial-level_eligibility score = 2 # for patient

#### 3-2-2-disease progression

The assessment of disease progression is also a critical step in assessing whether or not a patient is eligible for a clinical trial. There are three common measures of disease progression. However, no single measure supersedes the others. Therefor, you will evaluate the following three scales: 1) the 5-point Modified Rankin Scale, 2) the Barthel Index, and 3) the Modified Lawton Instrumental Activities of Daily Living scale. If any of the scales indicate substantial disease progression of a patient from the initial evaluation in the ER to the day of the intervention, the patient is ineligible for the trial. 
You are not required to choose which one is most appropriate under a given scenario.

<EOD> Association of Sensate Dural Layers With Pterygopalatine Artery: An Anatomical Observation
BackgroundThe pterygopalatine artery (PPA) is vital for preservation of the blood supply of the brain. The dura mater (DM) of the midbrain is intimately connected to the PPA and therefore is exposed to its high risk of occlusion. These 2 structures can be directly connected during skull base approaches in cases of extensive dural retraction. We aimed to investigate the possibility of developing an alternative route for the preservation of the blood supply of the brain in such cases. MethodsWe dissected 15 formalin-fixed specimens of the pterygopalatine region by using the modified Kerkhoff technique to identify the DM. The relationships between the dural folds and the PPA were analyzed. ResultsWe obtained 2 new findings in these specimens. First, the PPA was found in the DM in 10 (67%) specimens. Most of these PPAs entered through the roof of the infratemporal fossa through the greater petrosal nerve, or through an intradural route, in the midbrain region. The DM contained several sensate folds. Some sensate DM was connected with the PPA, and some PPAs were located behind the DM. Some of these PPAs passed through the sensate DM, which had sensation on the PPA. ConclusionsWe reported a surgically significant and easily recognizable variation of the PPA located in or behind the DM in the midbrain region and communicating with the PPA. This variation may help preservation of the blood supply to the brain in cases of surgical insult to the DM.<EOD> Invasive Hemophilus influenzae infections in adults. Expert Level: In all levels, the expert level is denoted as E. In a sense, the expert level is analogous to a supervisor level. The output can be a list of numbers, a list of tuples of the form (word, score), or anything that can be processed in a regular expression pattern. There is no limit to the number of patterns in the E level. Each pattern is processed in exactly one E step. Each occurrence of input is analyzed by a single set of patterns. A set of rules may be designed for example to find all words that are followed by numbers, if there are at least 2 numbers in between every 2 findings (e.g., you may find all words such as 2+2 or 2+ 9 or 2+16). This is also a set of patterns that can be set to work as an E level. Similarly, a single set of patterns can also be designed to find words such as `hospital` and `clinical trial` and also `Hospital-Southwest Hospital` and etc. Again, this is another set of patterns which can be implemented as an E level.

The assessments of eligibility have a three-point scale: 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial; 1) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation; and 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.
Predicting eligibility is important for two main reasons. First, it is useful for prioritizing patients for in-person assessments to check their eligibility. In some cases, many patients might be eligible for a given clinical trial but we can only recruit a limited number of patients. If we can predict the eligibility probability during the computer screening process, it can reduce the number of in-person assessments and save time and money.
Second, while determining the patient eligibility is a binary task, we should be able to predict the eligibility as an ordered value among the three-scale value. Determining that a patient is eligible will guide the patient care better than determining that the patient is not eligible.

Background: Congenital disorders of glycosylation (CDGs) are a group of extremely rare genetic defects characterized by improper glycosylation. There are many types of glycosylation disorder classifications that have been proposed, many of them involving overlapping groups of symptoms and diagnoses. A genetic mutation in UDP-Glucose Glycoprotein Glucosyltransferase(UGGT) was discovered. Conclusion: This case report indicates that CDG with a genetic mutation in SLC35A2 may cause symptoms including developmental delay, recurrent severe vomiting, and chronic lung disease.

### 311
<EOD> The role of the adrenal medulla in the pathophysiology of arterial hypertension

Although the etiology of arterial hypertension (AH) is diverse and incompletely understood, the renin-angiotensin aldosterone system and the sympathetic nervous system have been suggested as being the most important factors initiating the development of AH. In addition to the role of the central nervous system, the peripheral sympathetic nervous system is involved in the regulation of salt and water homeostasis, renin secretion and vascular tone. The central nervous system can excite the sympathetic outflow to the adrenal medulla (AM), where catecholamines are synthesized and stored. On the other side, there is also an ascending sympathetic influence on the AM, leading to the enhanced catecholamine release. The AM is the principal source of circulating catecholamines, noradrenaline (NA) being the major NA stored and secreted from this organ. Although previous studies demonstrate that NA itself exhibits hypotensive effects, there are also reports showing that the AM is a site of amplified blood pressure response during AH. Recent studies have shown that sympathetic activity targeted to the AM is enhanced in patients with essential AH as well as in AH associated with renovascular atherosclerosis (RMAH) and pheochromocytoma. Thus, one might suggest that the AM plays a role in the pathophysiology of AH.

# Introduction
The prevalence of arterial hypertension (AH) as a global public health issue has been estimated to be about 1.13 billion persons, which accounts for around a third of the global burden of disease. [INST] Hello. You are a helpful assistant for clinical trial recruitment. Your task is to compare a given patient note and the inclusion criteria of a clinical trial to assess eligibility. 

In the last two instructions, you were asked to make a trial-level eligibility on a patient and to repeat the trial-level eligibility, which was `Trial-level eligibility: 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.`. If the trial is eligible, the patient is eligible as well.

So, we have to find a way to automatically find patients that are eligible. A promising idea is to calculate the number of times a patient note is eligible for a specific trial. We can calculate the number of matches, which is the number of true positives, that is, matches that correspond to the patients and the trial eligibility scale, by dividing the number of true positives by the total number of occurrences for the patients. #### Scoring
To score each note:

* Count the number of exclusionary clinical factors (x) in the clinical note. Include a zero if no clinical factors exist.

* Assign a score of 1 for each exclusionary factor. If zero factors exist, you do not need to score this line.


* Assign a score of 0 for each inclusionary factor (y) in the clinical note. Include a zero if no inclusionary factors exist, i.e., no exclusionary factors exist, and the patient meets all other eligibility criteria.


* Calculate the eligibility score in the clinical trial by summing any x and subtracting any y, i.e., Eligibility score = x - y.

* Use a cut-off number to determine whether your patient is eligible or ineligible. In this study, we use a threshold number of 2. So if the clinical trial eligibility score is 0 (x=y=0), we have a patient who is 100% eligible. If the clinical trial eligibility score is lower than 1 (x>y), then the patient is 100% ineligible. If the trial-level eligibility score is 1 or 2 (x>y), then the patient is 50% uncertain, since we do not yet know whether he or she was eligible for the trial or ineligible for the trial. In future studies, we would like to determine if it is useful to have you rank the note from 1-27, so as to determine how your confidence score decreases with each decrease in score. [INST]

Purpose To develop a coding system for the criteria applied within clinical decision support systems, for use in vascular interventions. Methods The classification criteria and categories defined by a clinical decision support system applied on vascular interventions were classified into eight categories: Medical Prescription, Antibiotic Prescription, Cardiac Arrhythmia, Electrolyte Disorder, Renal Insufficiency, Neurological Disorder, Patient's Characteristics, and Drug Interaction. Each category was subdivided into subcategories. A standardized medical taxonomy was used as the structure to build the classification hierarchy. Results The hierarchy has a total of thirty-three sub-categories. It enables the clinical decision support system to create notifications, based on information extracted from clinical patient records. The application can then issue alerts, warnings, or reminders to a health care provider, or it may require intervention of a health services management team. Conclusion A classification system with defined criteria was designed, that enabled the generation of clinical decision support notifications. The system was tested for the alert generation of a clinical decision support system applied on vascular interventions and has shown to work efficiently.Key PointsThis paper presents a structured methodology, using a medical taxonomy for clinical decision support criteria classification, applied to vascular interventions.The proposed methodology has enabled to create a hierarchy structure with clear definitions to classify clinical decision support criteria.

BACKGROUND
The objective of this study is to evaluate the quality of life of a sample of patients suffering from dementias and the effect of the treatment on this quality of life and on the caregivers.


METHOD
This study is a retrospective assessment, carried out in 81 demented patients, which were seen consecutively. We used the following assessment instruments: Barthel test, mini-mental state examination, and the dementia scale of dementias questionnaire (SDDQ). We collected socio-demographic data on the patients and caregivers, and we evaluated the quality of life of the patient (measured with the SDDQ), caregivers, and the type of dementia.


PATIENTS AND PROCEDURES
We applied the quality of life questionnaire to the patients and to the patient's family caregiver (SDDQ). We collected all necessary demographic data and assessed the patients with the following tests: mini-mental state examination and Barthel index. These data were compared with and without pharmacological therapy.


RESULTS
The type of dementia of the patients was most frequently vascular dementias (26%) and frontotemporal dementias (24%). The mean Barthel score was 82+/-25 and the mean mini-mental state examination score was 12+/-5.3, which implies that the patients had a low degree of dependence and a non-cognitive altered state of consciousness. The score for quality of life in the SDDQ (18.9+/-12.8) indicated a high level of satisfaction. The mean SDDQ score for the patients was 19+/-13.7, vs. a score for the caregivers was 24+/-12.9, which means a better quality of life of the patients. The mean score of the patient was lower in the vascular group (14+/-10.8) and higher in the frontotemporal group (23+/-16.9), although, due to the type of patients we included, the differences were very small. <EOD> Theoretical Study of the Intermolecular Interactions between Dioxabicyclononatriene (DONT) and Amino Acid Based Chiral Recognition Sites.
Four DONT derivatives functionalized with an amino acid cleft (AACl) based chiral recognition site (CP178, EA150, DA150 and TE150) were designed as models to investigate the effects of the amino acids on the intermolecular recognition of DONT by means of dispersion corrected M062X density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The four DONT derivatives were docked to a common template comprised of the N-terminal region of the human carbonic anhydrase II (HCA II). A comparison of binding affinities of CP178, EA150, DA150 and TE150 for DONT in an aqueous environment at several temperatures is presented. This comparison is based upon the Gibbs free energy difference between DONT in water and DONT in the AACl template (GDD). In a previous experimental paper, we proposed that the hydrophobic effects at the interface of the two recognition moieties and the amino acids were the main contributors to the interaction between HCA II and DONT. In this theoretical study, the interaction between the recognition moiety and the amino acids are attributed to the stabilization of the binding of DONT to the template and the interaction between the two recognition moiety. In addition, the interaction between the AACl templates and DONT is shown to depend upon the size of the template cavity, as well as its hydrophobicity. It is predicted that a template with a large cavity size, such as TE150, would interact more weakly with DONT as compared to a template with a cavity size closer to the HCA II size, such as EA150. These results are in agreement with experimental study which shows that the amino acids functionalized with a large-sized cleft are better able to selectively bind the DONT derivatives than the templates functionalized with small-sized clefts.<EOD> Diversity and distribution

OBJECTIVE
To compare the accuracy of a previously published algorithm to one that incorporates information on clinically relevant characteristics of type 1 diabetes.


RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
We used computerized physician billing claims and a population-based diabetes registry to identify a cohort of 16.6 million individuals covered by the Ontario Health Insurance Program. A subset of 16,691 individuals with complete information on 23 variables was used to develop and test the new algorithm. A test for the difference in sensitivity was performed.


RESULTS
The percentage of subjects identified by the algorithm was 92.4% (71.5-100%), compared with 11.9% (10.8-12.9%) achieved by the previously reported algorithm. # Avoidance of spurious results
In this challenge, you are dealing with a real patient clinical note and a real clinical trial. However, your patient's clinical note and that of other patients are highly unlikely to have been enrolled to the existing clinical trial for a couple of reasons: 
First, the patients in the existing clinical trial are healthy volunteers. A patient clinical note should almost never be written by a qualified doctor.

However, RT can compromise the DNA of both healthy and tumour cells. This exacerbation of DNA damage can trigger cell death in tumour cells through the mechanisms of apoptosis or necrosis. In contrast, in healthy and normal cells, this may manifest itself as reduced cell proliferation and, consequently, contribute to the inhibition of tumour growth (and, therefore, to an improved overall outcome). Low-dose radiation therapy (LD-RT) is defined as a regimen of radiation therapy that delivers less than 2 Gy divided over several treatment days. The first aim of this study was to evaluate, using a rodent model of radiation therapy, the effects of low doses of radiation on tumour growth and tumour infiltration by immune (CD4+ and CD8+) and non-immune (CD206+, CD31+) cells, as compared with conventional (high-dose, c-RT). The second purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of low radiation on the immune and non-immune cells of healthy organs, such as the heart, liver, spleen and kidney. Background/Aims: There is no doubt that cognitive reserve allows the brain to efficiently maintain or reorganize for an individual its optimal functionality within the same neurological environment even when there is dysfunction. To date, the concept of reserve has not been well understood by clinicians, possibly because it has not been included in the widely used cognitive staging models of cognitive decline. The aims of this study are to develop a model that combines reserve, mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and dementia and to test the predictive validity of such a model in a cohort of health check-up examinees. Methods: Two models of reserve combining MCI and dementia were designed. First, reserve was conceptualized as the interaction between the individual and the environment. Second, the accumulation of vascular lesions with the individual's ability to compensate for losses, or its ‘neural capital’, were considered. A logistic regression analysis was performed in a sample of 1,073 health check-up examinees. Results: The multivariate adjusted logistic regression models showed the model of ‘reserve’ composed of the interaction of reserve and MCI (orange model) to have higher adjusted odds ratios (ORs; 95% CI) in the discrimination of non-cases, including healthy subjects, from cases with mild neurological disorders than the model of ‘reserve’ composed of the accumulation of vascular lesions with the individual's ability to compensate for losses (red model). The inclusion of cognitive reserve in the cognitive staging models yielded increased validity in the prediction of cognitive staging. Conclusions: The orange model of reserve may improve the prediction of a more rapid onset of dementia.

<EOD> A review: Clinical and metabolic features of hyperinsulinemia in the normal state.
Hyperinsulinemic normal man has been reported not infrequently in the past several years. The prevalence of this abnormality among normals is estimated to be from 1 to 13 percent. All reported patients have had a low insulin response to oral glucose intolerance tests, a normal or elevated insulin response to i.v. glucose injection, and normal or elevated fasting levels of insulin. Hyperinsulinemic normals appear to have more clinical (obesity) abnormalities than nonhyperinsulinemic normals. Hyperinsulinemia, once induced in normals, was found to persist after 4 to 6 days if fasting was avoided. Metabolic studies done on patients with persistently normal insulin levels and patients with hyperinsulinemia have led to the conclusion that: (1) pancreatic β cells respond to fasting and glucose loading with a greater insulin secretion than normal; (2) patients with hyperinsulinemia have greater insulin response to all degrees of glucose stimulation; (3) fasting hyperinsulinemics have lower hepatic glucose reutilization and a lower capacity for gluconeogenesis, although rates of exogenous glucose disappearance are normal; (4) the low insulin response of hyperinsulinemics to OGTT is not due to saturation of insulin receptors by physiologic levels of insulin circulating during the test, but appears to be due to an intrinsic insulin defect; (5) patients with hyperinsulinism have lower glucose disappearance rates at a glucose load of 500 mg/kg body wt, although the rate of increase of blood glucose with the load is similar to that of nonhyperinsulinemics; (6) hyperinsulinemia appears to be familial, and (7) hyperinsulinemia might be explained by genetic or environmental factors (possibly an increased adrenergic tone), by overactive β cells, or by a low threshold for insulin secretion

<EOD> Prostate-specific antigen and breast cancer.
Prostate-specific antigen (PSA), a 33-kD serine enzyme, has a major role in the physiologic function of the prostate gland.1 The enzyme's primary function is the formation of choline at the sn –3 position of membrane phospholipids in sperm,2 and the enzyme is secreted into seminal fluid but not into serum.3 A second physiologic function of PSA is associated with an inactive form of the metalloenzyme, matrix metalloproteinase-2 .4

Prostate-specific antigen was originally identified as a component of semen, where it was found at relatively high concentrations; the serum level is lower. With prostate cancer, elevated serum prostate-specific antigen levels occur, but there is considerable overlap with prostate-specific antigen serum activity in men who have benign prostatic disease or who are healthy. Apart from the prostate and sperm, there is no specific tissue that exhibits activity of this enzyme.1 Prostate-specific antigen serum activity correlates reasonably well with prostate size and severity of prostate cancer.1

### PROSTATE CANCER

Elevated serum prostate-specific antigen levels with and without prostate cancer occur in several extratesticular abnormal conditions. These include seminal vesicle hypertrophy or atrophy (with elevations up to about 15 to 20 μg per liter) and infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Other conditions, although not associated with prostate cancer, also lead to elevations in serum prostate-specific antigen. These include benign prostatic hyperplasia, prostatitis, prostate nodules, and the presence of carcinoma in situ of the prostate. Finally, because of the ubiquitous presence of prostate cells in the male body and the inability of prostate to divide without entering a prelethal state, serum prostate-specific antigen levels increase with age. The presence of prostate-specific antigen in malignant pleural, ascitic, and pericardial fluids has also been reported .

__2. Procedure-level eligibility__
You will make the procedure-level eligibility on each of 8 clinical trials by the procedure_level_eligibility keyword. 
The trial_level_eligibility variable describes the general eligibility of a patient, but for each of the N clinical trials, a patient may be ineligible for the same reasons that prevent them from participating. Therefore, to determine the patient's eligibility for a clinical trial, the procedure_level_eligibility variable is used to determine if the patient can participate safely and effectively through each of the N procedures and procedures. The trial_level_eligibility variable of the final procedure_level_eligibility variable is used after determining the patient's eligibility to that procedure. 
Additionally, the procedure_level_eligibility information allows for a more specific patient assessment in relation to the protocol of the trial, but also in relation to the disease that the clinical trial is focused on. 
As for the trial_level_eligibility value, if a patient meets the criteria required by a clinical trial, the procedure_level_eligibility value will be True; otherwise, it will be False.

The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of meloxicam (2 mg/kg of body weight, single dose) in Holstein cows receiving either a concentrate-fibrous material feeding or ad libitum hay consumption. The trial day for each animal was considered as the 3rd d postpartum. Milk yield was measured twice daily and averaged daily for the trial days. Cows in all groups increased their milk yield (% of the 1st d) postpartum and continued to increase linearly up to the 28th d, regardless of feed. There was no effect of meloxicam on milk yield, milk component content and milk composition on any of the experimental days. Mesenchymal cells from the synovial intima of the synovium present proliferative characteristics in the presence of articular fluid. We investigated the effects of an 8-week old rat articular fluid on the growth properties of a rheumatoid synoviocyte cell line. Growth was compared to control medium and to the articular fluid from the control rat, which we called young fluid (YF). The mitogenic activity of both these fluids on the synoviocytes was evaluated using counts of the cell population. YF induced a dose-dependent increase in the number of cells while the old medium had no effect up to the 50% dilution. Then, in order to evaluate a possible mitogenic influence of the growth hormone or a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) degradation product, we compared the relative amounts of GAG in YF and old fluid. ## F.1.1.2 | Experimental Design
A good way is to include a summary of the methods and the outcome measures at the end of each section of the paper, as in the following example: ## Overview The goal of this investigation was to develop and test a novel approach to eligibility assessment, which we term a clinical study eligibility screener or CSES. We studied the usability of the CSES in two separate but complimentary settings: (1) a usability study during which investigators were prompted to complete a set number of clinical trial eligibility screens for patient charts and (2) a naturalistic feasibility study in which we observed investigators’ use of the CSES in real-world patient chart review.

Participants and Procedures

To evaluate the usability of the tool, 25 trained investigators were randomized to receive instruction on use of either the CSES or a traditional chart review approach. Investigators received training in each tool before reviewing 12 de-identified patient charts for 60 minutes. The primary outcome measure for this study was the proportion of patients judged eligible by review. The chart-review process was recorded on video with a HIPAA-compliant audio recording device. To evaluate tool feasibility in a real-world setting, investigators were prompted to complete a set number of eligibility screens on patient charts during a clinic visit. The charts were selected randomly from the previous day’s clinic session. Investigators were prompted to use the tool only 50% of the time, allowing them the choice to review patients using either the CSES or traditional study eligibility review. During clinic visits, investigators documented the clinic date, eligible patients (according to the CSES), and patients for whom they completed the CSES. The study lasted 8 weeks.

Results

We will write functions to do the processing. In this section, we write the Python functions that perform the processing tasks of the TrialDetection system for generating Trial-level eligibility. They are implemented in the `trial_detect.py` module.

The main function of the module is the function `main()`. This function inputs a string file and outputs a dictionary file. The dictionary file contains all the Trial-level eligibility data for a clinical trial. Each key corresponds to a patient note. And the values are the respective Trial-level eligibility. The string file is the annotation file. The annotation file is a YAML file with a data structure in the form of a dict, and each key and value is the same as it is in the Trial-level eligibility from the output of the main. It is a dictionary file of the patient-level annotation. First, set the directory where you are in the program. And then the two strings are read. The string of the annotation file is the list of patient notes. The string with the content of the Python dictionary is the list of clinical trial information. And then we call the `parseClinicalTrialInformation()` function to read and store the information from the first string. And then, we iterate through the list of clinical trial information and call the function `make_trial_document()` function to parse the information and make the dictionary file of each clinical trial information. Then, we iterate through the `make_trial_document ()` list and call the `makeTrialEligibilityFiles()` function. Finally, we save the saved dictionary files of the trial level eligibility. This solution was developed by <NAME>, a student from the University of Tokyo, for Dr. <NAME>'s class. [INST] Hello. You are a helpful assistant for clinical trial recruitment. Your task is to compare a given patient note and the inclusion criteria of a clinical trial to determine the patient's eligibility. The factors that allow someone to participate in a clinical study are called inclusion criteria. They are based on characteristics such as age, gender, the type and stage of a disease, previous treatment history, and other medical conditions.


The assessment of eligibility has a three-point scale: 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial; 1) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation; and 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.


Here is the patient note:
A 48-year-old white male with history of common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) with acute abdominal pain, fever, dehydration, HR of 132 bpm, BP 80/40. The physical examination is remarkable for tenderness and positive Murphy sign. Abdominal ultrasound shows hepatomegaly and abundant free intraperitoneal fluid. Exploratory laparotomy reveals a ruptured liver abscess, which is then surgically drained. After surgery, the patient is taken to the ICU.
        Here is the clinical trial:
Title: Prophylactic Fenestration of the Peritoneum in Kidney Transplantation


Summary: A single centre open randomised parallel-group study to evaluate whether prophylactic fenestration of the peritoneum at the time of renal transplantation prevents lymphocele formation.~Adult (>18 years old) recipients of renal transplants from deceased donors were eligible for inclusion. From March 2007 to May 2009 130 patients were included. The patients were randomized either to peroperative peritoneal fenestration, or to serve as controls. Block-randomization was conducted in groups of 10, drawn from envelopes containing five notes from each group

531.output:
.<EOD> Hydraulic fracture network flowback monitoring based on long-range and large-aperture distributed acoustic sensing

Hydraulic fracturing has emerged as the key technology in the field of shale gas development. However, the lack of effective real-time fracture flowback monitoring methods can lead to the leakage of fracturing fluid to the surface environment and possible wellbore failure such as fracturing pipe break and cementing layer penetration failure. Meanwhile, the effect of flowback on fracture conductivity and gas production in shale gas wells is not clear. In this paper, a method of distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) fracturing flowback monitoring and estimation is presented by using an 8.23 km, 32-channel DAS line. By investigating the propagation characteristics of artificially generated fracture network acoustic signals, a calibration model is proposed to correct the fracture network acoustic signal amplitude for the purpose of improving the accuracy of DAS flowback monitoring. The relationship between the propagation speed of acoustic signals and liquid volume per unit area is established and the liquid volume per unit area of fracture network flowback can be estimated by using the relationship. The result shows that the measurement accuracy of DAS flowback velocity is improved from 0.89 to 0.75 of theoretical flowback velocity. Moreover, the flowback-rate estimation based on the real-time acoustic-propagation data shows obvious advantages. As a result, the flowback velocity and volume can also be estimated based on the measured velocity and the flowback data. The proposed study may have a certain degree of practical reference significance for effective fracture network flowback monitoring and estimation, fracture conductivity control and flowback risk analysis for shale gas wells.Supplementary materials for this article can be accessed on the website at https://doi.

# Introduction
The shale gas development is a new exploration direction in the second half of the 21st century. The evaluation of eligibility for a clinical trial should take into account each trial-level eligibility criterion of a clinical trial, i.e., the patient note.

Pharmaceutical production is generally linked to international drug companies, which own patents for many drugs. The pharmaceutical industry in Latin America is mainly comprised of local firms, which produce a large variety of drugs, especially generics. This situation has been changing in recent years, with an increasing number of mergers of local producers with foreign producers. Some of the most common national drug lists contain the drugs which are part of the WHO Model List of Essential drugs. 551.output:
## Conclusion

You have seen examples of assessing eligibility for patients of recruitment in clinical trials. 
As you can see, some clinical trials are more demanding than others as they are either broader or narrower. A broader clinical trial can recruit more patients than a narrow clinical trial. You should keep this in mind when deciding for the eligibility assessment of clinical trials. 
There are many elements you can consider when assessing the eligibility of patients for clinical trials. However, the two most important parameters are risk factors and contraindications that can decrease patients' quality of life if they enter a clinical trial. Contraindications should be the first factor to consider when deciding the eligibility of patients. 
Risks of clinical trials differ across trials. Some of them carry risks such as side effects or a decrease in quality of life, some of them may cause unnecessary harm due to inappropriate treatments or diagnostics, while others may not add anything new regarding patients' care or treatment. 
It is not recommended for patients to participate in studies that do not carry any new information about patients' care or treatment. On the other hand, you can see that patients may suffer from unnecessary risk or discomfort when entered to these studies. 
Even though risk factors and contraindications should be considered as the most significant parameters to assess eligibility, you may have to weigh other factors such as patients' needs, severity of patients' treatment, or physicians' and patients' preferences while deciding on the eligibility assessment of patients for clinical trials. 

The assessment of patient's eligibility for clinical trials is performed by clinical trial research assistants. Certain rules and regulations related to the conduct of clinical trials require these research assistants to assess eligibility.

<EOD> 3D-Printed Hydrogel Microstructures with Controlled Rigidity for Quantifying Cells’ Mechanosensing and Mechanotransduction

Here, we present and evaluate three-dimensional (3D)-printed polyacrylamide (PA) hydrogel microstructures for the investigation of the cell's mechano-sensing and mechanotransduction process. We employed our established 3D printing method and prepared soft and stiff hydrogel pillars with different geometries and varying rigidity. We observed significant differences between the responses of fibroblasts to the stiffness of the microstructures, with stiffer microstructures yielding stronger cell-adhesion signals and more complex cellular patterns in the vicinity of the structure. These observations led us to conclude that our 3D-printed soft and stiff microstructures could be useful in investigating specific biological phenomena, such as mechano-sensing. In this work, we present the fabrication of 3D printable hydrogel structures with tunable stiffness in order to stimulate cells with controlled rigidity. Our data indicate that our 3D-printed hydrogel microstructures represent a versatile tool to study cells' mechanical response to external stimuli regarding their mechanical properties.

<EOD> Prevalence and correlates of mental distress among civil servants in Sokoto, Sokoto state, Nigeria

Background: Mental distress is an important yet relatively neglected health problem in civil services. The paper examines the current prevalence and correlates of mental distress among civil servants in Sokoto, Nigeria.Methods: A cross sectional descriptive study was conducted using a multistage random sampling technique to select 225 civil servants (116 males and 109 females). Mental distress was determined by using the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-28). Chi square test was used to determine the association between mental distress and other independent variables.Results:The prevalence of mental distress was 56.7% (130/225), with higher proportion among females (34.4% versus 44.2%, P = 0.022). Of the 130 respondents with mental distress, most (58.5%) had common mental disorders (CMDs), major depressive episode (MDE) (21.5%), generalised anxiety disorder (GAD) (18.5%) while 10% had anxiety and depression related symptoms (AD). Factors significantly associated with mental distress among the civil servants were; female gender (P = 0.022), age of 21-40 (P = 0.019), lower income (P = 0.020), single marital status (P = 0.020) and being involved in court cases (P = 0.031).Conclusions: There is a high prevalence of mental distress among civil servants in Sokoto. There is need for urgent interventions to reduce mental distress.

<EOD> A study of intravenous administration of chlorpromazine for the inhibition of an uncomplicated labour.
Summary. 
 
A prospective study of administration to 47 patients during labour of 25mg chlorpromaazine hydrochloride i.v. showed no indications of a toxic accumulation of the drug in the blood serum and no serious side effects or changes in the neonatal heart rate. Significant slowing of labour, a lowered Apgar score and a decreased number of vigorous crying during the first minutes after birth were seen in the group of the women who had received chlorpromazine. It is suggested that these findings are attributable to placental absorption of the drug during uterine contractions. 
 
 
 
Zusammenfassung 
 
Prospektiver Einfluss der Injektion von 25mg Chlorpromazin nach i.v. Verabreichung in die Blutbahn bei 47 Patienten in der Geburt auf die Dauer des Geburtsvorgangs und die Apgar-Score der Frischgebornen wurde untersucht. 
 
 
 
Die i.v. Verabreichung des Medikaments hatte keine negativen Wirkungen. Eine Zunahme des Blutspiegels wurde nicht beobachtet. Auch nicht unerwartet war die vermehrte Wirkung des Medikamentes in der ersten Stunde nach Geburt. Serausnahmen in den ersten Lebensstunden waren aber auch bei diesem Befund keine. Das Apgar-Score der Frischgebornen war in den Chlorpromazinprasentierten unter dem der Kontrollgruppe signifikant niedriger. 
 
 
 
Es werden sich vermutlich auf einer der beiden Wirkungswege vor, ein Uberdosten des Medikamentes in die Plazenta oder eine intraabdominelle Umverteilung der vermehrten Blutmenge zur Kryorrhagie verantwortlich. 
 
 
 
Resume 
 
Influence de l'injection intraveineuse de 25 mg de chlorpromazine dans la periode de la naissance

His blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg, his pulse is 141/min, and his respirations are 18/min. His blood urea nitrogen is 33 mg/dL, and his serum creatinine is 1.3 mg/dL. Title: Enteroaggregative E.Coli (EAEC)

Summary: Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) is a bacterium that can cause diarrhea. The purposes of this study are to: determine how much EAEC is needed to cause diarrhea in a healthy person, determine if a genetic factor is important in causing diarrhea, and to see how the body's defenses control EAEC. Participants include 25 healthy adults, ages 18-40. Volunteers will be assigned to 1 of 4 dose levels in groups of 5 volunteers each. One volunteer in each group will receive a sodium bicarbonate placebo solution. Volunteers will be admitted to the University Clinical Research Unit for up to 8 days. Volunteers will receive therapy with levofloxacin to treat the infection either once they develop diarrhea or at Day 5 if they remain asymptomatic. Study procedures will include saliva, blood, and fecal sample collection. An optional study procedure will include an intestinal biopsy. Participants will be involved in study related procedures for up to 223 days.

<EOD> Neovascularization in the omentum: the role of microvessel count and microcirculation.
BACKGROUND
An abundance of tissue neovascularization favours wound healing and is considered a prognostic indicator of clinical outcome. The aim of this prospective investigation was to determine the level of omental neovascularization and potential correlating factors in patients with severe abdominal sepsis.


METHODS
Patients who were scheduled to undergo early secondary closure of abdominal compartment after an intestinal resection for severe abdominal sepsis were enrolled in the study. The omenta were harvested by a surgical procedure during the closure of abdominal compartments. In seven patients, an omental biopsy was performed using a diathermy device at the same operation. The same device was later used to examine histological specimens. Neovascularization score was expressed as the frequency ratio of small vessels (<50 microm in diameter) to the large vessels (>50 microm). Microcirculation was measured by laser Doppler flowmetry (moorVMS-LDF).


RESULTS
Seven patients died (D-group) and eight recovered (R-group). The survivors showed a higher neovascularization score compared with the non-survivors. Histologically, the neovascularized omentum exhibited less connective tissue and more adipose tissue than the non-neovascularized omentum. The microcirculation of survivors was higher during the early phase of the post-operative course than that of the nonsurvivors.


CONCLUSION
Neovascularization plays an important and unique role in omentum-induced wound healing as indicated by the findings of this study. In our case, survivors had greater neovascularization than non-survivors. The microcirculation of survivors was higher than that of non-survivors during the early post-operative course. The level of neovascularization in the omentum correlated with the level of circulation. Microcirculation is an important indicator of the functioning of o

Abstract Dysfunction of the central nervous system outside of the motor system has been well documented in Parkinson's disease (PD). Although such cognitive deficits are clearly present, no tests with known sensitivity and validity have been standardized for the diagnosis of “mild cognitive impairment” in PD. The objective of this cross-sectional study was to assess the utility of eye-tracking technology in the early diagnosis of cognitive dysfunction in patients with PD. Using the iView X Hi-Speed eye tracker, participants completed a test protocol consisting of fixation stability, reaction time and a Stroop task. Eighteen PD patients participated in this study (average age 58.5 years). Results demonstrated reduced accuracy, speed and efficiency across a series of eye-tracking tasks that were well-correlated with Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) and Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) scores. Notably, PD patients scored significantly less accurately and slower in these tasks compared to healthy participants. These results suggest that eye-tracking technology offers a valid and objective measure of cognitive impairment and could be used as an indicator for the early detection of dementia in PD.<EOD> The potential of fetal transplant for treatment of Parkinson disease.
