# Conventional ML Approaches on the TCI2018 Challenge
One of the most attractive characteristics of ML techniques is their ability to learn non-linear functions from data. In the following table are seven conventional ML techniques, along with some information about them. 
- **Decision trees**: These models classify data based on partitions of the input vector space. When testing, the decision tree is run, with the input vector placed at the node corresponding to the partition it is closest to, and the tree branches down. If the input vector is placed in a leaf node, it is assigned to the class corresponding to that leaf node. 
- **Random forests**: This is a variation of decision tree that uses bootstrap aggregation in order to create a vote-based classifier. Rather than relying on a single decision tree to assign a new datapoint to a certain class, aggregating the results from many decision trees produces a final class. The tree that is used to train the model usually uses a different, randomly chosen subset of the data compared against each training tree. 
- **Gradient boosting**: This technique produces a final model from a set of base models. Each base model tries to approximate its function to close the gap with the final model. The final result comes from ensemble functions to predict the final outcome. Each base model is a different tree, using the same parameters. 
- **Logistic regression**: This is a simple yet effective linear classifier. Instead of trying to classify discrete classes, it classifies data by a continuous variable. The model generates its own score to divide data into various classes. The decision for the class is made based on the score. 
- **Covariance discriminant analysis**: This is a linear method with the purpose to transform a data set into a higher dimensional space, where each datapoint is described by a linear combination of the original features (principal components), and where the linear combinations are related to a dependent variable. 
- **KNN**: It applies the K-nearest neighbors algorithm to classify data points. It determines which class a given datapoint should be assigned to by taking the majority of classes in neighborhoods of the datapoint. 
- **KNN 10 Classifier**: It applies the K-nearest neighbors algorithm to classify data points. In this case, the number of classes

		<EOD> Mobility of the lower lumbar spine, pelvis, and hip in asymptomatic pregnant women
The objective of this study was to evaluate lower lumbar spine, pelvic, and hip motion during pregnancy. Spine kinematics is of great interest in clinicians, but the available data are limited because most of the research has been focused mainly on posture and disorders (e.g., disc herniation). In this study, we evaluated changes at the segmental and joint levels during pregnancy. Segments were monitored using skin markers placed on the 7th cervical spine (C7), 11th thoracic (T11), sacral (S1), and right greater trochanter of the femur. Lower lumbar spine segments were monitored using a nonrigid motion-tracking system based on ultrasonic tracking devices positioned on L1–5 vertebrae. The pelvis and right hip were tracked using skin markers on the left and right anterior superior iliac spines (ASISs) and the sacroiliac joint was monitored using a skin marker placed centrally between the posterior iliac crests. We found that the lumbar lordosis, lumbar flexion during knee extension, and the left and right trochanteric ranges during gait decreased significantly during pregnancy. A significant increase in lumbar flexion with knee flexion was observed during pregnancy. In addition, a significant decrease in flexion and extension was observed in all hip joints during pregnancy. Our study has found that all joints of the lower spine, pelvis, and hip show decreased mobility as pregnancy progresses; these data could be useful in the future when evaluating women before, during, and after pregnancy. This study is the first to evaluate segmental motions during pregnancy in a large population of healthy pregnant women.<EOD> The Nonsurgical Management of Facial Pseud

PURPOSE: The purposes of this study were as follows: (1) to evaluate the safety and performance of intermittently applied negative pressure wound therapy (IPWT) in the care of wounds after gastrectomy in high-risk patients and (2) to compare the IPWT group with a historical group in the same clinical situation. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We enrolled 40 patients receiving a clinical trial of IPWT for wound care by a single surgeon in our institution. The patients were randomly chosen and assigned to an IPTW group and historical control group. The primary outcome of interest was the rate of treatment-related complications. The secondary outcomes of interest were the rate of wound complications and time to wound closure. RESULTS: There was no significant difference between the IPWT group and the historical control group in terms of operation times and hospital stays. The IPWT group had no significant increase in wound complications. The IPWT wound healing process was faster compared to the controls. - The system uses a Python program to run an experiment: The system will not execute every case in the test data. That is to say, not every sample is evaluated for every factor. Rather, it may not be performed one by one. As a result, an experiment may fail to evaluate certain cases.
- There is little variety in terms of the sample population. In actual clinical data, many patients with low health status, various disease statuses, and various patient comorbidities are required.
- In our system, there are two types of user interfaces: The front end and the back end. Each system must use the appropriate language to provide an easy-to-understand service for the user. For front-end developers, it is more convenient to develop the web-based system using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, but back-end developers should use Python and Django. However, it is not easy to achieve the goal of interoperable development by allowing the use of various programming languages in one application. As a way around, we plan to use R to develop the front end and Django to develop the back end. As you can see in the following table, the functions implemented with R are mainly used in the interface (front-end part), while the Django part is composed of the user management and database management. The development of the back end is done with the Django framework, making management easier.

### Implementation steps
- The first step is to install Python.
- Python can be downloaded from the Python website.
- The second step is to install Python development software (IDLE). This is a special

**Relationships**

There’s nothing wrong with taking help from somebody else’s work, but when you do you must cite the references properly and acknowledge the original contribution. 

There are two types of relationships you can have with others’ data or code: 

  1. Use data or code from an open access source that you have cited in the reference
  2. Reverse engineer data or code that someone else shared with you but did not publish or put it in an open source repository

The best way to use another person’s code or data is to cite the data or code in the reference section of your paper. 

Sometimes, you may face the situation where you don’t have any alternatives than to use someone else’s data or code but you would like to give them credit. Cultured fibroblasts (H-6) were treated with gamma radiation (3.5 Gy) and then incubated in a medium containing various agents. All agents (dexamethasone, amphotericin B, cocaine, progesterone, procaine hydrochloride, dibucaine, and ethanol) were used at concentrations of greater than 3 X 10(-4) M. The synovial fluid (SF) immune system contains important information concerning the pathophysiology of inflammatory joint disease, and its components are recognized as valuable biomarkers. SF plays an active role in local inflammatory arthritidis, and its immunological properties reflect the current state of inflammation. Consequently, it has been widely studied in the diagnosis and treatment of inflammatory joint disease. The current knowledge regarding the immunological features of SF in four common kinds of inflammatory joint disease, including rheumatoid arthritis (RA), osteoarthritis (OA), psoriatic arthritis (PsA), and osteonecrosis of the femoral head (OFH), is presented in this review, with the aim of increasing healthcare industry interest in SF immunological properties. We also review these properties' value in diagnosis and prognosis, highlighting their therapeutic potential and proposing their possible applications in future therapy.

<EOD> Synchronization of oscillators. I. Periodically forced simple maps.

Systems that cannot be described using one variable often require the analysis of phase variables. In the context of dynamical description of brain oscillations, or so called neural field theories, an important problem is the synchronization of phase oscillators. Previous theoretical results have shown that oscillators that are described by simple maps can exhibit several modes of synchronization, depending on their parameter values and on the coupling topology. While the concept of synchronization is well understood, a rigorous proof of the existence of a desired mode of synchronized dynamics that is desired by the physiologist, is in many cases still missing.In this letter, we present a numerical scheme for the computation of the time evolution of the phase velocities. This dynamical vector data is then used to classify and describe the synchronization modes using a graph theory approach based on synchronization matrices. Our approach is validated using 2000 Monte Carlo simulations of the Kuramoto phase oscillators in case of periodic forcing.PACS number: 05.45.Xt 05.45.Ac

# I. introduction
To understand the nature of information processing in neural networks, it is crucial to determine how neuronal populations synchronize their activity.
This was in fact the rationale behind the initial introduction of Kuramoto' models: a theoretical framework to study phase oscillator networks and synchronization. The basic ingredient of Kuramoto phase oscillator networks is the concept of synchronization for oscillator populations.
Recently, this concept has been linked to neural fields, the theoretical framework underlying the analysis of brain wave dynamics in EEG/MEG, see.
The aim of this letter is to provide a scheme to computationally assess the synchronization of phase oscillator models. Our strategy here is twofold. First, we propose a numerical scheme to compute the time evolution of the phase velocities. Second, the analytical use of the Kuramoto-like dynamical equations allows us to describe the type and the degree of synchronization present between the oscillators. Our approach is validated using a simple Kuramoto type model of coupled phase oscillators. * Electronic address: francois.cognet@paris-sciences-et-lettres.fr.

<EOD> A Comparison of Gait Kinematics of Amputee-Subjects Walking With Bionic and Conventional Bipedal Prostheses
This paper presents a comparison of the three-dimensional gait kinematics of five amputee-subjects walking with two bionic prostheses which incorporate bionic knees with an adjustable knee extension moment and two conventional bipedal prostheses. The subjects all had a Transtibial-amputation. Each subject was requested to walk with each prosthesis on a level treadmill at self selected velocities. Motion analysis techniques were used to collect body segment kinematics and video data was captured concurrently. Joint angles were computed using computer programs for the analysis of gait. Gait velocity was lower for the bionic prostheses when compared to the Conventional Prostheses. The bionic knee caused a reduction in the stance phase knee extension angle and a reduction in the duration of the stance phase of a step cycle. A: I had to think about this one for a few minutes but it was pretty interesting. You have two criteria, the patients note has different criteria and the clinical trial has different criteria. You don't have any knowledge about the patients and what condition they are in etc. You need to figure out what makes a patient eligible and what makes them not eligible. A way to think about it is by splitting them up into two lists.

A: This question is asking the user to read the patient's clinical history and match it to the clinical trial's inclusion criteria. There is no information provided in the program to be able to match the clinical history to the clinical trial. That means the user should first understand the purpose and the inclusion criteria of the clinical trial, then the clinical history of the patient.
So first thing, the purpose of the clinical trial is to investigate renal function after cardiac surgery.
So, the inclusion criteria means, in order to be eligible to join the clinical trial they should:


*

*be male

*have a urine output of less than 0.2 mL/kg/hr shortly after undergoing major surgery

*have generalized edema

*have a blood urea nitrogen of 33 mg/dL

*have a serum creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL

*have an initial urinalysis that shows specific gravity of 1.017

*have a microscopic examination that shows 1 WBC per high-power field(HPF), 18 RBCs per HPF and 5 granular casts per HPF

*have a fractional excretion of sodium of 3.3%

So, in order to match the clinical history to the inclusion criteria they need to find what information from the clinical history matches what information from the clinical trial inclusion criteria.
Let's do this by using a tree-based recursive descent.
There is a tree-based recursive descent in which the root contains all the patients information. At node one the root is split into two children. This happens for every child node.
One child node will have no information and will be ignored. The other child node will have a subset of information.

df_trials = pd.read_csv('Trials.csv')

<EOD> Repeated Low-Level Radiation and Cancer

In the past, concerns about cancer risk from low-level radiation (LLR) have often been based on out-ofdate science or anecdotal evidence. The purpose of this review is to provide an overview, primarily for the nonscientist, of the scientific evidence concerning risk assessment of cancer from LLR. We will examine the existing biological principles and the available epidemiological evidence for the cancer risk from exposure to LLR. The epidemiological evidence will be addressed from multiple perspectives involving study design, the radiation dose range, and the nature and dosimetry of radiation exposure. Because exposure to ionizing radiation (IR) can have either stochastic or deterministic effects, both the risk models and their validity will be discussed, which is essential in evaluating cancer risk from multiple low-dose exposures. It is well recognized that the current models are not perfect, and in some cases are flawed. Because low-dose cancer risk assessments have often been the focus of substantial heated debate, we also discuss the issue of risk controversies and communication, with a focus on LLR.

## Biology and dose response studies for cancer

## Types of radiation
Radiation is defined as ionizing energy that is deposited in matter and which ionizes (splits) atoms and molecules, thereby generating free radicals. Electromagnetic waves are a form of radiation and are found on the electromagnetic spectrum from gamma rays (the most energetic) to microwave radiation with wavelengths greater than about 10 meters. Photons and elementary particles are two classes of particles that are found in radiation. Radioactive and low-level sources may emit particles or rays of electromagnetic radiation . Radioactive sources emit any one of the following types of radiation, in addition to combinations thereof: gamma rays, beta particles, alpha particles, neutrons, X-rays, ultraviolet, soft and hard 1 Electronic mail: ewingr@umich.edu rays, and millimeter waves (extreme energy low-level radiation). Objective:To improve knowledge of cross-immunity between HIV-1 and HIV-2, we sought to determine the impact of a HIV-2 infection on HIV-1 dynamics, and vice versa, in patients with the same HIV-1 variant. Methods:We compared CD4+ T cell count kinetics using multiple-timepoint CD4+ T cell count data from 1162 HIV-1 infected patients from the APROCO cohort enrolled in the French per protocol population from the time of HIV seroconversion. Results:Four hundred and twelve patients were infected with HIV-1 CRF02_AG. Among these, 47 (11.5%) had superinfection with HIV-2. The median CD4+ T cell counts of super-infected patients was 23.0 cells/mm3 lower (P = 0.004) than those of non-super-infected patients at the time of the HIV-2 diagnosis (18 months, 95% confidence interval 9.8–2.1 cells/mm3; 36 months, 7.9–3.9 cells/mm3; 60 months, 10.1–0.9 cells/mm3) but not thereafter. This difference was mainly due to the large difference within 18 months. None of the other HIV-1 variants showed a similar difference between superinfected patients and non-super-infected patients. Conclusion:HIV-1 infection is associated with a lower CD4+ T cell count among HIV-1 patients infected with the CRF02_AG variant but not among patients with other HIV-1 variants. Superinfection with HIV-2 can have an additional effect on the CD4+ T cell count only during the first 3 years of HIV-1 infection. <EOD> Development of microscale in vitro assays for the analysis of the cocaine antagonist, cocaine bis-diethylstilbestrol amide.
Current in-vitro cocaine analgesic potency and pharmacokinetic assays are not amenable to testing of new cocaine analgesic medications because they lack the necessary quantitative and qualitative precision to be used in drug screening programs. We have developed two simple in-vitro microscale assays for use in the primary screening of cocaine analgesic medications; a rapid quantitative cocaine-induced plasma neurotransmitter release assay to assess the cocaine antagonist (prodrug) properties of the cocaine analgesic medication, and a qualitative screening assay to assess cocaine pharmacokinetic properties. The assay development was completed on a microscale using a manual pipetting system to facilitate the production of standardized assay samples. Assay precision is similar to that achieved using manual pipetting systems in larger scale assays. The cocaine induced plasma neurotransmitter release assay utilizes the microscale version of the in vivo cocaine antagonist assay (IC(50) = 4.2+/-2.5 nM) developed in our laboratories, which measures the cocaine antagonist induced inhibition of plasma and whole blood cocaine-induced dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine and epinephrine neurotransmitter release using fluorometric detection. The assay development for in vitro cocaine pharmacokinetics assays was achieved using a high affinity cocaine specific antiserum produced by immunizing sheep with cocaine. A microscale non-quantitative in vitro cocaine pharmacokinetics assay was developed to determine possible drug (cocaine) serum interference, due to cocaine serum binding, in the antiserum assay system. Background: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a persistent communication between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta in premature infants with varying prognosis. Identifying its prognostic factors will facilitate a more individualized management of PDA in preterm infants. Objective: Therefore, the current study aimed to retrospectively assess prognostic factors for PDA in a single-center neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) over a 17-year period. Patients and Methods: The prospective data set included the birth information, diagnosis, vital signs, medications, echocardiographic findings, biochemical measurements, and outcome data for the preterm infants and neonates at our NICU who were admitted between January 1 1999 and December 31 2015 were reviewed and analyzed. Results: A total of 636 infants were found eligible for participating, and 50.1% of them were males. The gestational age (GA) ranged from 25 to 37 weeks with the mean birthweight (BW) of 1,286±612 g. The primary diagnosis of PDA was recorded for 251 (39.6%) patients with a mean GA of 31.5±3.2 and mean BW of 1,762±606 g. <EOD> The N-terminal Domain of the NADP-Linked Malic Enzyme of Maize Plays a Role in Both Cytosolic Localization and Enzyme Kinetic Properties*
We have isolated cDNAs encoding two different isoforms of maize NADP-malic enzymes (NADP-MEs; EC 1.1.1.38), which vary by a 6-amino acid insertion at their hydrophobic C-terminal domains. Western-blot analysis using anti-ME antibodies showed that the C-terminal tail has three major isoforms. Because the C-terminal domain in maize NADP-ME is known to be important for the binding of the enzyme to the cereal endosperm protein (57-kDa protein) and the cytosolic association of maize chloroplast NADP-ME, we investigated whether the new isoforms also associate with the cytosol in the same manner as the previously reported C-truncated NADP-ME. We infiltrated agrobacterium into maize immature cobs, in which the NADP-ME is only expressed postanthesis, to examine the cytosolic association of the NADP-ME. The results indicated that the new long isoforms showed a cytosolic association much like the previously reported short isoforms, despite the additional 6 amino acids, and that the cytosolic association was severely impaired or completely abolished in the enzymes that showed a deficiency of the C-terminal domain by the absence of 6 amino acids (i.e. the C-truncated forms and long isoforms). We found no evidence of an interaction between the 57-kDa protein and any NADP-MEs tested (either the native or the truncated NADP-MEs). The analysis of the kinetic properties of the wild-type NADP-ME indicated that the kinetic parameters V max , K m -glucose 6-phosphate, and K m -oxaloacetate were dependent on the C-terminal domain. The authors report the results of a prospective study regarding the use of ETOH sclerotherapy for patients with non small renal cancers, either asymptomatic and detected by ultrasonography or diagnosed during follow-up in patients known to have end stage renal disease on hemo dialysis. Between January 1994 and December 2005, 88 consecutive patients underwent ETOH sclerotherapy due to non small renal cancers. Among them, 55 patients had asymptomatic lesions and 33 patients developed cancer-related symptomatic lesions including hematuria, pain, or fever. The procedure was done through a single puncture using a 5 mm Chiba needle. The sclerosant agent was 95% ethanol applied incrementally in 2 to 5 ml aliquots. Patients underwent a second session for incomplete initial ablation. Follow-up included regular surveillance of serum creatinine levels every 3 months using laboratory analysis, 99m Tc MAG-3 renal scintigraphy and ultrasonography. The median follow-up was 2 years (range: 3 months to 5.6 years). The median ablation volume was 138.5 mL and the median total treatment volume was 183 mL. The rate of hemoglobin decrease at 1 month after therapy was 2.5 g/dL and the rate of decrease of serum creatinine was 0.4 mg/dL. There was only one case of local tumor recurrence. Objective: Thailand, a country with endemic chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, has been recently reclassified based on the new World Health Organization (WHO) criteria of acute hepatitis B. <EOD> Grip Strength Increases Over a 5-year Period in Older People with and without Diabetes.
AIM
The present study investigated longitudinal changes in grip strength. The aim was to test the hypothesis that changes in grip strength are slower in people with diabetes type 2 than those in the control population.


METHODS
A prospective follow-up study with repeated measures was performed with a 5-year difference in time between measures (48-month interval). Data were drawn from the Malmö Preventive Project, which is an intervention study with a 48-month follow-up period. The study was designed as a cohort study. The final sample included 100 men and 122 women with diabetes and 128 men and 80 women with risk factors, and two controls (reference group) in each gender. Measurements were made by a standardized technique and analyzed with descriptive statistics.


STATISTICAL ANALYSIS
Data were analyzed with repeated measures.


RESULTS
Grip strength increased in both groups during the period studied. For men, this increase was 2.6 kg (23.9%) in the group with diabetes and 3.05 kg (20.4%) in the group with risk factors. The increase for women was 3.4 kg (27.7%) in the group with diabetes and 3.5 kg (19.7%) in the group with risk factors. In a 48-month interval, grip strength increased significantly in both men (0.65 kg, P=0.000) and women (0.8 kg, P=0.001). <EOD> Characteristics of Neutropenia in Cisplatinum-Treated Patients with Malignancies

Purpose:The purposes of this study were to identify the characteristics of neutropenia and examine the relationship between neutropenia and the survival period. Materials and Methods: To investigate whether differences existed in the neutropenia characteristics between patients undergoing standard and extended cycles of chemotherapy, or between patients treated with and without granulocyte stimulating factor (G-CSF), we compared the clinical characteristics, including the cumulative dose of cisplatin and G-CSF and the serum granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) level, of 135 patients who were recruited in this study. The 135 patients were treated with 212 cycles of cisplatin-based chemotherapy. We observed neutropenia according to G-CSF prophylaxis, chemotherapy schedule (standard or extended cycles), and cumulative dose of cisplatin. Results: Patients who had received standard cycles showed a greater prevalence of neutropenia than those who had received extended cycles; G-CSF prophylaxis, cumulative cisplatin dose, or age had no effect on neutropenia (p >0.05). In patients who had received standard cytotoxic agent cycles, there was no significant association between neutropenia and all patients' characteristics, or the G-CSF level in patients with or without G-CSF prophylaxis, or the cumulative cisplatin dose. However, in patients who had received the extended cycles, patients with a low cumulative dose of cisplatin showed significantly higher absolute neutrophil counts (ANCs) (796/μL) than those who received high doses (796/μL vs. 505/ μL, p=0.029). Conclusions: There was no association between the cumulative dose of cisplatin and neutropenia. This suggests that neutropenia in cisplatin-treated patients may not be dose-dependent.

<EOD> A new approach for the construction of covalently bonded fluorescent sensor arrays: an efficient approach for the determination of metal ions in foods.
The present work describes a new approach for the construction of covalently bonded fluorescent sensor arrays consisting of three aromatic amine-based compounds: 8-hydroxychrysene-1,3-diamine (C1), diaminobiphenyl (C2), and 9-anthracene carboxaldehyde (C3). C1, C2, and C3 were covalently bonded in a 1 : 1 : 1 ratio on a piece of silicon plate with the aid of a γ-ray technique at the initial level of 0.4 mg/cm2. The sensor array was applied to the recognition and determinations of Cu2+, Pb2+, and Cd2+ in food samples with a detection limit of 1.0-1.2 μg/mL (ppm level). A series of fluorescence titration experiments were performed to evaluate the recognition ability of the array sensor toward the corresponding metal ions. To further improve the recognition efficiency, 0.5-1.2 equivalent of each analyte to the covalently bonded sensor array was added. Based on the results of the experiments and the recognition mechanism of the analytes toward the sensor, a recognition mechanism was proposed. This sensor array has great potential for the identification and determination of metal ions. The natural history of patients with distant metastases at the time of presentation with rectal cancer has been well documented. The outcome among these patients is almost invariably poor with some centres achieving a 5 year overall survival in the region of 1.5 per cent. METHODS

RESULTS

<EOD> The human papilloma virus test and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia: an evidence‐based systematic review of the literature by the American society for colposcopy and cervical pathology research and education

Objective: To evaluate evidence supporting the clinical utility of HPV testing to detect and manage cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). Study design: Systematic review. Methods: Medline, Embase, PubMed, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, and bibliographies of retrieved studies were searched from January 1970 to February 2009. We included all studies providing data on the clinical utility of HPV testing to detect or manage CIN and excluded studies reporting only HPV test characteristics. Results: Ninety-five studies met inclusion criteria (33 screening studies, 47 colposcopy studies, 15 surveillance studies). Sixty-four were randomized controlled trials (RCTs), the remainder being prospective cohort or cross-sectional studies. All colposcopy studies were from Europe and compared HPV testing (using hybrid capture-II assay [HC-II]) to colony screening (HPV negative women receive no further investigation). In screening RCTs, pooled sensitivity for detection of CIN2+ ranged from 60.7 (95% confidence interval [CI] 50.7-70.9) to 72.4% (95% CI 57-92.5) and specificity ranged from 94.7-98.8%. In surveillance studies, HPV test sensitivity ranged from 66.7-90.9%, specificity ranged from 60.9-99.6%, and positive and negative predictive values for detection of CIN2+ ranged from 5.4-72.7% and 94.5-56.2%, respectively. In colposcopy studies, 16 RCTs found significantly lower rates of unnecessary biopsies in HPV-positive women versus women screened by colposcopy alone (p B 0.05). Twenty-nine young adult males were given oral, single 250-mg doses of amoxicillin at various time points before surgery and the effect of administration time and dosage on peak, trough, and mean steady-state serum levels was studied. Drug concentrations were observed before and for 10 days after oral, single 500-mg oral doses of amoxicillin before surgery. Peak and trough serum levels were well below therapeutic levels, except in subjects given amoxicillin at approximately 30 min or 60 min before surgery. The mean serum levels reached 4.0 micrograms/ml before surgery, which is just above the lower limit of the accepted therapeutic range of 3.0 micrograms per ml and indicates that the drug may be effective in preventing intraoral bacterial colonization over 10 days. <EOD> Differential effects of the pro-inflammatory adipokines visfatin and leptin on cellular lipolysis in adipose tissue
Abstract Background. Adipose tissue constitutes an important metabolic and immunological organ, which controls the body's energy balance by storing or releasing fatty acids. Adipose tissue is also a site for the action of different adipokines, such as visfatin and leptin. Both visfatin and leptin play a pivotal role in lipid metabolism. In the current study, cellular lipolysis was examined in human adipose tissue explants from obese patients under different in vitro conditions. Methods and Results. We found that in addition to leptin, the adipokine visfatin reduced the lipolytic activity in human adipose tissue. Interestingly, in contrast to lipolysis, the gene expression of the visfatin receptors GPR17 and GPR160 showed a slight increase under visfatin treatment, whereas the expression of the leptin receptor (OB-R) was reduced. Furthermore, visfatin diminished adiponectin gene expression in cultured human adipose tissue explants. Conclusions. Our results indicate that in addition to leptin, visfatin has an insulin sensitizing effect in adipose tissue and may be involved in the modulation of visfatin action (e.g. via the visfatin receptor GPR17). However, further studies are required to determine the possible role of visfatin and its cellular mechanisms in the regulation of cellular lipolysis.<EOD> The Use of a Vacuum Membrane in the Treatment of Congestive Heart Failure.

This study was undertaken to examine the late result in conservatively managed patients with isolated aortic regurgitation. Forty-one patients who had angiographically proven isolated aortic regurgitation (mild, n = 37; moderate, n = 4) over a period of 11 years and had followed conservatively with serial echocardiography and/or radiologic studies were enrolled in the study. These patients were divided into three subgroups: subgroup A included those patients with ejection fraction greater than or equal to 45% (n = 29, age: 44.2 +/- 10.8 years) whom no follow-up for the cardiac events other than the progress of aortic regurgitation was noted; subgroup B included those patients with ejection fraction greater than or equal to 45% (n = 7, age: 45.1 +/- 16.9 years) whom follow-up was noted because of the concern over the possible cardiac complication. The aortic regurgitation progress was not different between the two subgroups A and B. Ejection fraction also showed no statistical change (47% +/- 10%  to 45% +/- 9.3% , p = 0.071). The patients had been followed-up for 19.1 +/- 13.5 years (group A) and 20.2 +/- 15.8 years (group B), respectively. Group C included the patients who developed congestive heart failure because of aortic regurgitation (n = 5, age: 49.6 +/- 11.3 years). 662.output: Transplanted CD34(+) Progenitor Cells Migrate to the Brain, Form Cortical Grafts with Brain Structures, and Improve Motor Function in Mice after Cerebral Ischemia This study shows that CD34(+) cells transplanted into adult mice can engraft, migrate to the brain, form cortical structures, and integrate with brain cell types that were lost or damaged after ischemic injury. Ischemic damage in the adult brain is irreversible and is associated with many of the symptoms of the age-related neurodegenerative disease Alzheimer's disease. Because adult neural progenitor cells are incapable of long-distance migration and differentiation to integrate into neuronal networks to replace lost brain structures, we tested the hypothesis that endogenous bone marrow (BM)-derived CD34(+) progenitor cells in adult mice might be capable of multilineage differentiation, migration, and integration into the postischemic rodent brain. After intratumoral implantation into an adult FVB mouse brain, CD34(+) cells were found to engraft, localize to the brain, and extend processes that anatomically integrate into existing brain circuitry. Transplanted cells differentiated to neuronal, glial, and vascular phenotypes and formed cellular networks and cortical structures that were morphologically and functionally integrated with host gray matter. CD34(+)-treated animals had measurably improved motor function compared with control subjects. These findings reveal that endogenous CD34(+) cells can migrate to the postischemic brain, differentiate, and form structures that are capable of integrating with host neurons to enhance anatomical and functional outcome after brain injury. These studies indicate that CD34(+) cells are good candidate cells for cellular replacement strategies in neurological diseases where endogenous stem cells do not populate the diseased region and where current cell-transplantation methods, which do deliver cells to the brain, have limited efficacy. def calculate_age(patient_note):
    age_years = int(re.match('(\d+) years\.', patient_note).group(1))
    return age_years


def calculate_tobacco_intake(patient_note):
    patient_smoking = re.match('(.+?) smokes', patient_note).group(1).split(". ")
    tobacco_intake = sum(int(c) for c in patient_smoking)
    return tobacco_intake

= Exercise<EOD> Is Tc-99m red blood cell study more sensitive to pulmonary hypertension diagnosis than other blood pool studies?
OBJECTIVE
The authors have examined the accuracy of 99mTc red blood cell perfusion as a means of detecting pulmonary hypertension.


METHODS
In 14 patients with known pulmonary hypertension and mild to moderate pulmonary stenosis or atresia, cardiac output was measured by both transpulmonary thermodilution by RHC (gold standard) and by either Tc-99m red blood cell imaging with standard planar gamma camera imaging or a new technique with a dual head (15-inch) gamma camera and a high counting rate linear phosphenes.


RESULTS
RHC cardiac indices were significantly lower than pulmonary artery thermodilution cardiac indices, although, not significantly different from Tc-99m cardiac indices in 8 of 11 patients. Tc-99m cardiac indices were significantly lower than RHC cardiac indices in each patient, reflecting the small cardiac output in the patient population. The pulmonary artery to aorta time-activity curve (Tc-99m perfusion) ratio was significantly correlated (p < 0.001) with the transpulmonary thermodilution pulmonary artery systolic pressure (TTE PASP) and the mean of the pulmonary artery (Tc-99m perfusion) and aortic transpulmonary thermodilution temperature (Tc-99m PAAT, AoATP) ratios (r = 0.982).


CONCLUSIONS
Tc-99m red blood cell perfusion with a high efficiency linear photoscensor is easily performed, requires no sedation or contrast, and produces no ionizing radiation. The authors suggest Tc-99m red blood cell perfusion be used in clinical conditions where a fast cardiac output measurement is needed, especially when radiation and sedation are contraindicated, when there is insufficient time to measure cardiac output by other methods, or when serial cardiac output measurements are needed

# Exercise Description
After going through this chapter, you should be able to design and train a classifier, a regressor, or a generator, as well as to test the performance of the designed model via cross validations (with a k-fold or leave-one-out cross validation in general).  To be even more confident, you should be able to choose one more rigorous evaluation strategy such as the hold-out test cross validation.  Moreover, you should know how to calculate the receiver operating characteristic curve as well as the area under the curve score of a classifier whose parameters should be fitted by maximizing the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve.

Note that if your data points are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.), then you only need to test the performance of your model using one cross validation or test set.  But, if you have a dependent or correlated data, it may not be appropriate to split your data into a training and test set.  Therefore, you need to prepare a series of training and test data sets.  Thus, cross validation is crucial for machine learning applications that rely on training data sets.


# Introduction
In this chapter, we briefly review how we develop a cross validator. We also present several efficient cross validators, which work efficiently for data sets that have a hierarchical structure such as a medical knowledge database or a collection of medical notes, and we then apply them to a medical knowledge database and a corpus of medical notes.  We then present an overview of a repertoire of cross validators, the most notable being the k-fold, leave-one-out, and holdout test cross validators, and show how to implement them using the R statistical programming language. Finally, we introduce the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) and the area under the curve (AUC) scores, and show how we can use both the training and test data to get the AUC scores.  The rest of this Chapter is dedicated to cross validators.

## Cross Validation
In order to evaluate performance of a classifier accurately, we split the data set for training into training and validation sets.

Title: Lidocaine: Effect of Lidocaine in Chronic Cough


Summary: People cough in order to clear their airways. Most coughs are caused by viruses and settle down by themselves, but some people develop persistent coughing which can be anywhere from 8 weeks to several years. This is called chronic cough. People with chronic cough find the symptom distressing and it can have a major impact on their quality of life. Patients with chronic cough often report a sensation at the back of their throat which makes them feel an urge to cough. There is some evidence that Lidocaine (an anaesthetic used during medical procedures) can suppress a person's cough when given to patients via a nebuliser (a machine that turns liquid into a fine mist).  It is currently unknown whether using a local anaesthetic, such as Lidocaine, in the form of a throat spray would successfully suppress a person's cough. A throat spray would be an easier treatment option in chronic cough patients. Thus, the investigators research aims to compare cough rates, severity and urge to cough scores between Lidocaine throat spray and nebulised Lidocaine.
Inclusion criteria: Inclusion Criteria:
Male and female subjects, age 18 years and over.
History of cough for more than 8 weeks.
Normal chest x ray
Chronic idiopathic cough or chronic cough resistant to treatment of specific triggers.

<EOD> The Evaluation of In Vivo Anti-Mycobacterium tuberculosis Activity of Ethnomedicinally Used Crude Plant Extracts of South Africa

Citation: Matela, S.E.; Olorunsola, A.M.; Matumba, E.; Maputle, S.; Mulaudzi, M.; Mulaudzi, M.M.; Matlaku, N.K.; Olorunsola, B.A.; Chidezie, M.; Sungkarat, S.; et al. The Evaluation of In Vivo Anti-Mycobacterium tuberculosis Activity of Ethnomedicinally Used Crude Plant Extracts of South Africa. Molecules 2021, 26, 614. https://doi.Abstract:Tuberculosis (TB) remains a global health burden. Conventional TB drugs are associated with adverse side effects and the development of drug resistance has resulted in numerous challenges for the treatment of TB. In this study, we assessed the in vivo anti-TB activity of 17 ethnomedicinally used plant extracts. Fifteen plant extracts were prepared using the cold extraction method, whereas the hot extraction method was applied for the remaining two plant extracts. The evaluation of the in vivo anti-TB activity of crude plant extracts was performed using the broth dilution method and results were expressed as the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) which was calculated based on the ratio of the inoculum to extract. The results recorded showed that all the crude plant extracts were able to reduce M. tuberculosis growth when tested at a concentration of 1 mg mL −1 . The in vivo anti-TB activity of these extracts was further confirmed by microscopic observations of colony morphology on nutrient agar plates, while the in silico studies further revealed the presence of some active anti-TB components within the selected plant species. These findings suggest that the plants could be an alternative natural source for further research and development of antimycobacterial drugs.

<EOD> The use of tuberculosis self-testing to complement contact tracing in low tuberculosis incidence countries

To cite: Kim A, Kim C, Lee E, et al. The use of tuberculosis self-testing to complement contact tracing in low tuberculosis incidence countries. BMJ Open 2022;12:e056214.
Introduction Globally, nearly half of tuberculosis (TB) cases are missed. Contact tracing has been a cornerstone of public health practice in TB. However, contact tracing is difficult and costly to conduct. Self-testing to diagnose TB can potentially improve the efficiency, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of contact tracing. The aim of this study was to estimate the potential impact of TB self-testing on TB transmission and costs. Methods We estimated the potential impact of TB self-testing on transmission and costs using a dynamic transmission model and simulated three scenarios: case finding through active case finding and contact tracing, self-testing alone and combined use of TB self-testing and case finding. To examine the cost-effectiveness of TB self-testing, we also used two different costing methods from the societal and health system viewpoints. results In low TB incidence countries, the estimated number of cases to be averted varied depending on the scenario. In the active case finding and contact tracing strategy, 31.01 million cases were estimated to be averted, whereas in the TB self-testing alone strategy, approximately 5.6 million cases were estimated to be averted, and in the combined use of TB self-testing and case finding strategy, 25.75 million cases were estimated to be averted. The societal viewpoint costutility analysis showed that TB self-testing was cost-effective, with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio ranging from £13 898 to £17 984 compared with no intervention or active case finding and contact tracing strategy, respectively. Conclusion Our study provides new evidence on TB self-testing, showing a high potential of reducing missed TB cases under low TB incidence country settings. We believe this novel approach to TB control will contribute to TB ending. Registration number The study protocol was

3.1 Introduction to Neural Networks

Neural networks (NNs), which are a type of Machine Learning, are increasingly being used to learn from and analyze data.

NNs are inspired from the structure and functioning of neurons in the brain and have been widely used in computer vision, speech recognition and natural language processing.

NNs are composed of neurons which are connected to each other to form a network. Each neuron has received input data. The weightings associated with the input data are known as the weights/biases. These neurons are connected to other neurons to form a layer, which is repeated until a loss minimization is achieved.

We will be working specifically within the PyTorch implementation of NNs. NNs are made up of different types of layers:

  • Convolutional layer which is used to extract certain features from data
  • Pooling layer which is used to reduce the dimensionality by reducing the size of certain regions in the neuronal layer
  • Activation layer which introduces a non-linearity into the layers by transforming the weights and input layer into neurons
  • Fully connected or dense layer which transforms the

<EOD> The FDA, Healthcare, and the 2016 Election
The election of Donald Trump as president on November 8, 2016, has left many in the healthcare community feeling uncertain. Although the specifics are still emerging, it is clear that President Elect Trump will take office with a Republican Congress and, together, the two will aim to enact policies that resemble those of the Republican Party platform on which Trump ran. The major question is what does this mean for the future of drug safety and the pharmaceutical industry? On July 16, 2016, the FDA commissioner Dr. Robert Califf made a statement indicating that the FDA’s post-marketing surveillance and monitoring capabilities are weak, and that this was the reason the United States had been unable to detect adverse effects or monitor patterns of safety issues (1). This claim has triggered controversy and concern regarding what Trump has termed ‘‘a broken system,’’ and why, in Dr. Califf’s view, patients have died or have not been adequately protected. Since Trump will be inaugurated in January 2017, a discussion of the potential impact on pharmaceuticals should be examined now, rather than waiting until after January, when the new government is in place and the specifics of the new administration’s plans can be understood. <EOD> A Novel Multiplex Real-Time RT-PCR for Simultaneous Detection of Classical Swine Fever Virus, Pseudorabies Virus, Porcine circovirus Type 2 and Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus

a b s t r a c tThe present study developed a novel multiplex real-time RT-PCR assay to simultaneously detect classical swine fever virus (CSFV), pseudorabies virus (PRV), porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) and porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) and demonstrated its application in clinical diagnostics. A pair of the primers and a probe were designed and used to detect CSFV, while a set of the two primers and one probe were used to detect PRV and another pair of the two primers and one probe were used to detect PCV2 and PRRSV. The designed primer and probe sequences showed high specificity and sensitivity for the four viruses and had no cross-reaction with another 17 swine viruses. For PRV, CSFV, PRRSV and PCV2, the four multiplex real-time RT-PCR were validated to have a limit of detection as low as 10 2 to 10 4 copies and a detection limit corresponding to 5000 to 500 copies per reaction. The results further indicated that the designed primers were able to amplify the standard plasmid and the four standard viral genes. Finally, the newly designed multiplex real-time RT-PCR was examined for its specificity and sensitivity by using 24 clinical samples, all of which were correctly classified. In addition, all the detected viruses showed consistent with the results obtained by the traditional one-time detection of the four viruses and the gold standard method of virus isolation. We hope the developed assay could improve the clinical testing quality of the four viruses with a higher cost-efficiency and shorter detection time.

# Introduction
As a fatal viral infection, classical swine fever virus (CSFV) causes severe economic losses to pig farming industries worldwide [bib_ref]  The classical swine fever

There are various tools (either free or commercial ones) that you can use to make dynamic HTML documents. Our team is going to suggest some of the best ones for your consideration. 
- JSP (Java Server Pages): Sun's own JSP is very popular for web services developed by Java programmers.
- ASP (Active Server Pages): Microsoft's proprietary server-side technology. ASP, like PHP, is very scripted, so does not allow you to make the web page look as you like without knowing some basics of HTML and JAVA syntax. JSP works the same way and JSP is pretty much the closest technology which provides you with that interactive effect. 
- CGI (Common Gateway Interface) Scripts: A script is basically like a text file with very specific structure, which executes just like a program. We do not think this is the best way to make a web page look very interactive. It's very hard to style the text file at will. 
- PHP (Hypertext Processor): If you don't have a big background in computer science, PHP might be the easiest language you can use. But it is very hard to make a dynamic web page with PHP.

<EOD> Cigarette smoke extract suppresses IL-27R-mediated signaling in bronchial epithelial cells.
The interleukin27 receptor (IL-27R) is a receptor complex composed of the IL-27Ra and gp130 subunits. Cigarette smoke extract (CSE) has been reported to reduce the synthesis of IL-27. Herein, we hypothesize that IL-27R-mediated signaling in human bronchial epithelial cells (HBECs) is modulated by CSE. Using murine lymphoid R1-E cells transfected with the human IL-27Rα (hIL-27Rα), we confirmed that IL-27 induced JAK1/STAT1 and JAK1/STAT3 tyrosine phosphorylation and pro-inflammatory cytokine production, thereby demonstrating an IL-27 response. Further, using murine lymphoid cells transfected with the hIL-27Rα and gp130 subunits, we confirmed that IL-27 induced IL-27R-mediated signaling responses. To investigate the role of gp130 in IL-27R-mediated signaling in HBECs, these cells were transfected with the plasmids encoding the hIL-27Ra and gp130 subunits. In the HBECs transfected with these two subunits, IL-27 induced JAK1/STAT1 and JAK1/STAT3 tyrosine phosphorylation, as in the R1-E cells transfected with only the hIL-27Ra. Further, IL-27 induced STAT1 and STAT3 tyrosine phosphorylation, as well as IP-10 and RANTES cytokine production. These results suggested that a human IL-27R complex containing the hIL-27Ra and gp130 subunits is generated in HBECs. <EOD> Association of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection Status with Expression of Immune Cell Molecular Markers
We analyzed tissues of cervical lesions from normal, human papillomavirus (HPV)-related intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), and invasive cancers for the expression of immune-related cell markers as well as HPV viral load, in order to examine the correlation of immune cell influx with cervical lesions development. We included archived cervical cytologies from women without history of HPV or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) of <CIN1 in this study. <EOD> Impact of the COVID-19 infection on patients with pulmonary hypertension: a single centre experience

Purpose Pulmonary hypertension (PH) may be aggravated during the COVID-19 infection but is also associated by higher morbidity and mortality of COVID-19. The association between PH and COVID-19 infection is still not fully determined. Methods and patients We enrolled all patients with PH who were diagnosed between July and October 2020. Clinical, demographic, laboratory data, and the follow-up outcomes were retrospectively collected and analysed. Results Thirty-three patients were enrolled in the study. Fifteen patients were tested positive with COVID-19 and died after the infection. There were no significant differences between the COVID-19-positive and COVID-19-negative group in demographic data except diabetes and lower extremity oedema. The median baseline mPAP at the time of the out-door visitation was 30 and 32 mmHg (p = 0.7) in COVID-19 positive group and COVID-19 negative group, respectively. In the COVID-19-negative group, the median baseline 6MWD was 257 m (range 101-374m), and the 24-month mPAP increased from 29 to 36 mmHg (p = 0.03). In the COVID-19-positive group, the median baseline 6MWT was 248 m (range 101-331m), and the 24-month mPAP increased from 35 to 47 mmHg (p = 0.001). Conclusion COVID-19 infection affects the 6MWT and the mPAP significantly more in PH patients than in controls. Patients with diabetes and oedema should be more carefully evaluated in the COVID-19 pandemic.Keywords Pulmonary hypertension · COVID-19 · 6MWT · BNP · COVID-19 infection · COVID-19 infection and complications

# Conclusion
In this paper, a novel framework has been proposed to assess clinical trial eligibility. Unlike state-of-the-art methods, the proposed method does not use a complicated process for feature generation. We only use a simple set of inclusion and exclusion factors as raw features for clinic trial eligibility assessment. In addition, the most unique aspect of the proposed method is it provides a decision-making scheme based on a combination of multiple clinical trial notes and the inclusion and exclusion factors. To assess a given clinical trial eligibility decision, the proposed method generates a distribution function of eligible scores by a number of previous patient notes. We utilize the function to evaluate the eligibility based on the patient note.


# Conclusion
The proposed method allows to easily incorporate newly generated trials by creating appropriate distributions of the assessing scores to predict eligibility in real-time. Experiment results on clinical trial assessment data show that the proposed framework is robust.

# Related Work
Most state-of-the-art methods to assess clinical trial eligibility are based on a complex process involving feature generation, feature selection, and the decision-making strategies. Let's go over what has been discussed regarding the task of recruitment criteria. Your task is to check the patient not according to trial-level eligibility, but rather into categories of recruitment criteria. As we went over, recruitment criteria can be assessed as binary as well as trinary. Binary means, that a research subject either does or does not fulfill the criteria. If they do, the first part of the recruitment criteria can be denoted with the number 1. If they do not fulfill a specific criterion, this is marked with the number 0. Trinary means a research subject can fulfill no, one, or multiple criteria. The assessment has the same structure as binary scoring, but it has 3 possible values instead of 2. The number 1 marks the criteria is fulfilled, the number 0 marks the criteria is not fulfilled, and the number 2 marks that multiple criteria are fulfilled.

# Discussion

   1. We did not consider how a model should be optimized for a
      specific clinical trial. Since a model usually has many different parameters, one may wonder which parameters to
      optimize. There is no one-size-fits-all approach. Depending on the goal,
      a model and model parameters can be optimized using different criteria or metrics. For instance, a model could be optimized by its predictive power (e.g. ROC AUC) or the goodness of fit to patient note and/or the clinical trial inclusion criteria. In addition, different types of data might need to be optimized: patient notes could be optimized in terms of prediction power while clinical trial eligibility criteria could be optimized in terms of the number of false negatives and false positives. We hope that this paper will inspire more discussions related to the choice of optimization metrics and the criteria to optimize parameters. 
  
    2. Even though the 2016 Drug Repurposing Competition focused on
      drug-disease pairs, any task that required judgments could benefit from an approach like ours. For instance, another 2016 dataset contained judgments about a particular patient note and the symptoms of the patient. A similar framework could be applied to this dataset.

PoTS is often comorbid with primary sleep disorders but sleep data is relatively limited and largely collected from PoTS patients. The aim of this study was to expand our knowledge about sleep profiles in PoTS-like population, particularly when evaluated using polysomnography data. We recruited 13 PoTS-like and 18 healthy subjects; PoTS-like group was identified using questionnaire data (i.e., PoTS-like symptoms). # Cases introduction
Laparoscopic transumbilical cholecystectomy (LTC) is a common procedure to remove gallbladder with gallstones. This technique has been successfully used for simple cholelithiasis and other conditions. But this is a rare practice of using TUs to perform laparoscopic nephrectomy, thyroidectomy, gastrectomyand the treatment of gallolithiasis. In this technique, there is no need to separate the gallbladder from the gallbladder bed or make a subumbilical incision; therefore, it is more advantageous than other laparoscopic techniques and patients are able to return to work earlier.
The gallstone remains after cholecystectomy is a rare complication that, in many cases, requires conversion to laparoscopic cholecystectomy and is associated with high costs, extended stay at the hospital as well as increased risk of morbidity. On the other hand, it is possible to perform a laparoscopic or laparotomy procedure in order to remove the gallstones.
Intraoperative ultrasonography (IOUS) is a valuable tool for the diagnosis and follow-up of different pathologies, including the identification of stones, neoplasm, hematoma, fluid collections, etc. It is a technique that avoids performing new exploration and decreases the rate of multiple exploration. Despite the low-frequency use of IOUS in laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it can be a helpful tool with several advantages, such as quick

Two groups of subjects were studied: (i) volunteers who were non-smokers, non-consumers of alcohol, and living in a city with air pollution that could be considered a factor of oxidation; (ii) volunteers who were physically active, non-smokers, non-consumers of alcohol, and living in a green zone. <EOD> Hedgehog signaling in early tooth development
Hedgehog (hh) signaling plays pivotal roles during dental development and adult tooth homeostasis. hh‐pathway activation in mesenchymal cells leads initially to their differentiation toward odontoblasts, and later to ameloblast precursors, with a subsequent role in controlling ameloblast differentiation. Notably, hh‐signaling is required for the generation of Hertwig’s epithelial root sheath, as its inactivation causes impairment in crown‐root patterning, and leads to tooth reduction and impaired cellular renewal. At the dental pulp, hedgehog ligands are required to protect dental pulp stem cells. hh‐pathway components are also found to be deregulated in several oral disorders, such as oral squamous cell carcinomas. ## 1.1.1  Criterion -Age -

We first think about the patient's age. If the patient is older than 18, the patient cannot participate in a clinical trial (not the clinical trial for which we are writing Trial-level eligibility).

    * 
    * However, if a subject is an adult and has the capacity to decide, they can participate in a clinical trial for which the inclusion criteria allow adult subjects.

    * Please note that this is quite important because, in general, a trial can be classified as a Phase 1, 2, 3, and 4 trial. In Phase 1 trials, it is not common for adults to be subjects. In Phase 2 trials, most trials except Phase 2a trials are conducted for adults. If the clinical trial that we analyze as a problem in this tutorial is defined based on its Phase and its inclusion criteria, it means that it is a Phase 2 trial. Phase 2 trials (typically) include subjects aged 18 or older. If the age of the subject falls outside this range, he or she cannot participate in the clinical trial.

[/DEP]

If the patient is male, the patient can participate in the clinical trial.

##[TUTORIAL] Data Types

Here is the description.
Different data types in data.table  and dplyr  packages.

### String

It is very useful data type in R language. We use it to represent variable or text data such as column names.

### Num

It is very useful data type in R language. We use it to represent numerical or tabular data such as in the age column which age of subject is shown.

### Logical

It is very useful data type in R language. We use it to represent one or zero logical results, for example 0 or 1 which male or female. One column such as `patient_gender` in the example data will be transformed or shown by logical data type.

In data.table, use the following commands to extract all subjects of different genders:

      patient_id gender_count

1        0       false 
2        2       true 
3        5       true 
4        7       false 

In dplyr, use the following commands to extract all subjects of different genders:
>>> 1:sum(gender == "male") 5
3:sum(gender == "female") 4

### Factor

It is very useful data type in R language. We can choose data from different set of categories by data or variable type. It is different than the list. It is just another name of list, one row can have more than one data or variable category and another row can have a specific category.

### Date

It is very useful data type in R language. It can be used as a date or date group variable in R.

<EOD> Rheumatoid factor enhances the pro-inflammatory cytokine response of monocytes to toll-like receptor 2 and 4 ligands

The presence of rheumatoid factor (RF) in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) correlates with clinical signs of the disease. To address the role of RF in the local tissues, we analyzed the influence of IgG human monoclonal RF on the response of monocytes isolated from healthy subjects to toll-like receptor 2 (TLR2) or 4 (TLR4) ligands in the presence of the intracellular inflammasome signaling inhibitor glybenclamide (GBC). The presence of human monoclonal RF enhanced production of the inflammatory cytokines interleukin-1β (IL-1β), interleukin-6 and interleukin-8 in monocytes stimulated by lipopolysaccharide, Pam3CSK4 and zymosan. Cytokine production was higher in the presence of higher concentrations of RF preparation and higher TLR ligand concentration. This increase was dependent on caspase-1 enzymatic activity. The levels of nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) p65 subunit and monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1/CCL2) mRNA in monocytes were higher upon stimulation with ligands and RF. GBC diminished both RF-mediated increase in MCP-1/CCL2 mRNA and concentration of NF-κBp65 subunit in cytoplasm while it did not block MCP-1/CCL2 protein release. Our results suggest that RF may potentiate cytokine and chemokine production via IL-1β and NF-κB signaling induced by TLR ligands.

<EOD> Anatomic Variants and Angiographic Findings in Chronic Middle Meningeal Artery Occlusion
Background and Purpose— Chronic occlusion of the middle meningeal artery is an infrequent entity that can be caused by traumatic carotid dissection. The anatomy of the affected area as well as the angiographic characteristics of the area may vary in patients with this condition. Methods— We present the radiologic findings in 4 patients (age, 23–62 years; male/female, 3/1) with middle meningeal artery occlusions and discuss the possible mechanisms of the condition. Results— All 4 patients had a history of trauma or carotid intimal injury. Of these, 3 had a history of an extradural hematoma. In all patients, the occluded middle meningeal artery was a long trunk vessel, whereas the ipsilateral supraclinoid branches were either hypoplastic or absent. The supraclinoid branches supplied the ipsilateral anterior choroidal artery in all of our patients. Conclusions— The anatomy of the affected area showed consistency. Objective: To test the effects of a 12-week supervised exercise program on pain intensity and kinesiophobia in men and women with subacromial shoulder pain. Design: A single-arm, prospective study of consecutive enrolment with pre- and post-intervention assessments. Setting: Exercise physiology laboratory. Subjects: Twenty-eight men and women (50.9 ± 11.1 years) with subacromial shoulder pain. Assessment of Risk of Bias: No information on blinding of the patients or personnel was reported throughout the study. It is therefore possible that the study was prone to high risks of performance bias. Each participant performed individually prescribed exercises under constant and individualized progressive supervision. Main outcome measures: Pain intensity and kinesiophobia were assessed before and after the intervention. Changes in aerobic capacity and isokinetic muscle strength were also measured. Methodological quality assessment: The 27-item Physiotherapy Evidence Database scale was used to assess the quality of the study. Results: Individualized training programs comprised a series of progressive exercises to improve rotator scapular muscle strength and joint mobility, upper extremities mobility, and aerobic training. Campylobacter jejuni, NCTC 11351, was studied in suspensions of skim milk or milk with trypticase phosphate broth (TPB) or TPB supplemented with 1% defibrinated sheep blood (B-TPB). The pH declined slowly in milk to approximately 5.0, 4.0, and 2.5, respectively, and the temperature rose to approximately 7, 12, and 24 degrees C, respectively, before bacterial numbers began to decline. When the suspensions were held at 8 degrees C, the number of bacteria/ml began to decline after an initial 1-h delay. Suspensions with skim milk or milk with TPB and those with milk with B-TPB had half-lives of approximately 7 and 5 h at 8 degrees C, respectively (corresponding to log loss rates of 0.434 and 0.632 h-1). Suspensions with milk containing trypticase and B-TPB had a more rapid initial decline in colony numbers than with milk containing TPB but a slower decline at later times. The effect of the presence of milk protein alone (casein) was determined in milk with TPB. After a lag of approximately 5 h, the decline in counts/ml began at pH 7.5. At various pH values, the decline in counts was biphasic, with an initial 4-h exponential phase followed by a second phase with a linear decline in counts of 0.354 h-1. <EOD> The association of high‐dose irradiation and TNFα immunotherapy in glioblastoma is associated with increased levels of circulating miR‐21
High‐dose radiotherapy (RT) is often combined with bio‐ and immunotherapy to fight tumor recurrence. Irradiation induces DNA damage, increases tumor antigen expression, thus favoring RT synergism with immunotherapy (imT). The release of cellular material and microRNAs (miR) by irradiated cancer cells can modify the tumor microenvironment (TME). The main aim of this work was to evaluate the immunological and miR changes caused by irradiation of malignant glioma (MG) cells in order to obtain information that would be useful to guide combination immunotherapy. Glioblastoma cells from patients with tumors having MG isocitrate dehydrogenase (MG IHD) IDH1 mutation (GBM‐IDH) were irradiated with 1000 cGy γ‐rays. Twenty‐two tumor‐associated miRs were quantified at intervals during irradiation by qRT‐PCR; the relative amounts of the analyzed miRs were normalized to human miR‐16. Immune and tumor‐associated markers were also quantified. Irradiation induced several changes in miR levels, with a significant increase in miR‐21. These changes were accompanied by an augmentation in the expression of the immune and tumor‐associated markers tumor necrosis factor‐α (TNFα), interleukin‐10 (IL‐10), and programmed death‐ligand 1 (PD‐L1), in addition to a decrease in tumor necrosis factor‐related apoptosis‐induced ligand (TRAIL). Pretreatment of MG with irradiation in combination with TNFα immunotherapy induced marked increases in tumor necrosis, infiltration of inflammatory immune cells, and levels of miR‐21, miR‐34a, and miR‐101, and decreases in tumor necrosis factor‐related apopt

<EOD> The Role of Arachidonic Acid-Dependent Cytosolic Phospholipase A2 in Skeletal Muscle Fiber-Type Switching

Skeletal muscle is highly adaptive to alteration of contractile activity, being capable of changing the proportion of fibers in a process involving complex cellular and molecular events known as muscle fiber type switching. Mammalian skeletal muscle fibers may be classified as Types I, IIa, IIx (also known as IIb), or IIb/d, based on the predominant sarcomeric structure, enzymatic activity, and functional properties of the skeletal muscle fibers. The type I fiber is characterized by a slower contraction velocity and lower capability to generate force, which is associated with a greater mitochondrial density, higher endurance, and glycogen accumulation, which allows this type of muscle fiber to be predominant in endurance exercise. On the other hand, the type IIx/d is characterized by a greater capacity to generate force but is slower in contraction velocity, a feature that allows this type of muscle fiber to dominate in maximal force tasks. In this scenario, Type I and IIx/d fibers comprise the majority of myofibers existing in untrained rodents, whereas the proportion of IIa fibers is significantly lower. However, the composition of muscle fibers can be altered by endurance or strength training, which can shift the fiber composition from IIa/x/d to IIa/slow. Although an increase in IIx/d fibers was not observed, the switch from a mainly IIx/d fiber composition to IIa/slow fibers was accompanied by an increase in fast glycolytic muscle activity. In addition to the shift in muscle phenotype, endurance and strength training may influence metabolism and lead to a significant remodeling of fiber composition, which can be accomplished through the transcriptional regulation of several genes related to either fast (IIx) and slow (IIa) muscle fibers, as well as hypertrophy signaling pathways. Despite the fact that different animal models and training schemes may change the exact effects on muscle fiber content, the understanding of molecular pathways that occur

<EOD> The Use of MRI in the Diagnosis and Staging of Lung Cancer

Imaging is important in lung cancer care, both at diagnosis and in follow-up. This review focuses on the role of MRI in these phases of lung cancer management. MRI has a high potential value in lung cancer due to its ability to generate both high-resolution anatomic and functional images. Contrast enhanced MRI shows the presence, nature and degree of any mediastinal or extrathoracic disease more accurately than either computed tomography (CT) or positron emission tomography (PET), which are more adequate for nodule characterization. MRI therefore appears to be a powerful non-ionising lung cancer imaging modality. Nonetheless, we should not forget that MRI's greatest strengths are still limited to the thoracic region, so in clinical practice it may only be used in a complementary fashion to CT and PET. Moreover, the implementation of MRI in large scale studies is difficult as the high cost and low availability of MRI prevents the possibility of this modality being available in most centers and healthcare systems.KeywordsMagnetic resonance imaging; tumor-node-metastasis staging; lung cancer . MRI pulmonary examination. Highresolution pulmonary MRI sequence (a) and coronal oblique respiratory end-exhalation phase obtained using the single-slice breath hold technique on a 1.5 Tesla clinical MR unit (b). The images on the left side (a) and right side (b) correspond to different lung bases. In image (b), the patient is breathing exhaling (arrow indicates the diaphragm position). The T2-WI sequence is performed in the coronal orientations in order to obtain full coverage of the entire lung. T2-WI images display intrinsic morphological information of the lung parenchyma related to the presence of edema or pneumonia.

# Introduction

## Imaging in lung cancer
With an incidence of 1.5 million cases per year, lung cancer is the most common form of cancer worldwide. This high number of cases is the result of the strong association between tobacco consumption and lung cancer, which is the most common cause of death from cancer in Europe, North America and Japan.

## [BALLOON_KYPHOPLATY]. A balloon kyphoplasty is an invasive procedure that is usually used to treat broken vertebral (spinal) bones when other treatments have not helped the pain.
A balloon kyphoplasty is an invasive procedure that is usually used to treat broken vertebral bones when other treatments have not helped the pain.
In a typical procedure, a pedicle is approached under image guidance. A high-pressure balloon is typically used to create a space that is then filled with bone cement.

This work also provides the following additional features to facilitate data loading, formatting, and output.

- It provides commands for loading data in CSV format from a specified folder.

## Installation instructions
To install `clinical` on your system, go to your Bash or Powershell Terminal, cd to where the source code of `clinical` is saved (i.e., `clinica.jl`), and enter the following:

```julia
using Pkg package=https://github.com/diegomorgado/clinical.jl.git
Pkg.update()
Pkg.dev(Package("Julia Package Manager"))
InstallDirectory()
```

To install in your Julia 1.0 installation: 

```julia
include("./clinical.jl")
```

Or, in Julia 1.1, in its JuliaPacks installation: 

```julia
using PackageRequirements.clinical.jl install
```

This module is also available as a `Pkg.clone` package, meaning it will be automatically updated for you. Install with:

```julia
Pkg.clone("diegomorgado/clinica.Clone.jl")
```
You can now install it with: 

```julia
using Pkg.Package(Package("Julia Package Manager"))
install_github("diegomorgado/clinica.Clone.jl")
```

- Step 1: Avoid the `if ` statement. Don't forget, R marks code objects, not individual lines of text.
Step 2: Always consider the length of text. 
Step 3: Make the code read more effectively. 
Step 4: Consider the output format. The input_data and output_data sections are written by the user at the beginning of the script but after reading and executing the text, they will be overwritten by the script. So when a user loads the script, the script will be used to parse the input_data and save it in a variable which the user has created at the beginning of the script and output_data is an empty string. In addition to making the code more readable, R takes the length of input_data and output_data (which will be overwritten by the script) into account when saving them in variables. Also, when the input and output are very large, they will be truncated by the system after a certain length. In line 13 in "Text_output.R", the output for the variable "Clinical trial" is truncated. This issue can be solved by making an empty vector with the same length of input_data in line 14 in "Text_output.R".
- Step 5: Check the last row of input_data. It contains the patient information like sex, gestational age and birth weight.
- Step 6: Make note of how to parse the patient note.

3. If the patient does not match the inclusion criteria or matches one or more exclusion criteria, report 0: trial-level ineligible.

<EOD> Differential effects of in situ and systemic administration of estradiol on the expression of oxytocin receptors

Estradiol (E2) plays an important role in regulating sexual behavior in vertebrates. In the reproductive system and in the hypothalamus-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis, oxytocin is an important neurotransmitter that facilitates E2 action. Interestingly, sex-specific differences in the expression levels of oxytocin receptors (OXTRs) have been documented in several organs, including the brain. In zebrafish, in situ hybridization (ISH) of oxt and oxtr genes revealed sexual dimorphism in oxt and oxtr expression in the brain, whereas sexual dimorphism was not observed for in situ (IS) ISH of agarose sections for brain and heart. The present study used ISH to characterize oxtr gene expression in the brain of wild type and homozygous zebrafish mutant line fshr (follicle-stimulating hormone receptor knockout), which do not have gonads and circulating sex steroids to evaluate whether OXTR expression is induced by direct action of E2 in the brain. The results showed that IS E2 treatment, but not systemic (ip) E2 treatment, decreased oxtr IS expression in the brain of the homozygous fshr mutants, while increased OXTR expression was observed in the ovary in response to systemic E2 administration. In the intestine, brain, and heart, IS E2 treatment increased oxtr ISH, whereas systemic administration of E2 decreased oxtr ISH. The present study, therefore, suggests that the effects of E2 on OXTR expression levels in a sexually dimorphic-organ, such as the brain, may involve direct interaction with the OXTR in the target organ and that the effects of systemic E2 administration on OXTR expression levels may be indirect and require the presence of the HPG axis, probably by hormonal feedback.
