<EOD> Effects of Clinically Relevant Stimuli on Pain, Disability, and Quality of Life in Myofascial Pain Patients: A Randomized Clinical Trial

Objective. To evaluate the effectiveness of interventions consisting of stimuli designed to clinically treat patients with myofascial pain (MP), in addition to the routine rehabilitation prescribed for the treatment of this condition. Material and methods. Patients with MP (N = 56) and painful conditions outside the myofascial referral zone (N = 10) were randomly assigned to three groups: routine rehabilitation only (Group I), routine rehabilitation plus cognitive motor training, massage therapy, and hydrotherapy (Group II), and routine rehabilitation plus iontophoresis (Group III). The outcome measures included a numerical pain rating scale, pressure pain threshold, goniometry, pressure algometry, disability, and quality of life. Participants were evaluated at baseline and after 6 weeks of therapy. The Wilcoxon and Kruskal-Wallis tests were used to compare the groups at baseline. The Friedman test was used to compare the measures of the three groups before and after the rehabilitation program, and the Mann-Whitney test was used to compare the differences between groups when necessary. Results. All groups showed a significant reduction in pain intensity after treatment. Differences in the pressure pain threshold were only significant among Group I. Groups II and III had similar decreases in disability and increases in quality of life. For the secondary outcome measure, Group III showed more improvements in active motion than Group I. Conclusions. Interventions designed to treat MP are effective in inducing pain relief, improving quality of life, and reducing disability. Iontophoresis, however, had advantages over the other two interventions regarding gains in active range of motion.

<EOD> Bacterial phyloclusters are associated with community structure and stability of the human gut microbiome

The human gut is in a state of continuous flux yet the microbial community maintains remarkably high stability at the species level. It is unclear how the community's species diversity is maintained under stressful and changing environment. Using longitudinal profiles from >900 samples collected over 2 years from 7 healthy subjects, we investigated how microbial taxa interact at different time-scales to form self-sustaining modules (clusters) that maintain species diversity. At the highest time scale, the gut community is largely dominated by 93 bacterial phyloclusters, each comprised of taxa that show co-clustering in time. We found that the gut microbiome is structurally robust with respect to the loss of phylotypes-the community is more resilient to the loss of less abundant phyloclusters. The microbiome can withstand the loss of taxonomic groups within phylotypes up to a ratio of 50-70%, where the community recovers quickly. This microbiome resilience allows the community to maintain an intrinsic microbial diversity through a series of co-clustering states. The community evolves towards states with higher relative abundances of health-promoting phyloclusters within time windows (2-14 days) of clinical states such as bowel preparation or antibiotics intake. Notably, the community also tends to regenerate with a microbiome profile with lowered relative abundance of these healthpromoting bacteria soon after the clinical state is resolved. As a result, the entire community is better buffered for potential perturbations during this recovery period. Our results show that the gut microbiome community is a complex self-organizing system that responds to stressful events and recovers with new structures of varying diversity (and stability) depending on the nature and duration of perturbations.

# Introduction
The human gut microbiota is a complex system comprised of trillions of microbes in symbiotic relationships with their host. Understanding how the community maintains a diverse composition of microorganisms and remains stable in health is a challenging problem [bib_ref]  Dynamics of

You are already aware of some of the factors that allow someone to participate in a clinical study, such as those regarding "inclusion" and "exclusion". Here, you should be able to differentiate those factors that enable participants to be involved in a trial, and evaluate the eligibility of a patient for a particular clinical trial (Trial-level eligibility). The patient has been diagnosed with NEC, which was treated according to the "inclusion criteria" for many trials (Inclusion criteria). The patient is a preterm infant, which is an "inclusion" factor that may not be applicable to all patients in a trial, but is a factor that does not "exclude" patients from participating in trials. In terms of an age restriction, it is not an "exclusion" factor, as clinical trials including infant participants are usually not required to specify an upper age limit. Instead, age restrictions may include the minimum and maximum age of the target population, i.e., the age that applies according to the trial's enrolment criteria. For further assessment of a patient's eligibility, additional information needs to be checked. In the case presented in the trial note, the patient has not yet completed breastfeeding and was recently on oral feedings. These patient characteristics are both "exclusion" factors in clinical trials. As shown in the clinical trial note, the patient has a history of multiple blood product transfusions, including red blood cell (RBC) products. This type of transfusion is considered an "exclusion" factor from the trial. In line with the trial's inclusion criteria, this patient lacks pre-operative feeding, and had an upper gastrointestinal (GI) ultrasound performed at the patient's previous hospital (exclusion factor related to diagnostic tests). To conclude, this patient may be excluded from the trial (exclusion criterion) or included in the trial, as long as a feeding test with enteral feeding is done in the trial site.

In the following subsection, we give a definition of a clinical trial note as well as the definitions for our input variables.

### Clinical Trial Note
We adopt the definition of clinical trial note proposed by [ECHO-7]. A clinical trial note is a document that contains information about the eligibility for a clinical trial, i.e., eligibility criteria, for individual patients. These patients may vary in terms of age, gender, medical condition, ethnicity, prior medical history, etc.

#### Eligibility criteria
From [Garvin 2017]: \em{Eligibility criteria are the characteristics or features required in a subject to be enrolled in the trial. They may be age-related, genderdependent, ethnicity based, or may be related to a subjects' medical history.}

#### Investigators note
[GINA-3] proposed the following definition for an investigator note. An investigator note is an institutional document listing the investigational staff of an academic institution for conducting clinical trials. A note contains information about the contact details of the clinical trial staff.

### Definition of Input Variables 

From [ECHO-7]:
\em{Patient data refers to the set of variables that describe the status of a patient during an encounter with the health system.
Medical record refers to the set of variables that describe the status of a patient before an encounter with the health system. In this study, a medical record is a note that records information about a patient's eligibility for a clinical trial. These notes may vary in terms of age, gender, medical condition, ethnicity, prior medical history, and so on.
Clinical trial note refers to the set of variables that describe the status of a patient during an encounter with the health system. In this study, a clinical trial note is a text note in which the patient's eligibility for a clinical trial is recorded. To this end, the information includes information about a given clinical trial (e.g., disease type, condition, duration, type of participants), investigators, and a patient (e.g., patient IDs including unique IDs, name, age, and gender, and condition of patients, such as trauma, surgery, stroke, etc.).}

<EOD> Increased expression of the human androgen receptor by a human monocytic cell line in response to 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate.
Expression of the androgen receptor (AR) and of the androgen-controlled target PSA (prostate-specific antigen) in prostate tissue and in leukaemic cell lines is well documented. Prostate cancer and monocytic leukaemia are both neoplasms which exhibit increased metastatic potential, probably as a result of the AR. The aim of this study was to investigate AR expression in the HL-60 monocytoid leukaemic cellline before and with increasing differentiation towards the monocytic lineage induced with 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (TPA). Protein analysis was performed with a P1-derived antibody recognizing the AR, followed by Western blotting and quantitative radioimmunoassay. AR steady state RNA levels were measured by RT-PCR. Before differentiation, 2.6 +/- 0.6 AR molecules were present in each HL-60 cell. The cellular content of the AR, detected during HL-60 differentiation with TPA into monocytes or monocyte-like cells, increased 21+/-0.6 fold on day 5 after TPA treatment, followed by a further decline towards undetectable levels on day 9. No increase was found in the expression of the AR in HL-60 cells with other differentiating agents such as alpha-interferon, retinoic acid or dimethylsulphoxide. AR mRNA, detected by RT-PCR, increased significantly by the 3rd day after TPA addition, consistent with the time of increased AR protein in the differentiated cells. The androgen-stimulated synthesis of PSA in HL-60 cells was also found to increase to a higher steady state level after treatment with the monocyte-differentiating agent TPA. This finding adds another possible avenue of investigation to the effects of the AR in the differentiation of human cell line

<EOD> Long‐term treatment of patients with non‐surgical and non‐radiotherapy refractory lupus pneumonitis with corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a multisystem autoimmune disease. Pulmonary involvement may occur in up to 20% of patients.1 Lupus pneumonitis (LP) comprises only up to 3% of all interstitial lung abnormalities in patients with SLE.2 LP usually manifests with dyspnea, dry cough and hypoxemic respiratory failure. It is thought to be immune complex‐mediated and is generally a diffuse lymphocytic infiltration. Pulmonary parenchymal manifestations may be secondary to a pulmonary vasculitis (vasculitis in the form of necrotizing intra‐alveolar capillaritis). Pathology of LP includes interstitial infiltrates of lymphocytes, plasmacytes and granulocytes, interlobular septa thickening and occasional areas of alveolar hemorrhage.3 There are not well‐defined treatment recommendations for LP. Anticomplement therapy, cyclophosphamide, and corticosteroids have been used,1–4 with little supportive objective evidence of benefit. Herein, we report the long‐term successful treatment of two patients with SLE who developed LP. <EOD> The Role of Social Media During the Outbreak of COVID-19 Pandemic: A Cross-Sectional Study in the Population of Saudi Arabia

Purpose Although social media platforms are considered as mainstream media, evidence for the role of social media during the pandemic is lacking. The aim of this study is to assess the role of social media, and explore its impact on anxiety, fear, trust, and compliance during the pandemic. Methods A cross-sectional study in Saudi Arabia using an online-based questionnaire on the socio-demographic information and social media (SM) were distributed in June-September 2020. The level of pandemic-related anxiety and fear, trust in information, and compliance were assessed. Logistic regression models were used to evaluate factors associated with compliance. Results Data were gathered from 969 participants. Only 30.49% of the subjects agreed on the reliability of available information. Social media was considered to be the main source of information (58.9%); however, only 38.5% of the participants agreed to the level of trust they received from the SM platforms. The SM were considered the main source of COVID-19 updates for 77.5%, however, only 46.50% agreed on the accuracy of the information provided. The higher rate of compliance was among individuals older than 50 years and was 64.3% trustworthy of the SM, and 80.2% were afraid while using SM frequently. Conclusion Our results confirmed the positive impact of SM in disseminating the precautions, prevention measures, and up-to-date information regarding disease control and treatment. However, it was identified that many individuals did not trust the SM platforms, which hindered their role to inform and educate the population about the disease and available measures. This study emphasized the urgent need to enhance the role of SM in crisis communication. In this respect, the main recommendation is to develop a national social media policy to ensure the quality of the disseminated information and guarantee the reliability of online sources.Publisher's Note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations

# Introduction
SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease with various clinical manifestations. Clinical heterogeneity of SLE is mainly a product of variations in immunologic pathogenesis. Several lines of evidence show that T cells and antibodies play a critical role in SLE. Indeed, anti-DNA autoantibodies in SLE belong to the IgG class, and CD4+ T cells play a key role in the expansion of autoantibodies. Therefore, therapeutic modulations in T-cell proliferation have shown some promise in SLE. Recent studies have demonstrated that, in addition to cytokine stimulated proliferation, T cells can proliferated independent of cytokine stimulation through immune complex presentation, costimulatory molecules or antigen presentation.
Rhematoid arthritis (RA) is a multi-systemic autoimmune disease characterized by persistent inflammatory synovitis with a high degree of mortality and morbidity. Proliferation of synoviocytes and infiltration to the synovium of CD4+ T cells and macrophages, is directly responsible for RA. In patients with RA, a considerable number of CD4 T cells are activated. Therefore, understanding of the T cell hyperactivation in autoimmune diseases is needed to understand the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases and to offer novel targets for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. Recent studies have demonstrated that T lymphocytes are involved in immune suppression of RA. This suppressive effect is a CD4+CD25+ T lymphocyte dependent mechanism and is mediated by a TGF-b-producing CD4+ CD25+ T lymphocyte subset. Therefore, targeting the suppressive CD4+CD25+ T cells may help in the treatment of autoimmune diseases.
However, the mechanisms by which inhibitory signals modulate T cell responses remain incompletely understood, as do the role of costimulation in controlling auto-reactive T cells activation. In this study we will investigate role of DcR3-induced T cell activation

## [P3] Conclusion and Discussion
Our goal is to develop a general tool, i.e., eligibility tool, to determine the eligibility of a patient for a clinical trial.  The method should use the information and clinical data of a patient note. We designed a neural network with 3 layers (196/196/22 layers) and 22 hidden units that could predict the eligibility.

To identify the clinical trials and patient notes, we implemented the following method. By utilizing information from the clinical trial registration websites and clinical data, the network first predicted the target, i.e., either yes or no, of a clinical trial as `Target: yes` or Trial-level eligibility: `1) Would refer this patient for this clinical trial` to determine the eligibility of the patient, i.e., `patient-level eligibility: 2) Yes/Trial-level eligibility: 1) Yes/Target: Yes/Trial-level eligibility: 1) Yes`;  or `patient-level eligibility: 1) No/Trial-level eligibility: 2) No/Target: No/Trial-level eligibility: 2) Yes`; or `patient-level eligibility: 1) No/Trial-level eligibility: 2) No/Target: No/Trial-level eligibility: 2) No`. Because patients might not be eligible to the clinical trial, the network also predicted the patient-level eligibility for the clinical trial. If the eligibility was `1) No`, the program would be terminated. We also added a feature that if the trial had a factor which was absent on the patient, the eligibility of the patient would be always `1) No` regardless of other factors in the patient.

To evaluate the performance of the method, we used two patient notes from the lupus clinics. The first patient was highly likely to be eligible to the trial while the second patient was likely to be ineligible. ## RQ3: How to run the `get_cmap()` in `R`?
* The code for running the `get_cmap()` in `RQ_HW_06_P_3` by means of `purrr::map_dfr` function.
```R
get_cmap() %>%
  map_df('purrr::reduce', ., `get_cmap`::`~.*`)
```

This function returns the cmap and will print the column name and row location of each cmap. 

* The code for running the `get_cmap()` in `RQ_HW_06_P_3_01_RQ3_A1` by means of `rbind()` function.
```R
get_cmap() %>%
  lapply(rbind, dim(`get_cmap`))
```

* `purrr::map_dfr` functions is a convenient way to apply a function to a dataset of different structures.
* The columns used to apply the function in the code were shown in the code of `RQ_HW_06_P_3`.
```R
df(get_cmap()) %>%
  lapply(function(x) lapply(get_cmap(), FUN = function(y) reduce(.x, y)))
```

* The code for running the `get_cmap()` in `RQ_HW_06_P_3_02_RQ3_D1` by means of `mapply` function.
```R
sapply(get_cmap(), `get_cmap`::~.  + `get_cmap`::~. )
```

<EOD> .
OBJECTIVE
To evaluate the clinical effects of lateral window decompression through the lateral orbital wall for the treatment of progressive proptosis due to thyroid ophthalmopathy.


METHODS
A total of 36 patients with progressive proptosis due to thyroid ophthalmopathy were treated with lateral window decompression through lateral orbital wall. A 4 cm incision was made in the lateral orbital wall along the lower rim. The lateral wall was opened and was completely elevated. The orbital contents were separated and the bony structure was exposed and was removed along the orbital floor and the orbital roof. The orbital floor was paved with a titanium mesh plate.


RESULTS
The mean length of the surgery was 87.7 (65 - 110) minutes. The post-operative hospital stay was 6 (3 - 8.5) days. None of the patients had orbital infection, abnormal wound healing, or diplopia. The patients were followed up for 6 - 12 months. The surgery corrected the proptosis in 25 cases (72.7%) and improved the proptosis in 11 patients (31.4%). No recurrence occurred in the following 1 - 2 years.


CONCLUSION
Orbital decompression by lateral window through lateral orbital wall can relieve the proptosis and improve the eye motility in patients with thyroid ophthalmopathy. The surgery is effective, safe to perform, and gives satisfactory results.<EOD> .

<EOD> Contrasting patterns of polymorphism and divergence in the MHC genes in the burying beetle Nicrophorus.
MHC genes play an important role in a vast array of biological phenomena across the entire animal kingdom. One of the best characterized systems is provided by the bark beetles. These insects have a remarkable biology and serve as excellent models for host-parasite interactions. These studies have focused on several species of the genus Dendroctonus: D. ponderosae, D. brevicomis, D. rufipennis. This research has uncovered one of the most extensive arrays of MHC alleles reported to date. They are organized in discrete subregions in the genome, spanning over 0.2 Mbp, located within the class III genes. In the present study we sequenced the MHC genes from two species of the genus Nicrophorus: N. tattersalli and N. investigator, which exhibit completely different behaviours with respect to the bark beetles. We identified a single MHC class III region in the haploid genome of Nicrophorus. Sequence evidence suggests that, although the MHC region of tetrapods exhibits a highly conserved structure and synteny, distinct evolutionary pressures may have led to a different evolutionary scenario in the MHC genes of the Coleoptera. Indeed, the N. tattersalli MHC genes are characterized by multiple tandem arrays of variable loci within the class III region that are separated by conserved loci. The number of tandem loci exceeds that of bark beetles and is the highest reported in the class III region of all animal species. These data indicate that the MHC region is highly polymorphic within populations of the burying beetles, especially in the closely related haplotypes. This structural evolution is likely due to a combination of gene conversion, interlocus gene conversion and local gene duplication.<EOD> In vivo characterization of the infratemporal fossa and its impacts on the reconstruction with free

Aging and the apoptosis of cultured rat astrocytes Aging in the brain may alter the function and number of astrocytes, leading to a disruption of the cellular and molecular homeostasis of the nervous tissue. To study possible aging-related changes in astrocytes, we established an in vitro model of primary cultured rat astrocytes that were examined at different ages. The cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, and the results showed that the astrocyte viability and population density were highest during the second to fourth passages. The culture medium and culture condition were optimized by examining the cell viability, proliferation rate, and apoptosis of astrocytes at different passages. These results show that the in vitro cultured rat astrocytes are a suitable cellular model for studying aging-related changes for this cell type. We have also demonstrated the presence of apoptotic markers such as Bcl-2, Bax, and caspase 3 in cultured rat astrocytes stimulated with staurosporine (100 μM). <EOD> .

 The problem that occurs in analyzing data concerning marriage and divorce in France concerns the difficulty in identifying "married" persons. While there is no conceptual difficulty in distinguishing between married and single individuals, such a distinction is difficult to make for divorced individuals. The question remains unresolved to which data base, population, the "population on January 1" or "the population as of January 1," to which the number of divorces or separation should be attached and in what case they should be added to the number of married persons. This conceptual question does not, however, have much consequence. The use of different data bases for the same information causes a relative understatement or overstatement of the number of divorced persons in any given period. On the other hand, the difference in statistical data bases, the population on January 1 vs. the population as of January 1, constitutes an element of bias that is only slight in magnitude and can be easily eliminated by an arithmetic correction. Another point of discussion has to do with differences in population between the two types of data bases, and for this a more sophisticated method for population evaluation has to be developed. [/INST/CAN]<EOD> Mapping of Molecular Motions Induced by DNA Methylation in Human Telomerase RNA Using Cross-linking and RNA NMR

Human telomerase RNA (hTR) is the RNA component of telomerase, the enzyme responsible for telomere elongation in immortal cells. hTR forms an intramolecular structure with a compact domain and an extruded domain. DNA methyltransferase 3A (DNMT3A) methylates the cytidine in a single-stranded overhang at the hTR C terminus to prevent telomere elongation. We mapped the three-dimensional structures of wild type and methylated hTR using Cucurbit[7]uril (CB7)-assisted cross-linking and two-dimensional NMR spectroscopy. CB7 binds to the hTR terminal loop domain and prevents it from folding into an intramolecular structure. NMR spectra of cross-linked hTR samples showed the disappearance of CB7-assisted intramolecular cross-linked peaks, confirming that the folding of hTR was disrupted. # Examples

# Discussion
<EOD> .
UNLABELLED
In a first study of our laboratory, an isolated right ventricular dysfunction ("functional" left ventricular systolic dysfunction) was diagnosed during a dobutamine test in a 44-year-old male patient. Echocardiography confirmed the findings. Two years later the patient presented with acute inferior myocardial infarction. A coronary angiography was performed which revealed a complete occlusion of the first segment of the left anterior descending artery (LAD). Reperfusion therapy with PTCA was performed which resulted in the restoration of antegrade blood flow. The second study of our laboratory was performed to assess, in an in vivo model, if the isolated right ventricular dysfunction is reversible. The results of this study are presented. Coronary hypoperfusion of the LAD for 15 min resulted in a reduction of regional and total LV and RV contractility by 29 +/- 8, 34 +/- 4 and 29 +/- 4%, and by 35 +/- 11, 35 +/- 2 and 39 +/- 6%, respectively, following reperfusion in 6 rabbits.


CONCLUSIONS
In view of the results presented, we suggest that regional as well as total LV contractility may be preserved, to a certain extent, in a patient with a true isolated right ventricular dysfunction, even in the case of left coronary artery obstruction.<EOD> .

Six trials were chosen for our review. A significant reduction of MI was seen in three trials with drugs (beta-blockers or statins), whereas the other three trials examining counselling on lifestyle modification showed a reduction of MI.

<EOD> Effects of dietary fibre and resistant starch on cecal short-chain fatty acids in healthy human volunteers.
BACKGROUND AND AIMS
Since studies of fibre supplementation to obese patients have consistently reported decrease in serum cholesterol, reduction of small intestinal transit time is proposed to be an effector of this action.


METHODS
To test whether the degree of the reduction in digesta transit time resulting from the fibre supplementation may be related to its effects on serum cholesterol, we conducted a single blind study in which thirty healthy people were given a fibre supplement (resistant starch+fermentable/soluble fibre, RS+SF) or placebo in a random sequence.


RESULTS
The RS+SF supplement resulted in a significant reduction in serum cholesterol, and a significant increase in small intestinal transit time, concentration of microbial short-chain fatty acids , and pH of the cecal content. The supplement did, however, not change the ratio of cecal pH to acetate concentration. The levels of acetate in the breath were well correlated to the levels of acetate in the cecal content.


CONCLUSIONS
An increase in RS+SF in the diet promotes the fermentation to SCFAs in the hind gut region, and reduces the transit time in small intestine. These may be mechanisms which contribute to RS+SF effects reducing serum cholesterol.<EOD> Proactive use of in-hospital and community care reduces readmissions in a hospital-based complex care transitional care model.

<EOD> Toll-Like Receptors and the Control of Immunity
The mammalian immune system develops defense mechanisms to effectively recognize and eliminate pathogenic microorganisms but also to avoid tissue damage stemming from an overzealous response directed toward self-proteins. The innate immune system is thought to mediate this important task through the recognition of molecular patterns of microorganisms by its membrane or intracellular components. During the last 10 to 15 years, significant progress has been made in the characterization of these putative surface-associated recognition motifs known as pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and those that are present on stressed or damaged cells and damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). In this context, the discovery of Toll-like receptors (TLRs), that were first identified in invertebrates, has had a major impact on our understanding of the function of the innate immune system. During this period, TLRs were shown to be implicated in the recognition of different PAMPs or DAMPs by vertebrate cells, particularly by the antigen-presenting cells of the immune system. This review will present an overview of the recent developments in the field concerning the role of TLRs in the activation of these innate immune cells and their ability to induce adaptive immune responses.<EOD> SARS-CoV-2 and human reproduction: A clinical perspective.

Although a wide array of disease sequelae have been associated with SARS-CoV-2, there are limited data on effects on human reproduction. <EOD> Role of Neurotrophins in the Pathophysiology of Depression

Although the neurobiological mechanism of depression remain elusive, mounting evidence suggest that growth factors such as BDNF and VEGF may play important role in the development of the disorder. In this article, we reviewed the possible roles of neurotrophins in the pathophysiology of depression. First, we introduce the concept of neurotrophic factor and present brief history of discovery on neuronal growth factors. Next, we report clinical and preclinical evidences on changes in neurotrophins in depression. Subsequently, we show the current knowledge about growth factors related to neural plasticity and depression to summarize the evidence that neurotrophins might play an important role in depression. Finally, we suggest future researches using neurotrophins to develop new antidepressants. We hypothesized that new antidepressant targeting neurotrophins may be beneficial for major depressive disorder. We hope this review help researchers understand the possible roles of neurotrophins in the pathophysiology of depression.

Depression, also known as Major depressive disorder (MDD) has become a major disease burden worldwide. <EOD> A systematic review of the epidemiological evidence for dietary prevention of breast cancer in postmenopausal women
This paper reports on the findings of a systematic review of epidemiological studies of dietary factors in relation to risk of developing breast cancer in women after menopause. It is part of a series of systematic reviews of risk factors that affect cancer outcomes in men and women. All published and unpublished papers reporting on individual dietary factors and breast cancer were reviewed. Forty-eight reports published or in press in 26 different journals met the criteria for inclusion. Most of these were retrospective (n = 25) and only 19 used validated dietary assessment methods; half of these, however, were rated as being of poor quality. In the analysis, most studies (n = 39) were grouped into cohort or case-control designs. There were insufficient data to permit pooled analysis. There is mixed evidence regarding the role of fat, saturated fat and cholesterol in relation to risk of breast cancer after menopause. Many studies suggest consumption of soy and other isoflavones is protective, but the results have also been inconsistent. Several other dietary constituents have been studied including protein, energy, fibre and glycaemic load. Alcohol consumption may be of a protective effect. Many of these findings may be a consequence of methodological problems and, given the amount of heterogeneity across studies, data from individual studies should be interpreted with caution. Further large-scale longitudinal studies of various ethnic groups, in which diet is measured prospectively, and validated, are needed to help to clarify inconsistent findings from the current literature.<EOD> Lunar and Planetary Science Conference

In the data set used for this challenge, 96.6% of patients were eligible. So how is the data set generated?  
As one of the challenge organizers put it: we generate patient-level response vectors `r ` by the following rules:

```
If the patient note is identical to the inclusion criteria, the note will be included by applying the vector `1 ` for the trial-level eligibility;
If the patient note is different from the inclusion criteria, the note will be not included by applying the vector `0 ` for the trial-level eligibility.
```

As required by the HL7 FHIR specification, the data validation is implemented by the FHIR validation tool Validator. This validation checks the following validations in the `Patient.clinicaltrial`. FHIR resource:

 * ClinicalTrials.InclusionCriteria.eligibility.eligibility: The Trial-level eligibility assessment must be done.
 * ClinicalTrials.InclusionCriteria.eligibility.eligibility.grade.valueCode: The grade of eligibility as 'Referred' or else must be specified.

The following additional validations in the FHIR `Patient` resource are also executed in the `Patient.clinicaltrial`.

 * ClinicalTrials.identifier must be a valid Identifier.
 * ClinicalTrials.identifier.label must be present.
 * ClinicalTrials.identifier.value must be present.
 * ClinicalTrials.identifier.system must be present.


Additionally, the following validations are performed:
 * The data source for the `Patient.clinicaltrial` is an ID list with the URL(s) of the data sources. `Patient.source.data.source` is required.
 * The validator checks if the data source can be validated using XML schema. Using an invalid data source validator throws an exception when loading the `Patient.clinicaltrial` resource.

`[TITLE] `

# Convolutional neural networks

Another approach that has yielded promising results in the field of NLP is that of convolutional neural networks (CNN). These networks include many hidden layers stacked on top of each other. 
In these deep learning networks, the word features are first extracted with a convolution layer, followed by a deep max-pooling (sub-sampling) layer. Finally, the combined features extracted from all the hidden layers are passed to the classification layer for classification. 

To obtain word level features, a sentence is represented as an array of word segments with word vectors.  The sentence is then fed through a convolution layer, which outputs a 1 x N vector with feature values for each hidden layer of the network.  Each word segment is considered a filter and is convolved with all words of the sentence, with the word vector as an activation function. 
The result of the convolution operation is then passed through a deep max(pooling) layer which takes the maximum value for a word and adds the same word vector.  This operation reduces the spatial resolution of the feature maps as well as making the network more robust to over fitting, which is a common problem in deep CNN networks. 
In order to classify the words, the feature vectors are fed into the classification layer.  The classification layer consists of neurons that have a sigmoid activation function. After training the neural network, we need to obtain the probabilities for each word in the sentence. Finally, we apply a softmax function to our output probabilities. This is equivalent to normalizing the output probabilities to sum to one. 
For all words w, the probabilities p w are calculated as follows. Note that since n is the number of words in each sentence, so the p w are the probabilities that the ith word has the label y i . 
$$\quad
               p_i = (sigmoid(i,w)) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(y_i w)}}$$

AIM
To study the effectiveness and safety of two dosages of acetylsalicylic sodium in high-risk period patients of sporadic cerebral stroke.


MATERIAL AND METHODS
519 patients without hypertension, diabetes and ischemic heart disease were divided into the group of 363 patients (334 males and 29 females, 58.7 +/- 3.4 years). The group included 52 patients (36 males and 16 females, 59 +/- 3.5 years), in whom at the initial period of sporadic cerebral stroke the blood pressure increased up to 180/105 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure was higher than 100 mm Hg. All patients received aspirin in a dose of 100 mg per day during the 90-day period of observation. Patients were followed-up in out-patient setting and underwent the following examinations: MRI, MRA (25 patients), EchoCG (25 patients), Holter's ECG (26 patients), Dopplerography (25 patients).


RESULTS
Only one case of relapse of cerebrovascular stroke was registered in the group of patients with initial hyperemia of the brain who received aspirin. There were no serious adverse events during the 90-day period of observation in this group, and the total rate of adverse events was 3.1% (1.7% in the group of patients with normal arterial pressure and 3.2% in patients with high blood pressure).


CONCLUSION
The use of aspirin in hyperemic period of the brain sporadic stroke is recommended in patients with normal arterial blood pressure and a risk of hypertensive stroke with a good effect and without an increase in adverse events.<EOD> .

<EOD> Surgery and chemotherapy in the treatment of invasive ductal cancer in 7,851 cases: A study of the national cancer data base from 1998 to 2013

The standard treatment for invasive breast cancer is radical mastepies and postoperative chemotherapy. The optimal duration of chemotherapy is not known. A total of 7,851 invasive ductal cancer patients were randomly selected from a pool of 296,309 patients in the National Cancer Database with diagnosis between 1998 and 2013. The association between the duration of chemotherapy and recurrence risk, breast cancer mortality and all-cause mortality (ACM) was analyzed by multivariate Cox regression models and smooth curve fittings. The optimal duration of chemotherapy was examined by restricted cubic spline. The multivariate analysis revealed that recurrence risk was decreased by the duration of chemotherapy, and the dose of chemotherapy. Recurrence risk was increased by chemotherapy with hormonal modulators. Breast cancer mortality was decreased significantly. However, ACM was no significant. Dose ≥ 30 cycles was associated with a decrease in the recurrence risk, breast cancer mortality, all-cause mortality in multivariate Cox regression analysis, and increased recurrence interval compared with dose < 30 cycles. Duration less than 6 cycles was associated with high recurrence risk, increased hazard ratio of death, breast cancer mortality, and all-cause mortality. The duration of chemotherapy was an independent predictor of recurrence and breast cancer mortality. Chemotherapy did not improve the outcomes in terms of all-cause mortality. The dose of chemotherapy was associated with improved prognosis. The optimum duration is ≥ 30 cycles, whereas the short duration is a risk factor.

ClinicalTrials.gov 
"If a patient has a disease that qualifies her or him for the trial, and meets the eligibility criteria of that trial, they can volunteer to be a guinea pig. They can be a guinea pig in one of several phases of a Clinical Trial."
"The FDA defines these clinical trials into the following four phases: Phase I, Phase II, Phase III, and Phase IV. Phase I studies test new drugs or medical devices in humans for that first time and to answer many questions about safety. (By the same token, a drug not labeled "investigational" can be tested through Phase 1 before it is approved for sale.) Phase II tests if the drug works (effectiveness) and whether it causes severe adverse effects. Phase II studies, like Phase I, are conducted in a limited number of human volunteers, but the number of subjects is generally larger than Phase I. Phase III looks at how well the drug works in a much wider experience and longer trial. These studies often take years to complete. ClinicalTrials.gov provides search results for Phase I, Phase II, Phase III, and Phase IV trials. The fourth phase, Phase IV, is the FDA's required post-marketing surveillance to ensure safety even after the drug is on the market"
"Clinical trials help determine whether a drug is safe and effective. They also provide a system for testing new drugs on a pre-marketing basis. ClinicalTrials.gov does not provide information about whether a drug or medical device was tested successfully or unsuccessfully."
"One reason a person may volunteer for a clinical trial is for altruistic reasons. If all volunteers gave up their privacy, clinical trials would not yield the information needed to advance medicine. ClinicalTrials.gov was launched in April 2000 as a publicly-accessible, user-friendly Web site providing information on all clinical trials. The database is maintained by the National Library of Medicine and National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS), part of the National Institutes of Health."

973.output:
<EOD> An Overview of Tremor Suppression Applications

Tremor is one of the most common movement disorders, and is characterized by pathological rhythmic or nonrhythmic tremulous movements. Its implications on society include tremor-elicited hand impairment, degraded functional performance, and social stigmatization. Due to its high prevalence and devastating physical and cognitive effects on patients, tremor has been the subject of continuous research on understanding its neural mechanisms and developing non-invasive treatments. Despite its prevalence, tremor remains an overlooked motor disorder that is under-researched and under-treated by clinicians and healthcare systems worldwide. Current treatments for tremor include medications such as propranolol and diazepam as well as physical treatments such as botulinum toxin injections known as Botox. Although these treatments have achieved moderate success, many patients are left with tremors that cannot be alleviated by current treatments. In these cases, the tremors must remain, or have a significant impact on the lives of individuals, including physical discomfort, psychological stress, and disability and degraded functional performance. To supplement or replace current therapeutic options, tremor suppression using biofeedback, electrical neuromodulation, medications, mechanical devices, and exercise is receiving greater interest as a means to address and alleviate tremor symptoms. Although much clinical research into tremor suppression has been completed, the overall trend of clinical trials indicates a lack of progress in the development of such treatments. In this paper, we survey the literature on tremor suppression to understand what is known and where gaps in the clinical research exist. We identify the many studies published on tremor suppression, including the different techniques and their clinical success, and analyze them against clinical progress in the field of tremor suppression. The current trends that are apparent from the survey reveal a dearth of high-quality clinical trials of tremor suppression, and thus a need for increased clinical investigation.

# Introduction
Tremor is defined as "abnormal rhythmical oscillatory movement of a body segment against gravity with increased amplitude during execution of a motor task" [bib_ref]  The management of tremor

# ❚ [D5.0] Summary

## Summary & Outlook

The application of natural language processing techniques is useful in clinical studies, also for the patient-level eligibility task. In this section, we tried to show this with three different textual features. By combining them with an Naive Bayes model we could reach an average accuracy of 0.896 on 398 patient cases. More research by adding new data sources and additional textual features will give us further insights on the patient-level eligibility task.

982.output:
You are allowed to access the trial-level eligibility matrix of the clinical trial to determine the trial level eligibility matrix of the clinical trial. All rows in the trial-level eligibility matrix of the trial are not in a decreasing order from left to right, and all rows in the trial-level eligibility matrix of the clinical trial are in a decreasing order from left to right.


If you are not familiar with the matrices, please consider it as a 3x3 matrix of the trial-level eligibility for a patient, in which each row represents a random patient for the trial and each column represents a patient assessment factor. In total, there are three columns in the trial-level eligibility matrix of the trial. Each cell of the matrix shows the assessment results of the inclusion criteria of the patient for the trial. A cell of the matrix is empty, if the corresponding patient is not assessed for the inclusion criteria of the trial by the clinicians. 
        In the trial-level eligibility matrix of the trial, the first column represents patient age ,  the second column represents gender , and the third column represents the disease .
       After determining whether the patients of the trial meet the requirements of the inclusion criteria and performing an individual assessment of the inclusion criteria, you should use these results to determine the trial-level eligibility of the trial. For instance, if a patient satisfies the age-related constraint of the first column , the patient is assessed as 1 in age category "18-35 years"; if a patient does not satisfy the age-related constraint of the first column , the patient is assessed as 0 in age category "36-50 years"; if a patient satisfies the age-related constraint of the first column , the patient is assessed as 0 in age category "51-80 years". The same is true for the gender-related constraints of the second of the columns and the disease-related constraints of the third of the columns. Note that the trial-level eligibility matrix of the trial is in a decreasing order from left to right.

<EOD> Tinnitus: a comparison of the effects of anxiolytic and hearing aids treatments on tinnitus loudness.
OBJECTIVES
To investigate the impact of anxiolytic treatment and hearing aids on tinnitus loudness, and which factors influence the response to these treatments.


DESIGN
Non-randomised prospective clinical trial.


PARTICIPANTS
One hundred and thirty-eight consecutive referrals with tinnitus were followed up for 1 year.


METHODS
This study looked at the changes in tinnitus, self reported, subjectively, after 6 months of amitriptyline and 6 months after the fitting of hearing aids, as well as examining the possible variables influencing the improvement in tinnitus. A tinnitus diary was kept on a daily basis, and at the first visit and every 6 months patients were assessed for anxiety, depression and hearing loss. Tinnitus questionnaires were completed on self assessment of annoyance and sleep disturbance.


RESULTS
Thirty-two patients did not reattend for the assessments, and a total of 86 had completed data sets available for analysis. Amitriptyline was found to have a significantly beneficial response in 34 of 46 patients (73.91%), and tinnitus distress was reduced in 67 of 79 patients (84.81% 95% CI ) in the group fitted with hearing aids. Depression was an independent predictor of positive responses in the amitriptyline group, with a history of a hearing threshold greater than 10 dB in the better hearing ear predicting favourable outcomes for hearing aids.


CONCLUSIONS
Amitriptyline could be useful in selected patients and hearing aids as effective as amitriptyline. Clinicians need to be aware that both treatments may require a delay in positive response.<EOD> LDL size determines the response to diet and losartan in hypertension.

#

Learn more about competitions

See a List of Running Concretized Contests

Register your contest

[T]The main idea of this competition is to find a data-driven way to predict which patients would benefit from a given anti-cancer drug and which wouldn't benefit (or even worsen). If this research is successful, we may be able to selectively treat cancer patients with drugs that have the greatest chance of working for their cancers. Our hope is that, for many patients, this would mean sparing them from the side effects of ineffective treatments and reducing costs. We also hope that this research will lead to new methods to estimate the chance that a patient's cancer will respond to the drug. In this competition, we will be focusing on the subset of patients treated with the drugs pazopanib and gefitinib to predict the probability that a given patient's cancer would respond to the drugs. ### About cancer clinical trials The [T] [T]Cancer is, in a generic sense, the leading cause of death. More specifically, each year over 1.5 million Americans are diagnosed with cancer and more than 500,000 die of cancer. Most of these cancers either have no therapy at all, or standard therapy. Our hypothesis is that if we look only at cancers we feel reasonably confident will respond to therapy, we may still see a 20-200 fold difference in response rates. One limitation of our hypothesis is that we can expect relatively few cancers (and hence few patients treated for them) to respond to a given drug, with a drug response defined by the shrinking of the tumor size for each patient tested. The fact that patients may die before a complete response is observed with some drugs also poses a problem. In order to have a successful competition, it will be necessary for us

1012.output:
# Conclusion
In this tutorial we have introduced the concept of clinical trials using a simple example. We used the inclusion and exclusion criteria to compare a patient note and a clinical trial and evaluated its suitability based on a set of rules. In a real-life setting, the use of inclusion and exclusion criteria is standard practise in a clinical trial. In the biomedical domain, many tools have been developed for eligibility assessment, e.g. KDMR [bib_ref]  A knowledge driven method for patient eligibility assessment, Effort [/bib_ref]  , MedXN [bib_ref]  MedXN: An ontology-based, cross-platform medical applications search engine -design and evaluation, Noy [/bib_ref]  , MedTN [bib_ref]  MedTN: A novel approach for eligibility assessment in clinical trials, Zhang [/bib_ref]  , MedLEE [bib_ref]  MedLEE: A high-performance medication information extraction system for clinical narratives, Xu [/bib_ref]  , Med-EX [bib_ref]  EX: Fast Automatic Recognition of Medical Event Expressions, Munkhdalai [/bib_ref]  [bib_ref]  EX: EXtracting Medicine, Munkhdalai [/bib_ref]  or MSE [bib_ref]  Toward automatic patient inclusion eligibility for prospective trials: An ontology-based tool, Núñez [/bib_ref] . In this tutorial, we have explored this approach on a patient note and have shown the concept and results. To summarize, it was simple yet challenging and the clinical trials are not standardized and difficult to assess. We have not used any tool to conduct this assessment but the use of tools could ease the process, reduce the overall time for assessment and enable researchers and clinicians to identify clinical trials they may be suitable for [bib_ref]  Eliciting patients' eligibility in prospective trials from primary care electronic records, Zeng [/bib_ref] .

HISTORY AND CLINICAL FINDINGS
Male patient, 85 y, with chronic heart failure (HF) as primary diagnosis. The patient was admitted to the emergency department because of dyspnea, pain in the area of the scapula, and weakness of all limbs over the last six days, which were accompanied by increasing dys- oral, dysphagia, diarrhea, and weight loss (90 kg to 79 kg).


INVESTIGATIONS
Apart from HF, the initial laboratory tests showed a normal leucocyte count and normal kidney function/electrolytes. The patient's brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) was slightly elevated (110 ng/l) at 398 ng/l. His thyroid-stimulating-hormone (TSH) was increased (26.12 µU/ml), his free T3 levels were decreased (0.55 pmol/l), and his free T4 was normal (0.92 pmol/l).


TREATMENT AND COURSE
Apart from the application of dopamine, i.v., the patient was treated with antibiotics for infectious pneumonia and a proton-pump inhibitor for gastroesophageal reflux. His free T3 levels increased from 0.55 pmol/l on admission to 2.1 pmol/l in the following few days and the TSH decreased to a normal value. However, the patient died two days after his admission from hypovolemic shock caused by the worsening of heart failure during the further hospital course. His final BNP and NT-proBNP were 1121 ng/l and 14,377 ng/l.


CONCLUSIONS
Pneumonia, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances are the most common causes of T3 and T4 disorders in HF. Thyroid-related metabolic abnormal

## Procedures for requesting access to the dataset

### Description (provided by the data custodian)
The University's Health Sciences Statistics Data Center (STA) can be seen at the following URL: . Please use the “Contact Us” form on the STA website to access the Clinical Trials Support service to request access to the dataset. STA is a secure research space for University of Toronto faculty, students and staff. All who have completed the training program are admitted. STA provides computing environment with access to a wide range of statistical software under central administrator control. STA contains three databases. Two of these databases, called HSDC and UTREB, store data from research projects funded by ICES and the research ethics board (REB) respectively. The third database is a clinical trial support database that contains information on clinical trials and health system data sources on which to identify potentially eligible patients. We require this information before recruitment of trial volunteers begins.

### Data access (provided by the data custodian)
Researchers seeking to use this dataset as part of a health research project must first complete the STA training program. Once trained, they can access the database via STA's client via their own University of Toronto credentials. After submitting a data access request, the researcher will need to be trained on how to access and extract data from STA. The researcher can then request the specific data needed from the data custodian. Only University of Toronto faculty, staff, and students can access STA, and only when they have completed the relevant training and have had their project approved by the STA's research ethics board.

### Supporting documentation/policy (provided by the data custodian)

<EOD> The effects of inpatient psycho‐oncological intervention (PI): A randomized controlled trial comparing standard and enhanced intervention
Despite improvements in early cancer detection and treatment, metastatic neoplasm often still remains without cure. Cancer patients often die by other diseases rather than by cancer itself; therefore, symptoms of the disease and its treatment (distress symptoms) gain special importance. Thus, psycho‐oncological intervention (PI) or psycho‐oncological palliative therapy has proven to be very beneficial. We investigated the effects of inpatient PI, which comprises two parts, symptom‐oriented intervention and psychotherapeutic/psychodynamic therapy, using a randomized controlled study design with patients suffering from metastasized solid tumors in a palliative situation. Both the treatment group (N = 39) and the waiting list control group (N = 38) show improvements of symptom distress and quality of life. The treatment group in particular improved in symptom distress. Synopsis This paper describes the use of the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) administered by trained lay interviewers to a community-based pregnancy sample to determine the incidence and predictors of postpartum depressed mood. Antenatal history and social characteristics of 1062 women was analysed together with data on 820 of these women obtained at the time of an interview 6 weeks postnatally. Results showed a frequency of postpartum depressed mood of 12·2% on the EPDS and a higher rate of depressed mood among single women, those with an antenatal history of depressed mood and those with current emotional/relationship problems. Social and environmental factors did not correlate reliably with postpartum depressed mood. A further study examined the sensitivity and specificity of the EPDS using a standard clinical diagnostic interview as the standard of reference. This showed an estimated optimal EPDS cut-off at 12/13 to define the presence of high risk depressed mood (sensitivity 0·75 & specificity 0·80) using this gold standard.<EOD> Cystic Fibrosis Bronchiectasis – from Pathophysiology to Care

5. If visit_eligibility is equal to 1, then do nothing. Just go to the next line.
6. If visit_eligibility is equal to 0, then return to the main function and do another iteration of the loop.
7. Call the function `med_eligibility(Trial, v, patient_note)` to check if they meet the medication-level inclusion criteria, i.e., the patients who are receiving some of the following medications:
- Budezide (TID)
- Carbondiimide (TID)
- Combination of Budezide (TID) and carbondiimide (TID)
- Combination Ipratropium + Budezide (QID)
- Combination Ipratropium + Carbondiimide (QID)
- Difluniset (TID)
- Combination Difluniset + Carbondiimide (TID)
- Dihydrocodeine (TID)
- Diphenhydramine (TID)
- Emetophen + Diphenhydramine (TID)
- Erythromycin (QID)

<EOD> Changes in Mating Preferences with Age in C. elegans Depend Upon Genetic Variation

Genetic variation has the potential to influence the rate of adaptation to environmental conditions. The widespread presence of mutations that interact with the environment to influence fitness provides a mechanism for environmental factors to influence evolutionary outcomes. Furthermore, mating behaviors, which can be influenced by environments, are important factors in evolutionary outcomes as they can influence adaptation to different environments. Previous studies show that the worm Caenorhabditis elegans undergoes rapid and repeated genome-wide changes in mating preference with age. However, the extent to which these changes are due to genetic variation or influenced by the environment is not known. We examined whether genetic variation influences mating preferences with age. We used a C. elegans strain with more extensive genomewide variation (CA14206) as compared to the Bristol N2 wild type strain and a related strain carrying a non-lethal mutation in the insulin/IGF-1 gene (daf-2) to examine the influence of genetic background on changes in mating preference with age. We found that the insulin/IGF-1 pathway genes influence these changes, but that the extent to which each gene influences mating preferences with age is dependent on genetic background. The N2 wild-type strain showed the greatest decline in female mating efficiency with age, and in this strain, daf-2 delayed this decline. However, in the CA14206 strain, the insulin/IGF-1 pathway genes had little influence on changes in mating preference with age. Daf-2 also delayed a decline in female mating efficiency with age in strain CA14206, but only partially inhibited this decline. In summary, genetic variation influences the extent to which mating preferences change with age, as well as the extent to which insulin/IGF signaling pathway genes affect these changes.

<EOD> Genetic determinants of preeclampsia: an overview.
Preeclampsia is a serious pregnancy related disorder affecting 4 to 8% of all pregnancies and often leads to adverse maternal and perinatal outcomes. Despite its recognized importance, its pathogenesis remains elusive and incompletely understood. Over the past decade, significant improvements in the identification of genetic contributors to complex diseases have been achieved. Genome-wide association study methodology was used to analyze more than three million single nucleotide polymorphisms in a large panel of individuals. Among them, the first studies reported by the Wellcome Trust Case Control Consortium demonstrated the success of this strategy to identify the first reproducible associations between variants in the complement factor H (CFH) gene and age-related macular degeneration, whereas a subsequent meta-analysis of genome-wide association data reported by the National Health and Examination Survey identified the strongest genetic determinants of blood pressure to date. Using these methodologies, we recently sought to identify novel genetic determinants of the clinical presentation of preeclampsia, as the clinical features of this condition have some similarities to age-related macular degeneration and blood pressure. Our analysis of genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism data in 200 preeclamptic patients and 200 control subjects identified two loci independently associated with preeclampsia; one in the complement factor H gene and one in the CFH-like 1 gene (CFHL1). This finding, coupled with data from the literature showing that preeclampsia is characterized by complement activation and increased proteinuria, is consistent with preeclampsia resembling a complement-mediated immunological response syndrome of gestation. Furthermore, the loci identified are located within introns and contain functional single nucleotide polymorphisms that alter splicing efficiency, leading to altered gene function and protein expression.<EOD> Exploring the Link Between Nucleic Acid Drug Administration and Cachexia in Cancer Patients: A Scoping Review

Background:Propofol is a sedative hypnotic that affects the GABA A system, and is commonly used in anesthesia practice. Ketamine has many effects on GABA A receptors and could be used to reduce propofol. The purpose of this paper was to study if pretreatment with ketamine reduces the amount of propofol delivered intravenously while maintaining anesthesia for patients receiving sevoflurane/ remifentanil anesthesia for hysterectomy.Material/Methods:Forty patients were divided into 2 groups by applying a propensity score matching method (1:1), including those who received a propofol infusion based on target-controlled infusion (TCI) method for anesthesia and those who received a ketamine infusion to achieve anesthesia. The baseline parameters were balanced between the 2 groups. The concentration of sevoflurane and remifentanil were maintained via target-controlled infusion, while the concentration of propofol was adjusted by the TCI method. Hemodynamic data were recorded after the induction of anesthesia and 5, 10, 15, and 30 min into surgery. In addition, the recovery time of consciousness was compared.Results:The minimum concentration of propofol needed to maintain the target level of consciousness was greater in the low ketamine group than in the normal ketamine group during the first 30 min of maintaining the anesthesia. The average propofol dose during the first 10 min of surgery was greater in the low ketamine group as compared to the normal one.Conclusions:Pretreatment with a low dose of ketamine prolonged the induction of general anesthesia, induced greater propofol requirement and higher blood pressure during the first 30 min of anesthesia, and delayed the recovery of consciousness. AIM
Monoclonal antibodies (MAb) against tumor-associated antigens were developed by immunizing athymic mice with either human ovarian carcinomas or human embryos.


METHODS
Hybridomas were derived by fusion of mouse myeloma P3U cells and spleen cells from immunized mice. Supernatant was assayed by an enzyme immunoassay method. Antigen specificity was assayed by western immunoblotting or indirect immunofluorescence. The antigen purified by immunoprecipitation was assayed by sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.


RESULTS
MAb 2F11-482, which recognizes 85 kd heat shock protein (hsp 85) and was produced by immunizing mice with human ovarian carcinoma, had a high cytotoxic activity in T cell and natural killer (NK) cellmediated lysis, while the other MAb which reacted with human embryonic kidney epitope had neither T cell- nor NK cell-mediated cytotoxic activity. MAb 2F11-482, which had a cross-reaction with murine 85 kd hsp or 67 kd hsp, showed a high serum activity against murine renal or 3LL tumor in syngeneic mice.


CONCLUSIONS
Serum activity against 85 kd hsp and 67 kd hsp was detected in patients with various autoimmune diseases such as lupus nephritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, suggesting that 85 Kd hsp, which is released from the cells by physical or chemical stimulation, is a good tumor-specific immunogen and should be examined as an immunotherapeutic target.<EOD> .

Experiments were carried out to study the effect of the sympathetic response on microcirculation. The skin blood flow was recorded with a photoelectric plethysmograph, the intestinal mucosal blood flow with a dye-dilution technique and the pulse volume by a tetrapolar phleboluemograph. An intestinal infusion of acetylcholine, norepinephrine and phenylephrine were made in 5 subjects. The acetylcholine infusion produced local muscular contraction of the intestinal and pharyngeal wall (and hence increase of pulse volume) and was accompanied with a slight increase in intestinal mucosal blood flow. The intestinal effects of the norepinephrine infusion were similar to those of acetylcholine but less marked. An increase both in mucosal and skin blood flows were also noted, which indicates the influence of the sympathetic system on intestinal microcirculation. No obvious local muscle contraction or increase in pulse volume were elicited with the infusion of phenylephrine but a slight increase in intestinal mucosal blood flow was noticed. In your training dataset, you should apply your trained model on the training set, and predict the probability for trial-level eligibility of each patient to get a final score for the patient. 

Then you need to define a threshold value from your training data, that can automatically determine whether patients are included in the clinical trial or not. 

You could use the median score or some other measure as the threshold, which means patients with higher scores will be recruited and the scores for those patients will be >= threshold, while the rest of the patients will be excluded. We call them `included patients` and other patients `not included patients`. 

We can use the following R code to determine an optimal threshold.
```r
plot <-rbind(x=train$score, status=as.numeric(train$label))
plot$label <-as.numeric(plot$label)

th <-quantile(plot$score, probs=0.1)

final_score <-as.numeric(round(plot$score + 0.2,2))
plot <-select(plot, `label`=TRUE)
plot.score <-as.vector(lapply(plot, `score`))
plot.status <-as.vector(lapply(plot, `label`))
predictions <-data.frame(score=plot.score,status=plot.status)
predictions$score <-predictions$score -final_score
predictions$status <-predictions$status <== (predictions$score > th)
plot <-plot[1:nrow(predictions),]
plot <-data.frame(score=plot$score,status=predictions$status)
plot$label <-predictions$status <== (plot$score > th)
plot <-plot[1:nrow(predictions),]
```

When defining threshold according to trial-level eligibility scores, if the threshold is too high, then all patients are excluded; If the threshold is too low, then more patients are included than would be expected. We could set the threshold to a value between these lowest and highest threshold for which the patients meet our expected criteria.

<EOD> Assessing patient knowledge about breast cancer risk and mammography: a preliminary study.
OBJECTIVE
We assessed patients' knowledge about breast cancer risk and mammograms to better understand women's screening practices.


DESIGN
In 1994, we distributed a questionnaire in French or English in waiting areas of a teaching and a community hospital to noninstitutionalized women, aged 30 or older, who had at least one visit in an internal medicine or gynaecology clinic in the six months preceding the questionnaire distribution (n = 766 questionnaires returned). The questionnaires explored sociodemographic characteristics and knowledge of the following: (1) breast cancer incidence; (2) risk factors common to non-environmental conditions (e.g., age, alcohol consumption, hormones, family history); (3) environmental risk factors (e.g., radiology); (4) hormone and contraception use; (5) the effectiveness of screening; (6) the existence of "safe" screening protocols; (7) the effect of mammograms on mortality; and (8) the availability of information and training on breast cancer through the health system.


RESULTS
Questionnaire return was 59%. Only 4.1% (32) of respondents were "very likely" to receive a mammogram in the next year (96.9%  were not). Responses were similar in both hospitals and both languages. Mean knowledge scores were 5.8 (standard deviation  2.2) when a score of 10 was considered as the upper limit. More than a third (37.4%, 293) believed that a mammogram could detect the disease when the clinical signs were nonexistent. Some 17% (145) did not know that screening was not 100% effective, and 42.5% (338) had no knowledge about "safe" screening protocols. Only 15.7% (130) knew that a doctor could influence the level of radiation women absorbed. Only 30.0% (2

Background: US cancer survivors may be vulnerable to poor mental health outcomes during the COVID-19 pandemic due to high risks of severe illness and death from COVID-19 among older adults and those with multiple comorbidities, and social distancing measures intended to reduce transmission risk. We sought to examine the impact of the pandemic on the mental health of cancer survivors compared to adults without a history of cancer.Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of data collected from the nationally representative Health Information National Trends Survey-Cancer supplement survey from November 2019 to January 2021. Participants were asked if they stayed in their homes, avoiding other people ("shelter in place") and if they stayed inside as much as possible because of the pandemic. Participants were classified as sheltering in place or not. The primary outcomes were anxiety, depression, and loneliness. Linear and logistic regression models were used to estimate the association between shelter in place and outcomes. Effect modification by age, race and ethnicity and income was evaluated.Results: Of 2569 cancer survivors who completed the 2019 wave and 2056 cancer survivors who completed the 2020 wave of the survey, 1042 and 286, respectively, responded to shelter in place questions. Overall prevalence of anxiety (27.4% vs 41.8%, p < 0.0001), depression (20.0% vs 30.8%, p < 0.0001), and loneliness (32.3% vs 43.2%, p < 0.0001) was higher among cancer survivors who sheltered in place than survivors who did not. Compared to adults without a cancer diagnosis with similar shelter in place status, the cancer

<EOD> The Role of Changing Environmental Conditions and Species Turnover on Shifts in the Community of Endohelminth Parasites of Salmonid Fishes

The objective of this study was to determine how parasite communities change in response to the environmental conditions of spawning areas and as the host fishes disperse away from the spawning areas. We focused on how the community composition, diversity, and relative abundance of endohelminth parasites of two distinct populations of salmonid fishes (Chinook salmon: O. tshawytscha and rainbow trout: O. mykiss) changes across the life cycle during migration from a spawning area and across the salinity range of inland freshwater environments. We collected 478 Chinook salmon and 523 rainbow trout fishes; 181 (38% total) of the Chinook salmon fishes and 203 (38% total) of the rainbow trout fishes collected contained one or more endohelminth parasites. Both Chinook salmon and rainbow trout parasite communities were more diverse in the spawning areas and became less diverse as fish moved downstream. As fish moved downstream, parasite communities of Chinook salmon and rainbow trout became increasingly similar, suggesting that, in moving downstream, parasites from similar niches become more prevalent. By the confluence of the Klickitat River, parasite communities of Chinook salmon are the most similar to those of rainbow trout collected from the confluence of the Hood River. In this analysis, we included parasite species that were rare to eliminate bias toward common species. Species dominance did not vary substantially with downstream location and parasite species that dominated the spawning areas are less likely to be common as fish move downstream. For both the Chinook salmon and rainbow trout, parasites shared between species become less prevalent as the downstream distance between fish increases. Finally, there is a marked increase in the relative importance of ectoparasites, the most abundant group of endohelminth parasites in riverine environments, in downstream locations for both fish species.

<EOD> Impulsiveness and Sensation-Seeking: Relational Patterns and Components, and Their Associations with Psychopathology

The constructs of impulsivity and sensation-seeking are commonly considered independently, albeit with inconsistent findings linking them to the psychotic or personality spectrum. We performed this study to (a) examine the differential associations of these constructs with both the severity of psychosis and the severity of psychopathology/personality traits; (b) examine the extent to which they are correlated with one another; (c) examine the relative contributions of the domains of impulsivity and sensation-seeking to each other; and (d) examine associations between these two components and risk of psychosis-outcome. The final sample consisted of 1,600 adults between the ages of 16 and 63 (M = 34.66, standard deviation (SD) = 12.55) with a broad spectrum of psychotic/personality disorders. Associations of impulsivity and sensation-seeking with both the severity of psychosis and with the severity of psychopathology/personality traits, and the correlation of impulsivity with sensation-seeking, were all significant. Of the impulsivity domains, negative urgency and positive urgency had significant independent associations with the severity of psychopathology/personality traits, beyond sensation-seeking and negative urgency. Neither urgency nor sensation-seeking domains (positive urgency, negative urgency, lack of perseverance, sensation-seeking) were associated with outcome (psychotic-like experiences, psychotic-like symptoms, psychotic-like experiences with distress, distress and psychotic-like symptoms). Impulsivity and sensation-seeking are related variables, each of which are associated with different traits. Impulsive and sensation-seeking traits are not, however, reliable predictors of future psychosis-outcome.

<EOD> Transition from 2-dimensional microbial single-cell array to 3-dimensional human tissues by microfluidic-assisted cellular tissue engineering.
The development of new approaches that can create functional tissues in vitro has been at the heart of regenerative medicine. Traditional cellular studies use cultures, such as two-dimensional (2D) monolayer or three-dimensional (3D) cultures, to provide information on the cellular signaling pathways. However, these cultures fail to provide complex cellular architectural and functional information because the cells are usually dispersed in the medium or suspended in the gel, such as cultures in Matrigel®. These traditional cultures provide only a limited understanding of complex cellular systems because the cells are isolated from each other and are not organized as a functional structure. In addition, the traditional systems often rely on a single cell to form the aggregate that leads to significant variability in results that would arise from the inherent properties of each cell. Therefore, a system is needed that can provide the cell with the necessary support structure for mimicking an artificial tissue and at the same time maintain the 3D architecture for long-term studies. This manuscript explores a new experimental system of utilizing hanging-drop culture to form 3D multicellular aggregates, termed a synembryon. This technology enables cellular coculture and can control the morphogenesis and viability of the cellular aggregates over multiple days with ease of observation within a microscope. Our work explores several variations of the system, such as hanging-drop microtissues with different cell ratios and cell densities, and their long-term coculture viability. As proof of principle, our system was also used successfully to study the formation of lung microtissues as a scaffold and cellular support for growing 3D human lung tissue in culture. This method provides a novel platform to study 3D cellular interactions, tissue formation, and morphogenesis in a simple and high-throughput fashion.<EOD> Dry Eye Disease in Women: Risk Factors and Disease Characteristics

<EOD> A novel PAX3 gene mutation in a Chinese family presenting with Waardenburg disease Type I
The PAX3 gene was amplified by PCR and directly sequenced. The PAX3 gene harbors six exons. Mutation analysis revealed a novel p.Ser152Leu mutation in exon 1. The mutation was confirmed by DNA sequencing, by a direct sequencing analysis of the amplified products from proband’s blood sample (Figure 1). PAX3 mutations have been previously reported associated with type 1WD. In a family reported by Chen et al., a mutation (c.464T>C) in exon 1 was identified, resulting in truncation of the PAX3 protein at codon 155 and consequently in the loss of the PD in the protein encoded by PAX3 gene. In another family with WS, reported by Tsai et al., the authors identified an in frame deletion of five amino acids (Arg-ArgPheGlyGlu) in the PAX3 protein (p.Arg65_Phe69del) resulting in the loss of the ETS DNA-binding domain. They concluded that the PAX3 mutation caused loss-of-function mutation in ETS domain and led to abnormal interactions with other transcription regulator proteins and hence produced abnormal gene products. In 2013, Wang et al. demonstrated through in vitro expression assays that WS mutant PAX3 proteins interacted with and repressed the transactivation activity of wild-type PAX3 and MYOCD proteins, implying that mutant PAX3 proteins were dominant negative inhibitor of wild-type PAX3 and MYOCD functions.
