1075.output: ### Discussion Identification of prognostic biomarkers for predicting the progression of oral squamous cell carcinoma via integrative analysis of transcriptome and miRNA-targets network. Although oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients with the same clinical presentation can have dramatically different recurrence and survival outcomes. Hence, an exploration of the molecular mechanism of this disease progression will be beneficial to the survival and treatment outcome of such patients. In this study, integrated bioinformatics analysis was applied to the selection of prognostic molecules associated with the progression of OSCC. First, gene expression data of OSCC patients were collected and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were obtained via the Wilcoxon signed-rank test based on three expression profiles for gene expression profiling of the OSCC process. Subsequently, a microRNA (miRNA)-targets network was built based on the differentially expressed miRNAs (DEMs) and DEGs. Thereafter, key modules in the network were identified by the WGCNA. Four hub genes and 56 miRNA-mRNA regulatory pairs in the blue and yellow modules that are most closely related to the OSCC progression were retained by the analysis of the KEGG pathway, GO annotation, and literatures about the genes. Finally, we experimentally demonstrated that CAV1 is an important molecule among the genes that influence the malignant degree of OSCC. This study will provide a new perspective and basis for the molecular mechanism of the OSCC process. Since only RNA molecules produced from viral genomes present in the liver can potentially be secreted in the bloodstream (i.e., genomes of different genotypes, subtypes, and quasispecies), we have examined the intrahost diversity of HCV populations. This study aimed to compare the diversity of viral populations in the liver of chronically infected hemodialysis patients with the heterogeneity found in patients of the same hemodialysis centers but chronically infected and spontaneously cleared infections. A total of 54 hemodialysis patients were selected, including three patients with spontaneously cleared infections and 51 patients chronically infected with a subgenomic HCV RNA concentration of >10 copies/ml. The viral populations in the liver of the patients with cleared infections were more than twice as heterogeneous as those found in the chronic patients. ## INST: Sensitivity analysis

# Sensitivity analysis

Sensitivity analysis involves re-evaluating how sensitive the output of a program is to changes in its input, by determining the effect of each input parameter on a particular output. It tests the validity, usefulness, robustness, uncertainty, and plausibility of the results generated by a program.

There are two major kinds of sensitivity analyses: one-at-a-time sensitivity analysis and global sensitivity analysis
- One-at-a-time sensitivity analysis involves running the main program with each potential input parameter varied over a particular range (e.g., from 0 to 250) or with a single value varied 10 or 100 times. The results are then compared with the original results to determine the relative sensitivity of the program to such variations.
- Global sensitivity analysis involves varying all of the program's parameters simultaneously by a certain percentage. This analysis can be used, for example, to evaluate how sensitive the model is to variations in its design or assumptions.

<EOD> A comparative evaluation of marginal adaptation of dentin bonding agents

Aims:The aim of this study was to evaluate the microleakage and marginal adaptation between dentin of human tooth and bonding agents. Materials and Methods: Sixty intact teeth were used in this investigation. After tooth preparation, the cavity floor was finished with diamond fissure bur and the exposed dentin was etched for 15 seconds. Three different bonding agents: Single bond, Syntac, and Enforce were used for placing composite resin. Cylinders were then made with composites in a mold and subjected to thermocycling. The buccal and lingual sections of each tooth were prepared with buccolingual cross-sections. Then the teeth were placed in 37°C distilled water and were sectioned under light microscope after 24 hours. Microleakage was scored and microscopically evaluated. Results: Bucco-lingual and mesio-distal section showed that all three groups were leakage free at the proximal margins. However, there was significant difference in microleakage of teeth restored with Adper and Single bond (P < 0.05). No significant difference was noted in microleakage of teeth restored with Adper and Syntac and also teeth restored with Syntac and Enforce. Conclusion: All bonding agents resulted in leakage-free margin and Adper was least leakage and best adaptation than the other two bonding agents.

L ow fidelity of dentin bonding agents has remained a problem because the bonded interface is prone to hydrolytic and mechanical degradation. <EOD> A review on the use of acupuncture in chronic prostatitis treatment: its effectiveness and potential mechanism

The National Institute of Health (NIH) issued the consensus statement for chronic prostatitis (CP) in 2000. According to the consensus document, no treatment for prostatitis has any "established" efficacy. Although α-blockers, antibiotics, phytotherapy agents such as sildenafil, etc. have been extensively tested in clinical trials, it is not clear whether these drugs really have therapeutic effect on CP. Recently, more and more reports were found to prove that acupuncture therapy is effective in relieving prostatitis symptoms. However, the specific mechanism of acupuncture therapy still is unclear, the specific treatment regimen has not been unified. It is difficult to summarize the efficacy of acupuncture therapy simply by analyzing these articles. Therefore, this article will give a brief review on CP and research progress of acupuncture on CP in recent years. And, this article will also discuss the potential mechanism and the unified program of acupuncture on CP. This article provides a comprehensive review of acupuncture on CP for clinical therapists who are involved in CP treatment in order to make a balanced judgment on the efficacy of acupuncture in CP patients and to make a wise choice of acupuncture program for the clinical practice.

Discussion:

Evaluation

We observe whether the assessment of eligibility is consistent with the real status. If so, we check if the model makes correct prediction. If so, congrats. Otherwise, we should think why we get an incorrect prediction and which factors cause the assessment of eligibility to differ from the real status.

Limitations & Outlook

  1. This model is trained in a single hospital, which does not accurately reflect the diversity of the real world.
  2. To improve the clinical decision-making model, we try to reduce the number of features. We consider it effective to reduce the number of high-dimensional continuous features, that is, the numerical features in the clinical note, as dimensionality reduction methods such as , , and for continuous features may be good ideas. Moreover, we can use feature sets with smaller numbers of features by excluding features not related to the assessment of eligibility. For the ordinal features, we can use information gain for discretized features, which is a typical clustering method for feature selection. By excluding the features that often occur but that are not related to the assessment of eligibility, we can reduce the length of the feature set we need to handle. In addition, even for the categorical features, 's information gain method is a representative method. By excluding features related to the assessment of eligibility, we can reduce the number of features and the computation cost.

Background:The incidence of diabetes mellitus (DM) is increasing and nowadays it is a serious public health challenge. Because of the high level of immunodepression in diabetic patients, it is supposed that patients with diabetes have a relatively higher risk of contracting tetanus infection. However, the results are not conclusive and there are inconsistencies among these studies. Therefore, a pooled analysis from all relevant studies was carried out to examine whether or not diabetes mellitus is a predisposing factor for tetanus infection among humans. Methods: Two reviewers independently selected all case-control or cohort studies assessing tetanus risk in patients with diabetes mellitus compared to healthy subjects. A random-effects meta-analysis was used to calculate the pooled odds ratios (OR). I-square and a p-value were used to detect significant heterogeneity. Subgroup, meta-regression analyses and sensitivity analysis were performed in order to find explanations for the heterogeneity. A funnel plot was used to estimate publication bias. # Related Work 
This is the 21st track of the IEEE Conference on Empirical Software Engineering. It is the inaugural event in this series of conferences. It is organized by ESE members of the IEEE Technical Computing Council. Since 2006, the IEEE has been promoting a change from the traditional view of empirical studies as purely quantitative, with a bias toward large scale, to the emerging view of empirical software engineering (ESE) research and practice as quantitative and qualitative.
We invite submissions from a broad range of topics including, but not limited to: software engineering topics, design, architecture, process, and management; quantitative and qualitative analysis of software artifacts and related artifacts, such as program source code, configuration files, and data-processing systems; social and human aspects of software engineering development; and methods for training and education in software engineering

# About the Track Chairs 
The following people will serve as the 2019 IEEE International Conference on Empirical Software Engineering (ESE) Track Chairs.
 - Tom Van Der Mei, University of Leuven, Belgium
 - Svetlana Yakovlev, Moscow State University, Russia

# Submissions 

We use double-blind reviewing to ensure the quality and fairness of decisions. Thus, authors are required to keep the names of program committee members and reviewers anonymous during the review process. After submission, the IEEE Conferences Publication Assistant will assign each submission an anonymous and unique electronic manuscript number (EAN). The Program Committee will consider each submission by its EAN throughout the review process. During the revision process, authors will be required to resubmit their papers by retyping those pages, replacing the EAN.

Please make sure that your submission complies fully with the following instructions before you submit. Failure to follow these guidelines will result in your submission being returned.

<EOD> .
Dentists' occupational diseases remain rare with few cases reported by scientific publications. They may nonetheless have more incidence than generally recognized and lead to long periods of disability. There is little information about their evolution and management. The objective of the study was to collect dentists' occupational diseases data which appeared as diagnosis in their medical file. We conducted a retrospective study of the disease evolutions and the redeployment of dentists on the French labour market. In a 12-months study period, medical files of 1,074 dentists were retrospectively studied. A total of 45 dentists (4.2% ) were sick-listed and diagnosed as an occupational disease. Twelve were sick-listed by an occupational disease leading to permanent disability. Of the 45 sick-listed dentists 25 were redeployed by the National Insurance System. Of the 24 dentists remaining on the labour market and still sick-listed, 18 were on sick leave. Fifty-three percent were women. Forty-five percent of the dentists had no experience on the labour market, 14.3% had more than 10 years of experience. The median of the time needed to be on sick leave was 24 months. The most diseases were "Diseases and disorders of the musculoskeletal system", "Others", "Diseases and disorders of the circulatory system". Dental occupational disease is little or not recognized by society. <EOD> A novel technique using the bull-eye technique for the repair of recurrent or persistent pterygium

A b s t r a c t Purpose: To describe a novel technique that uses a bull's-eye design pattern, by marking the pterygium with a small bull's-eye pattern and then removing all the excised tissues, to reduce the risk of recurrence of pterygium. Methods: A total of 86 eyes of 86 patients who underwent pterygium surgeries for recurrences and/or persistent pterygium were enrolled. Patients were examined at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively. Recurrences were observed and evaluated by the masked surgeon. Results: The mean follow-up period was 24.8 ± 19.0 months (range, 12 to 60 months). Postoperative corneal abrasions occurred in 9.4% of the patients. A recurrent pterygium occurred in 13 (15.8%) patients, and the mean recurrence-free period was 8.4 ± 10.9 months (range, 1 to 48 months). The recurrent pterygium was treated by a simple pterygium excision in ten patients (22.7%). Conclusions: Our study demonstrated that a pterygium excision using the bull-eye technique is safe and results in a higher postoperative recurrence-free period compared to simple pterygium excision. Based on our results, we suggest that the bull-eye technique is a good surgical choice for treatment of recurrent or persistent pterygium.

# Introduction
Pterygium is a disorder found at the junction of the bulbar conjunctiva and corneal limbus with an inflammatory tissue process, which is characterized by neovascularization and fibrosis. Pterygium is a prevalent disorder, found in 2.1-30.6% of the global populace, and it is common throughout all ages, ethnicities, and geological areas [bib_ref]  Epidemiology and risk factors

(1) POSITION_OF_TRACTOR 
- You should first transform it into a numeric vector.
- Then, calculate the position score for each patient by concatenating the five numerical vectors.
- For the last patient, you do not have complete information. Hence make sure that you do not calculate the score, and move on to the next patient. Remember, the score should range from 0 to 2.
- Next, the average score, ∑(score/5), will be your final score for the clinical trial. The score of a position will be affected based on the length of the patient note.

# Introduction
Pig kidney dipeptidyl peptidase I (DPP I) is a multifunctional glycoprotein with a molecular mass of about 130 KDa. Native DPP I occurs as a homodimer or, like the enzymes of DPP IV family, as a non-covalently linked heterotetramer. DPP I is one of five mammalian serine peptidases that can split dipeptides from the N-terminus of polypeptides. It is secreted from the kidney into the circulation and acts as a regulator of many biological processes. It influences, among others, renal proximal tubular function, platelet aggregation, insulin biosynthesisand blood pressure.
DPP I is a glycoprotein containing 24 potential N-glycosylation sites; only eight of them have been reported to be occupied. The enzyme contains a single N-glycan on the carbohydrate recognition domain (CRD). The N-glycan chain is a heterogeneous mixture, a complex type chitosaccharide. It has the following composition: Man 8 (GlcNAc 3 Man 9 GlcNAc 2 )-GlcNAc(Gal 1 GalNAc) (DPP1-G1) or Gal (GlcNAc 3 Man 9 GlcNAc 2 )-GalNA (GlcNAc(Man 3 Gal 1 GlcNAc 2 )) (DPP1-G2). The glycoprotein is expressed by human, rabbit, horse and many other mammals. The enzyme isolated from pigs' kidneys has been found to be the major formand is the model enzyme used in the studies of enzymatic activity.
Deglycanation of glycoproteins by microbial enzymes was shown to be a promising tool in therapeutics and di

On a surgical side, there is a trend in postgraduate training programs to have trainees perform the procedure more before a trainer takes over. In terms of basic training, there are numerous teaching techniques available, such as the use of videos, lectures or didactic sessions. In terms of surgical training in which a procedure is performed on a model or phantom, there are also several options available. <EOD> Development and Validation of a Quantitative Enrichment Assay for Bacteria in Urine Using a 16S Real-Time PCR Assay
Real-time PCR assays based on the 16S rRNA gene have been established as rapid and quantitative methods to detect and enumerate bacteria. The objective of this study was to evaluate the performance of real-time PCR when applied for detection and quantification of Escherichia coli in the urine samples obtained from patients with urinary tract infection (UTI). To that end, we used 16 real-time PCRs assays in conventional and quantitative modes, as well as a novel single tube technique called rapid real-time (rrt). The E. coli assays were evaluated with a spiked synthetic control in order to validate the results of these three methods and to validate the standard curve used in rrt. Three types of samples were evaluated: urine samples with 105 CFU mL−1 of E. coli as a pure culture, urine samples spiked with 1 × 102 CFU mL−1, and clinical urine samples with >105 CFU mL−1 of E. coli. The results obtained were directly comparable between the real time-PCR assays tested, and the results of these three techniques were similar. The rrt assay was 5-fold more sensitive than the other techniques. When used with synthetic controls, all three methods had similar results within a range of 0.1–10 CFU per assay, even down to 0.1 CFU per assay. The new simple, inexpensive, and rapid assay, the rrt, can be used to quantify bacteria in urine samples with high accuracy. This method will be an alternative to the classical technique for isolating urinary bacteria and a powerful additive for the UTI diagnostics panel.<EOD> Hair dye ingestion with the use of lighter and lighter fluid.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare neoplasm of unknown etiology with clinical heterogeneity and multiple organ involvements. Although LCH is often diagnosed in early childhood, some patients are diagnosed in adulthood. Moreover, there have been uncommon cases in the literature which the patients presented with cranial LCH in adulthood. The demographics, clinical characteristics, and response to treatment in such patients are unclear. We analyzed adult patients with cranial LCH who were treated from 2008 to 2016 and classified them into early-onset group (within 45 years of age) and late-onset group (over 45 years of age). There were 15 earlyonset patients (eight males and seven females, median age 34 (21-45) years) and 13 late-onset patients (seven males, six females, median age 65 (53-68) years). In the early-onset group, five patients were symptomatic and 10 were asymptomatic. In late-onset group, six patients were symptomatic and seven were asymptomatic. All early-onset patients underwent treatment, and the symptoms were resolved in all of them after treatment. In late-onset group, one symptomatic patient was treated, and the remaining 12 symptomatic patients did not receive treatment. The cerebral lesions in late-onset patients mainly involved the corpus callosum, basal ganglia, thalamus, and corona radiata. All of them had residual lesions after the treatment. Thus, our findings provide essential information to clinicians to understand adult cranial LCH,

<EOD> Identification of mammalian GTPases, which interact with the cell cycle control protein p125, using two-hybrid screening.
p125(gag-mil) is a p53 homologue involved in cell cycle control of normal cells. Because some viral oncoproteins bind to p125 and inhibit its function, we identified the cellular proteins able to bind to its coiled-coil (CC) domain using two-hybrid technology. Three proteins were found to bind to the CC domain in intracellular locations distinct from the nucleus. Among these proteins, one was identified as Gbeta, a component of heterotrimeric transducin. In addition, 188 genes were isolated from an intracellular two-hybrid screen using the CC domain as prey. Among these, 129 genes, 57 of which encoded Rabs, were GTPases and belonged to the Rho/Rac/Rab family of small GTPases. We show that several members of the Rac/Rho family are able to bind to p125 in vitro and in vivo, suggesting that p125 has the ability to interact with various members of this family. Furthermore, our data indicate a potential role of p125 in cell movement or proliferation. ## Eligibility Assessment Guidelines 
You can find more detailed information on each step here.


### A) Is the patient's condition one of the indications for the treatment of interest?
A patient can be eligible for a study if they have the condition studied in that trial. You should know the inclusion criteria.
When patients have more than one condition, only the condition of interest is considered. That is, if a patient presents two conditions (e.g., migraine and sinusitis), only migraine is considered. If the conditions in which a clinical trial is of interest include two or more diseases, it is highly recommended that you pay special attention to the inclusion criteria of the diseases.
When this disease condition does not coincide with the inclusion criteria in the clinical trial studied, the patient is considered not eligible for that particular study as long as they do not meet the inclusion criteria. If the exclusion criteria in the clinical trial are considered as negative results, or when diseases that appear in the exclusion criteria are considered as negative effects of the treatment, and not as diseases to be treated themselves, they are not considered a reason that the patient cannot be enrolled in the study.
### B) Is the patient aged between 8 years old and 18 years old?
The age criteria may involve age limits or age categories.
If the age range of interest for an evaluation does not include ages, e.g., 8-16.99, a patient aged 6 months must be at least 8 years old and cannot be older than 16.99 years old. If the age limit is 8-18 years old, if the patient is less than 8 years old by 6 months, then they are not eligible for that study.

### C) Does the patient have a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) scores from ≤5 to 12?
GCS is a tool used to define the level of consciousness or the state of consciousness of the patient.

<EOD> Correlation between blood-flow parameters and the degree of stenosis of internal carotid artery in patients with internal carotid stenosis on the basis of multislice CT angiography

A b s t r a c t Introduction: Internal carotid stenosis is a serious factor influencing the cerebral blood supply, and its assessment helps in predicting the risk of ischemic stroke. Multislice CT angiography (MSCT) is one of the leading and non-invasive diagnostic methods. The aim of this study is to determine the relationship between the degree of internal carotid artery (ICA) stenosis and blood-flow parameters of ICA measured basing on MSCT angiography examination. Material and methods: We examined 40 patients hospitalized in the Department of Internal Diseases, Neurology and Angiology, Medical University of Łódź. All patients underwent multislice computed tomography angiography (MSCTA). The degree of hemodynamic compromise of ICA was determined on the basis of measurements of the internal diameter of ICA according to NASCET criteria. Results: There were no significant differences in mean values of blood-flow parameters between patients with less severe (1-30%) internal carotid stenosis and more severe (31-99%) internal carotid stenosis. Conclusions: Patients with less severe internal carotid stenosis and more severe internal carotid stenosis have similar internal diameter of ICA assessed on the basis of multislice computed tomography angiography (MSCTA). Also patients with less severe internal carotid stenosis and more severe internal carotid stenosis have similar blood-flow and cerebral vascular index (CVI) parameters of ICA measured on the basis of multislice computed tomography angiography (MSCTA).

# Introduction
In the medical literature, one can easily find data about a correlation between stenosis of internal carotid artery (ICA) and risk of ischemic stroke. According to current reports, 15-20% of all cerebral strokes are the result of ischemia of brain tissue and are caused by sten

Study Design: Retrospective cohort. Objectives: To evaluate the clinical presentation and neurologic complications associated with posterior quadrant epidural abscesses and to explore the potential for decreased mortality or morbidity following treatment with emergent intervention. Methods: Forty-four consecutive patients at a single institution with cultureproven epidural abscesses (eight patients had concomitant infectious dissemination), diagnosed via magnetic resonance imaging, who were treated with surgery or antibiotics or both. Patients with postlaminectomy epidural abscess, who had only a single level of involvement and who had undergone prior surgery (laminectomies or discectomies) at the affected level, were excluded.Results: Thirty patients with posterior quadrant epidural abscesses had complete presentations/follow-up: 56.7% of subjects had no neurologic deficits, 20% had severe deficits, and 23.3% had deficits that were incompletely described. Patients with posterior quadrant abscesses had a higher rate of neurologic complications (40%) than those with central epidural abscesses (14.3%, P ¼ .0585). Patients with severe neurologic complications underwent early epidural abscess drainage or had a higher rate of emergent spinal instrumentation (80% vs 60%, respectively, P ¼ .34). Of the 18 patients in whom the epidural abscess was treated without emergent surgery, 66.7% had severe neurologic complications. Of the patients who underwent early drainage or early emergent spinal instrumentation, 40% had severe neurologic complications. # Discussion

In this tutorial, we learned how to write the Python program for trial-level eligibility (TLE). 
Now, you can apply your clinical knowledge and background
and apply the algorithms or computer science concepts.

<NAME>, we appreciate your reading the tutorial and hope that it would help you
to deepen your understanding of clinical trial management.
In the following, we would like you to answer the questions below:

**What would you do if the patient's age was not within the age range of the clinical trial but the eligible criteria were met in other respect?**

What would you do if the patient has multiple abdominal complaints but meets all the clinical trial eligibility criteria?

Can we generalize the three criteria as the most important? In other words, is it possible to create a binary variable that encodes whether each patient is eligible for clinical trial? If so, how can you compute such a variable?

When writing programs for computer algorithms, it is very useful to make all the elements of the algorithms clear to the reader so
that the computer programmer can read the code with no ambiguity
and also
so that novices can understand the algorithm 
and its logical flow more easily.
We would like to share the design principles for writing such programs.
The core design principle is `data first and algorithm later`.
In other words, you should prepare the data in advance and design the algorithms later. Here,
we show you an example of using the `pandas`
library when we wrote the code. 
Following is the code for TLE:

<EOD> Exercise physiology and pathophysiology: how should we apply the concept of exercise prescription to patients with endocrine disorders?
Exercise is an effective and low-cost therapy to treat endocrine disorders. However, the concept of an exercise prescription cannot be applied to endocrine patients, nor can the exercise intensity calculated using the ratio of maximal oxygen consumption to body weight be applied to these patients. Exercise is an effective and low-cost therapy to treat endocrine disorders. However, the concept of an exercise prescription cannot be applied to endocrine patients, nor can the exercise intensity calculated using the ratio of maximal oxygen consumption to body weight be applied to these patients.



Patients with an endocrine disorder are a unique population. Some of these patients are so frail that they are unable to perform even small amounts of mild exercise training, while others can perform vigorous exercise training. Therefore, a single recommended exercise protocol cannot be applied to all endocrine patients. Exercise therapies for endocrine disorders usually involve a combination of aerobic exercise and strength training, which reduces systemic inflammation, improves cardiovascular, and musculoskeletal function (1). However, prescribing a combination of aerobic exercise and resistance training to a population of patients with varying degrees of cardiovascular health (even within an individual patient) and differing muscle strength and exercise capacity is difficult.

<EOD> Development, Refinement, and Validation of a Questionnaire-Based Method to Assess Social Drivers of E-Cigarette Intention
Abstract Background The use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) is increasing in the general population, specifically among never smokers. Given that much work has been done to measure smoking behavior, there is a need for the development of a questionnaire to assess e-cigarette behaviors. E-cigarette use, unlike cigarette smoking, may be viewed as a prototypical harm reduction device. Accordingly, a questionnaire to measure e-cigarette use may best be developed as a proxy for cigarette smoking. Methods Our objectives were (1) to develop a short and psychometrically sound questionnaire to measure behavior in smokers, former smokers, never smokers, and dual users (smokers who also use e-cigarettes); (2) to develop a questionnaire to measure the psychometric properties of e-cigarette use that can be used across studies examining the efficacy of e-cigarettes; and (3) to adapt the questionnaire to measure e-cigarette behavior changes that accompany a cessation attempt as a marker of efficacy of e-cigarettes in smoking cigarettes. Results We developed and validated a short version of the questionnaire in a population that consisted of smokers, former smokers, never smokers, and dual users. This questionnaire was able to measure behavior changes that were associated with an e-cigarette cessation attempt. Conclusions We developed new questionnaires to assess e-cigarette use in smoking cessation attempts and in e-cigarette prevention trials. Application of Measure This questionnaire can be used in cross-sectional, case-control, cohort, and intervention studies to measure e-cigarette use as a marker of cigarette smoking cessation and as a target for preventing cigarette smoking

A patient note is a JSON file that should be created before you conduct the analysis. They serve as parameters for the function that you will generate from the function you will generate to predict a trial-level eligibility.

It is recommended to prepare a patient note for the training and test datasets in the same way.

However, you usually don't want to include cases to meet all criteria for your study. `Exclusion Criteria` is a textual description of the exclusion criteria. # Introduction
Thermal ablation is currently one of the most widespread procedures in the treatment of tumors, which can provide an alternative to surgery, especially for unresectable cases. These minimally invasive procedures are well tolerated, often providing immediate symptom relief, and present acceptable rates of complications and mortality. Various thermal ablative devices and techniques are currently applied in clinical practice, but high temperatures are frequently encountered in the tissues at short ablative times in contact mode treatments, especially in fatty tissues. This is because the target tissue is not the most sensitive one to heat, and large thermal gradients are generated due to the heat dissipation of surrounding tissues. Due to the proximity of major blood vessels and bones, such large tissue temperature increases could result in clinical complications such as coagulative necrosis of bone marrow, thermal trauma of visceral organs, or steam pop syndrome. However, this can only be achieved by conducting the appropriate preclinical investigation using a tissue-mimicking phantom.

<EOD> Tick-derived factors involved in biodiversity and tick-borne diseases transmission

Ticks are blood-feeding arthropods that feed periodically on mammals. In North America, Ixodes scapularis is the main vector causing babesiosis, anaplasmosis and lyme borreliosis, which are three major tick-borne endemic diseases on which several works recently focused. Most of these works used a molecular approach and showed that tick salivary gland proteins (SGPs), secreted in the saliva to facilitate blood feeding, are involved in biodiversity and bacterial transmission. Here we hypothesized that molecules involved in tissue adhesion and hemolysis are also involved in transmission. In this work, we therefore took advantage of our transcriptomic data on I.scapularis salivary gland and focused on a set of 796 SGP transcripts, of which 279 encode proteins with the potential to interact with several biological molecules: 134 proteins contain cysteine-rich domains (CRD) and 208 contain transmembrane domains (TMD). We then checked whether these transcripts were present in I. scapularis life stages with various bacterial loads, using RT-qPCR for I. ricinus, the model species for european ticks. A subset of the CRD-encoding transcripts was indeed present in embryos with or without bacterial endosymbionts, while several CRD transcripts and the TMD transcripts were present exclusively in ticks infected with Borrelia burgdorferi. Ixodes scapularis and I. ricinus share the same bacterial endosymbionts and therefore the TMD sub-family could be used as an important molecular marker to identify infected ticks.

Enhancement of the antitumoral cytotoxic activity of LCL124 by interferon-gamma: effects on survival of syngeneic mice implanted with B16-OVA melanoma. The effects of the co-treatment with interferon-gamma and the antitumoral cytotoxic chemotherapeutic agent 1,3-bis(2-chloroethyl)-1-nitrosourea (LCL124) on the survival of syngeneic mice implanted with B16-OVA melanoma were analyzed. The combination of two subtoxic doses of LCL124 with interferon-gamma resulted in a significant increase of the survival probability when compared to the survival probability of interferon-gamma-treated mice. In the experiments, LCL124 or interferon-gamma was given to animals either i.p. or i.m. The administration route had no significant effect on the observed therapeutic index, which was highest when both drugs were co-administered. The antitumoral effect was specific for LCL124 and interferon-gamma; therefore, it was not due to immunostimulation by interferon-gamma, but rather due to the chemotherapeutic action of LCL124. <EOD> The effect of phosphorylation on mitochondrial proteins: A study in the rat heart.
Myocardial ischemia results in the phosphorylation of multiple proteins within the cardiomyocyte. Underlying cause of ischemia-induced phosphorylation of proteins is unclear. The present study tested the hypothesis that ischemia-induced phosphorylation of mitochondrial proteins was primarily due to phosphorylation by cAMP-dependent protein kinase and protein phosphatase inhibition. This hypothesis was tested by administration of inhibitors specific to these two protein kinases in the mitoplast and permeabilized cell models. Our results from the mitoplast model demonstrate that ischemia produced phosphorylation of mitochondrial proteins. Exogenous cAMP (0.015, 0.15 and 1.5 mM) induced no change in mitochondrial protein phosphorylation. On the other hand, the presence of an inhibitor of protein phosphatase-1 (okadaic acid; 10(-7) M) dramatically increased protein phosphorylation. These results were confirmed in the permeabilized cell model. Ischemia did not produce any change in protein phosphorylation. Exogenous addition of AMP significantly decreased protein phosphorylation while adenylate kinase activity or adenosine 5'-triphosphate (ATP) depletion had no effect on protein phosphorylation. It appears that only when mitochondrial function is severely inhibited, such as in the presence of okadaic acid, does the mitochondrial protein become phosphorylated. This phosphorylation is most likely due to the inactivation of mitochondrial protein phosphatase-1.<EOD> Influence of age and sex on total body and segmental fat estimates by DXA in normal adults.

The results of 162 women with relapsed ovarian carcinoma who underwent high‐dose chemotherapy (HDCT) followed by autologous stem cell rescue (ASCR) with melphalan and carmustine (43 patients) or thiotepa, carboplatin and etoposide (119 patients) were analysed. Patients were allocated to the HDCT regimens predominantly on the basis of their renal function. The response rate (CR + PR) was 31% and the overall survival at 2 years was 42%. The most significant parameters predicting a positive response were performance status (PS), duration of first remission, the total amount of drug given in the induction chemotherapy regimen and the maximum tolerated dose of carboplatin and cyclophosphamide, as well as the presence of liver metastases. Patients with a second complete or partial remission had a clearly better prognosis than those achieving only a minor response or no response (CR, PR: 32% vs 0% at 3 years). [INST] "How can an automatic decision-making system be constructed based on the results of eligibility assessment?" 
[START]

The purpose of this exercise is to review the basic information on the eligibility decision support system (EDSS). EDSS is a type of CDSS that aids researchers in automating the eligibility decision or recruitment of the target population as close as possible. EDSS is designed to enhance clinical trial recruitment and improve data quality and analysis capabilities, thus facilitating clinical trial management at a reduced cost.
While the eligibility assessment is usually performed by humans, EDSS uses automated computer algorithms and data mining to mimic humans. Although EDSS cannot replace the assessment by knowledgeable human experts during clinical trial eligibility, EDSS can assist in assessing the eligibility of patients using data recorded so far. The assessment of eligibility by EDSS can be an effective tool because it can be time-consuming to manually evaluate the eligibility of every participant in the clinical trial.
EDSS requires the following two steps before assessing the eligibility of a particular patient:1) Identifying the set of records representing all eligible patients, i.e., patient data that satisfy the inclusion criteria and do not satisfy the exclusion criteria 2) Finding out the most influential inclusion criteria for the assessment of eligibility.
In this exercise, try to construct an EDSS of your own and compare with a published one.

Rheumatic diseases have long been recognized among the causes of skeletal deformities, yet these skeletal problems remain not widely recognized, and even less frequently in childhood rheumatic diseases. HIV infection is strongly associated with certain mycobacterial infections, including Mycobacterium avium-M. intracellulare complex lung disease, tuberculosis, and, rarely, M. kansasii bacteremia. To explore the spectrum and natural history of bacteremia caused by M. kansasii in people infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), we examined the clinical histories of 63 patients with histologically documented M. kansasii bacteremia (36 HIV-seropositive and 27 -seronegative cases). Patients with M. kansasii bacteremia were characterized by low CD4 cell counts (less than 90/μL) and frequent disseminated infection and death. Seropositive patients had significantly shorter durations of fever (P = .0006), anemia (P = .0002), weight loss (P = .01), and leukopenia (P = .0008), a higher initial mean C-reactive protein value (P = .005), and 57% fewer cultures positive for HIV (P = .01). Our findings suggest that opportunities for earlier diagnosis and treatment of patients with M. kansasii bacteremia may be enhanced by the presence of HIV infection.<EOD> Association between physical activities at a young age and cardiovascular risk factors among adolescents in a high school in Kuwait

1200.output: `, }), dataClass: "instructions", } } The Roles of Serotonin and Tryptophan in Memory Process: A Perspective Serotonin or 5-HT is a neurotransmitter synthesized from tryptophan (TRP) utilizing the kynurenine pathway in the brain. The 5-HT synthesis pathway is mainly regulated by the availability of TRP and the expression levels of various synthetic enzymes. Because TRP is required for protein and neuronal synthesis and various TRP-utilizing pathways, a deficit of TRP is involved in memory process in various brain diseases. Many types of research have been performed to understand the roles of 5-HT and TRP in the memory process. Furthermore, therapeutic uses of 5-HT and TRP in some brain diseases have provided some evidence for their memory enhancing role in cognitive function. In this review, we discuss the functions of 5-HT and TRP in normal and pathological memory processes based on the present studies. ## The synthesis pathway of 5-ht and trp in the brain Serotonin (5-HT), a neurotransmitter and neuromodulator in the central nervous system, is synthesized from L-tryptophan (TRP) utilizing the following pathway in the central nervous system (CNS): 1) L-TRP is converted to 5-hydroxy-L-tryptophan by tryptophan hydroxylase (TPH); 2) 5-hydroxy-L-tryptophan is converted to 5-hydroxy-L-tryptamine (5-HT) by aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase (AADC); and 3) finally, 5-HT is released from presynaptic terminals into the synaptic cleft, where it binds to various 5-HT 1 to 5 receptors. The synthesis is mediated by the serotonin synthesis pathway in the CNS, and it is largely regulated by the availability of TRP, which is also required in protein and neuronal synthesis
